number of helpful: 650 of 720 people (90%) found this review helpful23 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I've played for half and hour and I already feel like I never want to touch this again. The tutorial itself teaches you how to spend money.Basically the game is designed around making the building as tedious as possible to entice the player to spend real money to skip absurd waiting times. I thought the '8 hours to collect wheat' must have been an exagguration but it's not. It's literally wait 8 hours or spend money.The game isn't designed to be fun, it's designed to be tedious unless you spend money.The battles are incredibly shallow. Three lanes of units move towards eachother without your control and you 'tap' them to 'charge' when prompted. You can tell archers to shoot (through a very cumbersome system that is clearly designed for your phone), and 'taunt' which is really the only way you can move between 'lanes'. It's utterly woeful.Not to mention you can again, pay real money to buy better units and buff said units. You also need to spend money to heal units. And spend money to avoid more ridiculous waiting times to build more units.Even on mobile phone, this game seems terrible. It's basically an excercise in tedium unless you pay money. They didn't want to make the game fun, rather they tried to make it as dull as possible unless you cough up money.Avoid like the plague. This is an abomination of a game. Sega and Creative Assembly should be ashamed of themselves.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I gave this game a good shot. Got to level 26 and was starting to gather materials for crafting units you have to normally pay gold for which you buy with real money. It was fun up until that point. The AI after awhile suddenly becomes nearly impossible to beat since they can have several elite units of the same type while you can only have one. And they will be higher rank than you can possibly achieve without throwing tons of money at the game specially with how fast you can level just trying to gather supplies that the missions will be beyond your troops capability of winning without you paying for buffs and gear and super troops bought from the store.This unfortunately is too much pay to win for me to recommend.  I thought when I got to crafting that maybe hey I could just put some time into it and get the same items but with more time required. I gathered the materials for an item, hit craft, and saw that it said stage 1. Stage 1...So I have to gather the supplies FIVE times in order to build anything and if you don't use mastercraft you could end up making a pile of scrap metal instead of what you aimed to make. Mastercraft costs nearly triple the resources of basic craft.Not to mention it takes 12-18 hours to craft one stage. And it takes 12 hours per sheep to get one hide or cows which will take 6 days to recover their land before you can butcher them again and you only get 2 after 20 hours of waiting for them to grow. So with three sheep farms you get 18 resources a day..And the most basic sword/armor/shield takes 25 to start stage one and thats using basic craft not master.This is a disappointing game that I am sad I wasted even a couple days playing after seeing how much of a cash grab it really is. You disappoint me CA...You made my favorite games of my childhood and then you spit out this piece of crap and insult your fans like this. Definite hands down, don't waste your time or your money. Find something far better than this on your phone than a crap mobile game shoved into the pc world.Damn..

number of helpful: 129 of 150 people (86%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												To clarify, Total War Battles: KINGDOM, has nothing to do with Total War series. It is a well known brand, and that is the only reason why that name is being used here. Lets think about it, they could have released a game called Battles: KINGDOM, but everyone knows that by adding Total War in the name, it will get much more attention, and that will lead to much more people trying it. As for me, Battles: KINGDOM, as that is how I will call this game, because it is a disgusting cheap trick to call it Total War, as was explained before by me, is nearly a copy of Stronghold: KINGDOMs. I do not think it is a coincidence. We start in England, oh wow, so cool and unexpected. Whole world is made out of hexes, that can be edited. Build a building or change them into something else, such as terrain modification. Buildings have their roles, which takes time to complete. If You Ain't Talkin' Money I Don't Wanna Talk! I think that pretty much sums it all up, whole game concept. If you do not want to wait, pay! That is what the game is all about.Once I saw how the battle looks, I made a quadruple facepalm, with botfh of my hands, and feet, touching my forehead. There are three fixed lines, that unit is move on vertically, meaning they only move forward, like zombies. They ca not even be controlled, they can swap position with other unit though, at the horizontal level. Burn it with fire! I do not recommend.

number of helpful: 103 of 123 people (84%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Disadvantages:1. The game seems to be purposely slow paced  (especially when it comes to equiping troops and leveling to 2nd rank), it's very likely for most to lose their patience and either buy gold or quit the game. 2. Nonsense restrictions, such as on crafting, which can be carried out only by one blacksmith at a time.3. Gold buttons are everywhere, thus making it very likely to 'accidentally' spend even that little gold bars you got available from in-game leveling and battle quests.4. Enemy AI on challenging and 'brutal' difficulty,  has often additional soldiers which do not appear on pre-battle info. In general it feels the AI is 'cheating' on certain battles.5. The game is quite unbalanced when it comes to the gathering of resources. Insanely long cooldowns. As an example: gathering 20pcs of stone takes 2:30 hours... Upgrading structures consume an imposible amount of resources. 6. Crafting gear is expensive and exaustingly slow, it takes 5 crafting 'stages' and takes about 4 days to craft a simple bracelet.7. There is no way to tell about the water level and flooding likeliness.8. When I reached winter season, I found it so terribly boring, no crops and no forests. Trees yield way too little wood, by chopping 1500 pcs (first castle upgrade) you end up clearing everything around making the map desolate and cold, like Isenguard... Furthermore 'tracking beasts' on winter removes all the last (if any remained) forrest left on the now depressing looking map. In retrospective, I think I mismanaged awfully the resources, however it is actually not hard to do so and go off track.9. The game fails to inform the player early on about building bonuses (forcing you around level 25-35 to demolish, rebuild and spent additional time and resources restructiring your cities). For example, I found out later in the game that you must build producers next to military buildings, it is rather vague how many residences you need to sustain a city and I had to count hexes to make out wood cutters range (tracking and wood cutting range is about 4-5 hexes).10. Has some minor bugs and disconnects from server 2-3 times (on average) during a 6h period.Advantages:1. The game has very well polished graphics for a game of it's kind.2. Battle and map zooms in, up to a great detail, very pleasant to the eye.3. Terraforming (changing the flow of rivers etc) and the changing of seasons is quite nice.4. Great variety of troops, however I'd like more detail on weaknesses and strengths of certain units.5. I believe the game most probably might be much more playable on my tablet.Conclusion:There is lack of vital information about how things work and -alas- you got to discover them by yourself. It's very difficult to enjoy properly this game, you either must have got lots of time and patience or  spend a good deal of real cash. I'd prefer just paying a one time amount for it as a complete game, without the long resource 'cooldwns' and any other cash-involved transactions.Suggestions :Reduce the cost of construction and cooldowns, amplify the benefits of gamer commitment to the game. Alternatively give the posibility of a one time purchase into a 'premium' status (global reduced cooldowns, reduced crafting costs) with the guarantee of no more gold transactions.Epilogue:We choose to play a game in order to get entertained, enjoy some challenge and overall feel better at the end of the day. This game fails delivering such.

number of helpful: 86 of 102 people (84%) found this review helpful31 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												The most interesting and worthwhile part of this game is the kingdom building, but it falls flat on its face.  In the short time that I played KINGDOM I have already asked myself "what's the point to playing this?"Building different buildings and designing your own kingdom is a fantastic idea, backing it up with a total war style battle system makes it even sweeter, but KINGDOM, as others have stated, is basically a tablet game.  The battle system is too simple to be any fun, your guys just automatically walk toward the enemy and there is little you can do besides move a unit to try and trick your enemy (lol) or use a dopey powerup.  As others stated, doing anything in the KINGDOM building mode is ridiculous, with the game trying its hardest to get you to buy premium currency to speed up every resource gathering task.  If i wanted to play a game where I just check in for 2 minutes and then log out and not play for 8 hours I'll go break into peoples houses and water their house plants.Also, building the kingdom feels very empty and pointless, the world does not feel alive at all, (no little medieval people using the roads or bustling about, or harvesting the resources) and since the ultimate purpose of the kingdom is to support the army for the dopey battles, there really is no point.Unless its some kind of end of the road/ high level feature, the building part of the game does not intertwine with the battle part.  Yes you build certain buildings to actually get your units for battle, but besides that there is no direct interaction between kingdom and battle.My opinion to fix this would be to pull it off the marketplace, and bury the code with the E.T. Atari cartridges in a landfill.No but seriously, what I would do is actually pour some depth into KINGDOM to make it almost more like a medieval sim city, then combine a fun addicting city/region builder with a battle system that plays more like an actual total war game like Rome II or Atilla, and your kindgom supports your army in way more depth.  They could even make it so your army invades other peoples realm and they try to plunder the castle and sack the village.If you want to make a free-to-play game with microtransactions that's fine with me, but if the game itself is pointless/unfun, I will not play it long enough to even consider buying premium anything.I love the actual Total War games, but please either fix this or kill it with fire.Now if you excuse me my neighbors hibiscus needs watering.

number of helpful: 83 of 101 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												First of all we need to establish the premise that this game is not a total war game, nor will it ever be strictly a total war game. This game does have total war features but it reminds me of a cross between age of empires and game of war. Positives of this game include its terraforming system which you can change the hieght of land and change directions of water intuiteively. Customisation was also a nice feature being able to make your character but I would like there to be alot more. Battles were fun and I like the inclusion of missions, duels and soon to be a campaign. Graphics and animations are quite good for a mobile game and excelled from what I thought they would be like. I can imagine this game progressing and more features being added to make an already decent game a good game. Now for the negative... I feel like alot of reviews expect this game to be like most Total Wars and if you have that outlook this game will disapoint you. This game is in beta and does not have all the features, it also lacks some polish and the game even crashed once for me and I noticed some bugs in the tutorial, but nothing major. This game also takes time to unlock things so dedication is needed to tend to crops, resources, buildings and missions. You can purchase gold (guys gotta make money somehow) but I don't like P2W, although this game does not seem like anything is unachievable by normal means, just takes a bit longer.My Main gripe with this game is there is hardly any tactical depth compared to Total War, this was disapointing. This game is in BETA and it will get better, but if you do not like it now there is no point in getting it later. p.s narrator was annoying...

number of helpful: 74 of 93 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Keep in mind, this is a beta testing review!!!So I have not played much of this game yet. I can say I was very excited about it when I first signed up and when I got my beta key. Now, well... not so much. The game itself is a lot like a mix between civilization and clash of clans with the battles being much like the total war battles: shogun except without all the buildings you can build in battle. So as a sequel to total war battles: shogun, it is ok. As a Total War game, I do not recommend it.Positives:Graphics and terraforming are pretty coolThe simple strategies may appeal to less serious strategy gamersI enjoy building my townThe tutorial is helpfulAlthough they are simple, microbattles are pretty cool to see because each unit is fighting against individual enemiesOrders are cool as well as they give different bonuses to units and orders are attainable from churchesNot everything is pay to win as some things you cannot use gold to getLogin is good and not buggy (which tends to happen in many beta games)I like the medieval feel of the gameThere seems to be an unlimited amount of "workers" or "builders" which is great!The peasant and craftsman systems (your workers) seems useful.I enjoy having to build multiple barracks and stables that each field one unit as this makes the town bigger and cooler-looking.Negatives:Fighting is too simple (see above positives)Not at all what I expected from a total war gameMore or less pay to win (strong units cost "gold", aka money) You can of course earn gold but it takes a very long time (I guess it makes sense because the game will be free so they need a way to make money)Some buildings are not available until much later in the gameUpgrading buildings seems to take a lot of grinding and upgrading castles (main building) seems to require having multiple castles and towns and having a certain amount of buildings in your town.I personally think that the lord (basically, you) should be more customizable as right now there are only a few different options for hair color, bacjground of profile, etc.So overall this is a fun game although not at all what I expected or wanted to play from Total War,I RECOMMEND IT TO JUST PLAY A CLASH OF CLANS/CIV MIX BUT NOT AS A TOTAL WAR GAME!and because of the pay-to-win aspect of this game, I will not recommend it overall.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I play World of Tanks, so I am familiar with free to play games. There are plenty of games that use free-to-play models well and are developed with a PC gaming audience in mind; LoL, DOTA, TF2, WoT. Generally the obstacle to progress in these games is an experience system locking out hightier or desirable items which you can unlock by playing the game, or alternatively they simply offer a cash shop with funny hats that people buy for reasons?!?!This game is free to play of the mobile variety, so rather than making gameplay and "fun" (insofar as world of tanks could be described as "fun") the route to unlocking things it instead uses your precious time, or your money. Or both. While time lockouts might make a bit of sense for games you'll play occasionally through the day on facebook or your phone/tablet, they make no damn sense in a PC port. There are also shameless paywalls for powerful units and unit upgrades.Also the UI is a straight mobile port so it's got chunky, mobile optimised UI elements.tl;dr I have no idea why this even ended up on steam. As a casual game, the underlying mechanics are alright, but the implentation as a PC title seems poorly matched to the platform.EDIT: I have now played long enough to exhaust my gold and can't really do much other than wait or 'play' the battles.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												I played the game in beta 2.0 and again in 3.0 (it reset the entire game so I had to build everything back up again).  It has terrible resource balance which forces constant market exchanges that are costly.  In battle, it is a classic 'pay to succeed' game.  You almost can't win some battles without buying specialized units.  You can craft these special units at the blacksmith but it is very costly and time consuming and at the end of it there is still a possibility 'you workers manage to make a pile of metal scraps' and you lose all the resources you put into and still don't get the unit (pretty much forcing you to buy the units if you want them).  The objectives are trying to encourage duels against live opponents but there are seldom live opponents to play against. The list of frustrations could go on and on with this game.  Bottom line is, if you want to succeed at this game be prepared to spend the $$$$$.

												Total Waste and Boring: KINGDOMI have never written a review for a game, but this one deserves oneI was part of the beta testing and really tried to play the game and expandAfter 53.4 hrs and 5 regions with level3 Castles, game turned out to be a major battle grinder to level up my units so they don't suck. After a battle i had to wait for an average of 15 minutes for them to recover in order to reuse them again .... (or pay gold to insta-revive them). I decided enough is enough and uninstalled. Will never touch this game again.The ammount of time you need to spend to actually do something in this game can be compared to smoking. Every 10-15 minutes you need to launch game to play a battle or harvest something and repeat that forever...You need to calculate the 2-3 or 8 hour periods so you login and click stuff to collect because they need to be clicked....So either you have no life and no other games to play, or you are rich and have cash to spend to play the game without wasting your time.I don't even wanna talk about the combat system because i will spend 2 hours writing my complaints about how much it sucks.1/10 It can fool you for some hours until you realize that it isn't worth your time

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												What's the difference between Total War: Kingdom and Goat Simulator?One is a complete and utter joke, the other is a game about goats.TW:K Sucks so much. Firstly, I give it a go, a good go - I put in many hours to get a complete look at the game.First of all - The resource system doesnt even work properly - you wait for several hours to collect wood, for instance, but you have to actually be online to collect it. It's not like its a proper streaming economy - this would be so much better. You buy a woodcutter - all your work should be done.Secondly - The balance is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible - It's so obviously pay-to-win its excrutiatingly painful to play against other people. I muster the best units I can, with all the upgrades. I didn't purchase any gold so I couldnt recruit the most advanced units (which would cost 200 gold OR approximately 300 hours playtime to get 200 gold for free).Moreover, No more rock-paper-scissors style Total War. Archers now beat cavalry in melee, spearmen beat swordsmen etc.Thirdly - The battles are so damn boring. I mean, who thought this could be fun at all? There's also a lot of UI lag, which makes it hard for you to get 'Good' or 'Perfect' charges to any level of consistency. At times it runs like a jet-ski on gravel despite it being played on a high-end PC. I know this is a seperate team of people from Creative Assembly and they may or may not have worked on previous titles, but I suggest that anyone in CA who has an ounce of goodwill in his body, kick these devs out of CA. But I guess I wait to wait 8 years for that to happen (or get it NOW for 500 gold!).

Posted: April 10, 2015
												Total War? ... Total Rubbish. Casual. Pay to win. Battles lacking any strategy at all. Even the tutorial makes you use gold instead of waiting hours to harvest wheat or mine stone. Utterly stupid. But you can build a barracks in 8 seconds.  Right.  Uninstalled. Back to Attila I go.Edit: "if you can earn gold, how is this a pay to win game?"Im sorry, but starting with gold and being able to earn gold by playing the game does not mean it isn't Pay to Win. I think a lot of the backlash is because this is being released firstly as a PC game (not Andriod or iOS) and thereofre Total War fans expect a deeper gameplay experience. I have no inherant hate for pay to win as a category. Pay to win just should not be in the same category as Total War. For example, I spent over 100 hours on an android game called Real Racing 3. Similar mechanics, you can wait for your car to repair through a timer or pay gold to do it instantly.  you could earn gold by playing, or buy it at the store. Later, there were also restrictions on what you could buy based on completing the lower level races. The fundamental difference between the two was that RR3 was fun, and this is not.Especially when you compare it to the other full total war gaming experiences available on Steam

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												STATEMENT:"Total War Battles: KINGDOM is very enjoyable, but has too many pay-to-win apsects"RATING :6 / 10INTRODUCTION:Very enjoyable and I just played the first 7.8 hours without a brake. However, there are quiet a few cons to it as well.PROS : - Easy to learn (tutorials are great)- Free- Has multiplayer and a friend system- Has many types of buildings; the developers have thought about balancing these buildings prices and their purposes- Mining is especially fun, when finding out what resource you will discoverCONS:- Gold is extremely overpowerful as a resource, and is able to be bought- Gold can be exhanged for every other material- Inabilities can sometimes make the game boringRECCOMENDATION TO CUSTOMER:I reccomend this game as it is very enjoyable and can keep you hooked hours on end. But, be wary of this pay-to-play system (although it's exaggerated by the reviewers), and think about if your wasting Gold.FEEDBACK TO THE DEVELOPERS & PRODUCERS:Look, you may be looking at all of those negative reviews and feel like you get no feedback; and say "Whats the point."But, if you make some changes (examples listed below), people may feel more optimistic about this game.- Make Gold not able to be exhanged for other materials- Lower the hours it takes to build things, to minutes- Keep the use of Gold as a 'catalyst' for building- Keep the use of Gold for changing 'Profile' and 'Coat of Arms' aesthetics- Take away the use of Gold to get high level troops, make it possible with upgrading barracks and such- Add the use of Gold to be able to customise what your troops look like (without affecting their battle attributes e.g: Damage, Defence etc)- If you want to not have any more bad reviews about pay-to-win; I say put a price on the game, and refund anyone that payed money into itFEEDBACK SUMMARY:Thanks for reading, and just making a few of these needed changes would make the player base alot less toxic.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I gave it a chance but there isn't anything in the game to grab my interest. The combat is plodding and has no depth, a severe limit to army size and variety, global cooldown when you tell a group of archers to shoot(must be a bug) so you have to wait to even give the order to attack, and limited maneuverablility when in combat which is frustrating. The city building is decent if simple but trying to build where you want in the geography is needlessly complicated-roads and bridges can only be built on certain elevations. Excavating on land next to a body of water flooded stone I managed to find, building dams and trying to release the water somehow to get the stone didn't work so I gave up.Buildings and missions are gated behind a honor system which you gain by doing small quests(mostly just building up your city and battles) the early game is very slow and tedious. Building actions like gathering resources or earning money can take hours of time but can be expedited by using purchasable currency, also certain combat buffs can be purchased. Rather than have different outfits for your avatar or skins for units as their money maker his is where the developers chose to setup the gameshop, a clear pay-to-win formula.As it stands the game does not offer anything of value worth the effort of installing and hours of waiting involved to get anywhere.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												As someone who plays a lot of mobile games with timers and freemium transactions, this game is poor even by those standards.The amount of pay to win is abhorrent - more than I've ever seen before. I found a gold deposit (the game's premium currency) and, after 10 minutes of "mining", acquired 1 gold. It costs 150 gold to purchase a single premium unit. Some upgrades to those units cost over a thousand. As someone who has played almost every Total War game - and was sorely disappointed by the broken excuse of a  game TW:R2 was released as - I've lost any modicum of respect for the TW series. This type of freemium game that was clearly intended for markets such as Google Play, iTunes, and Facebook need to be banished from Steam. I've seen more of them show up over time, and I fear that one day Steam will be inundated with these garbage shovelware games despite the fact that they receive almost unanimous criticism by their customers.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
 Most humble and greatest review for a game, which is the result of miscarriage Remember those browser games, where you build stuff, farm stuff, destroy other people's stuff and steal all their resources so you can repeat this again? Generally they are all the same. You can pay some extra bucks there to get extra income of in-game resources, finish construction of virtually same buildings instantly with a level number increasing next to their name somewhere, so you can spend another 10 minutes of your pathetic life playing a game that's not fun but you can at least ruin other people's fun?This game tries to be something like that. I'm thinking so the very least, in a way when that awkward guy you have as an acquaintance does something strange, you try to be polite and not make fun of him. Which I'm not trying to be, as this game is not my ♥♥♥♥ing acquaintance and it sucks major♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Almost literally.Okay, so here we have it. A F2P game with Total War in its name. A major AAA title you don't even have to pay for. Let's get to the gameplay!You are the lord of some Britbong duchy/county whatever, turns out something happened to your daddy and some old regent dude is giving you a tutorial of doing things, which he was too wasted to do. You build a dam, which is the coolest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ part of the game, because there are water physics (!) then you get praised for clicking on something. Surely increased my self-worth.Oh, and about clicking: you only need to use the left mouse button. Right click does nothing, it would be too hardcore for the game. It's obvious this was made with touchscreen in the mind.Anyway, from first glance it looks fairly average but it gets worse: you need two hours to saturate a resource tile which gives you 20 wood/food/something or you can click on harvest all button, which does it for all the tiles eight hours and nets you half that much per tile. And the best part is: you need to manually collect all collected things by clicking on them. Then wait for it to grow out again. Which won't start until you collect the resources. Then once it grew out, you need to order them to start saturating it again. So much fun to be had! But wait, it gets even better: if you pay money, you don't even need to wait for all this fun, it happens instantly! And you should pay, because getting 10 resources is not even nearly enough, you need about 100 to build the silliest of buildings. Then upgrading it, of course, which costs even more.That's about the management part, but worry not, there is  COMBAT  like in every proper game! And it even gets you resources, so you can have more fun faster! But not so fast. First the concept: there are different units, which is the gathering of soldiers. A battlefield can hold 9 units on each side. To create a unit, you need to build a corresponding building, which gives you one unit of the type you want. There are barracks, archery ranges and stables, for starters. When a building is finished, you are asked to pick one of 4 possible units to be linked to the building. Too bad, two of them are more powerful and you can only buy them for real money, so get your wallet ready! More advanced barracks housing knights are avalaible later in the game but I don't think a living human being played this game long enough to get that far. One unit consists about 16-18 men, so that's about 150 dudes fighting against 150 other, assuming there are no siege engines shooting an army, because they are substracted from the lineup and are shooting offscreen. This is the Originally posted by Store Page: Large scale battles  I was promised, but it's okay, gotta give some suspension on disbelief. In Fall of the Samurai more people died in a single battle than in the entire war, historically.The battle system is having the 9 units forming 3 rows and 3 columns, practically making a square. The first 3 lines charge each other and... you watch them fight. In the charging period you need to click once to get a charge bonus. Once a unit is beaten, the one behind them takes its place and starts fighting. There is no flanking if you have taken one of the columns, you just watch units 1v1 each other until one of them drops dead. Archers are worthless because there is a global cooldown on the fire order and at best they can kill 4 dudes from an idle unit before the frontline collapses. And you can never expect an archer unit to excel in melee.For winning battles you get some resources, then you will wait 10-20 minutes for your injured units to heal. But fear not tovarich, you just need to pay and they are healed instantly.Oh, and these are game-generated opponents of course. I have not met a way to play against other players besides inviting a friend to a duel, which is a waste of time. Basically: this is a f2p  single player  game which expects you to pay money for its incompetent gameplay. I'm sure they have plans for multiplayer and whatnot, but I honestly feel sorry for programmers who have to work on this pile of unfun♥♥♥♥♥♥tl;dr: The design is irredeemable♥♥♥♥♥♥ so do yourself a favour and don't install it. Even better; forget it ever existed Pros: -Water physics on the map are cool! You can grow crops and trees faster, if you make it flow next to them! Cons: -This "game" exists

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												After putting some more time into this, I retract my thumbs up. I dont recommend it at all anymore. Even as an Idle game. The combat is simple and fun, like rock-paper-scissors fun, and the game has a few cool features like terraforming the land...but thats about it.The reward for actively playing is extra silver or resorces for winning in combat. You spend that to build up your kingdom. The only reason to build up your kindom is to build barracks to build your army. Everything else like farming, mining, and tree harvesting, is just too cumbersome to even bother. What they do in hours, your army can do in moments all on its own. Most idle games continue their task whether you are on or not. This game, when assigned to harvest, it does it, but once its done with the task, it stops until you tell it to go again. Now doing this for every farm, mine, blacksmith, tavern, peasant house, and tree farm, It gets cumbersom and annoying. Their timers dont end at similiar times, and the amount of resorces you get for it is minimal. Not to mention, you are out those resorces if you log in late.If the pace on resource gathering was a bit faster, and resource buildings were automatic, this wouldnt be a bad game. But since thats combersome, and there is no need for it anyway...there is no point. Taking the fun out of both sides of the game. I would play a game with a map like that if everything about it was more along the lines of the normal Total War franchise. With scaleable armies, resource management, and rewards you for your time.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Runs better than Rome II and Attila combined.  10/10-----THIS IS NOT A TRADITIONAL TOTAL WAR GAME.  There.  You’re warned.Of the handful of free-to-play, castle-style games I’ve tried, they have been a handful too many.  Stronghold Kingdoms was either too lonely or filled with inter-House drama.  Sparta: War of Empires was too deceptive with its trailers and required zero micro.  Kingdom Wars had too many bugs and performed too poorly.  Upon reading several negative reviews, I convinced myself internally that this game would prove no better.Total War Battles: KINGDOM is none of any of those bad things.KINGDOM, firstly, plays very, very smoothly and quickly.  Controls are responsive and the game doesn’t waste your time.  “But stuff takes forever to grow and collect!!”  Not my point.  When you are in-game and interacting with the world, you don’t encounter slowdowns, or annoyingly-long cutscenes, or needless exposition.  The engine is a well-oiled machine, undoubtedly.  The music is also really good, complementing the game without getting in the way.KINGDOM’s depth really sells it, mind you.  The Realm overworld map is hex-based in style, with each space viable for manipulation: elevation, irrigation, terrain type, etc.  Building placement encourages wise structure layout.  During battles, your formation and tactics matter in equal measure. (a qualm I have is that the archers’ ranged attack acts like an ability and does not auto-fire on enemies; I assume this is done to encourage micro, but it’s more tedious than tactical)  Warfare requires very simple, but constant, micro.  It’s not too overwhelming, but also not "set and forget."And judging by the speed at which units gain experience and upgrade, there is so, so much more to do.“But Gold makes it pay-to-win!!”Accept it.  There is no way around that.  The amount of PvE and personal kingdom development, and strictly optional PvP (there's almost always a PvE option to quests), however, mean there’s more than enough to do without interacting with another human online.  And the prices for most things is extremely minimal in cost.  Need a boost this battle?  Sac 3 Gold.  Desperately need that bit of Wood absolutely right now?  1 Gold for your troubles.  The costs do not murder the player’s treasury, and a variety of in-game methods offer the chance to accumulate Gold independent of any real money you spend on the game.The game does not persistently badger you to share with your Facebook friends with annoying pop-ups every time you successfully gather grain, or pester you to buy Gold every 3 minutes.  The option is up there, quietly sitting on its own, not bugging you.  Mad props for not beating the player over their head with it.TL;DR: Total War Battles: KINGDOM is not your average free-to-play, castle-style title.  It is indeed better than the simplistic tripe that passes on most on mobile devices or sits in the back tab of web browsers.  I would recommend people try it simply because it runs so blasted smoothly, but the profundity to the grand strategy of it all may arguably keep you hooked.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Hello steam subscribers I am here to write a review for this game. Before I get into the fighting♥♥♥♥♥♥spirit with this review I should tell you I am a long time Total War player and started with Shogun 1 when my balls first dropped and have played everything after that and enjoyed them thoroughly (although some more than others). Since the series has been around so long players have come to expect a certain type of game when they see the total war logo with the tiny samurai horseman logo next to the letter, you know the one I'm talking aboot ;)WHAT IS DIFFERENT?This game for all intents and purposes is NOT a total war game, there is no turn based campaign map instead it is real time much like a command&conquer where buildings need time to finish contructing. While there are real time tactical battles, the open ended and diverse battle maps known from the other total war titles are gone as well. This means there are no terrain advantages or disadvantages (at least I have found) during battles and the battlefield is made up of 3 lanes.+WHAT IS BATTLE?+Each lane has 3 slots for units, and I will illustrate how you may distribute your units among these slots by making a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ diagram with text and little symbols herefront<- [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, Ranged, and Siege Weapon ]front<- [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Siege Weapon ]front<- [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, Ranged, and Siege Weapon ]As you can maybe see there is SOME depth to battles, but the meat of battles and how they are decided is military orders and unit abilities and the traditional rock paper scissors gameplay of other TW tittles. And yes, I spelled titles that way on purpose. After your units gain enough experience they can unlock special abilities with a variety of effects depending ont he unit type. Each unti has 2 choices for ability. Military orders are like general abilities but you are able to use them throughout the whole battle but they have a timer cooldown between each use, unliek unit abilities which can only be used once. So troop choice is extremely important in battles and the right combination of orders and abilities.+WHAT IS CAMPAIGN?+The campaign map is layed out before you like a giant deep dish pizza pie on hexagonal tiles. You can build buildings, gather the resources which are silver, stone, food, and wood *INSERT STRONGHOLD "Wood Needed" VOICE CLIP HERE*. I'm pretty sick of writing this review already so I'm going to wrap it up with the big important thign about this game.+WHAT IS LOVE?+This game screams IPHONE WINDOWS TABLET TIME SINK. And like most other tablet time sink the pace of this game  is extremely slowwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww. BUT: and this is where the magic happens; you can purchase a 5th resource known as gold and with this gold you can speed up harvesting, building, and purchase unique battlefield buffs such as flaming arrows and saxon mercenaries. But to be fair and ubjective you can acquire these things without payign gold, but much much slower. So slow that if you go in expecting this game to be as fast as traditional TW games you will be angry and write angry reviews containing 1 sentence referencing pop culture memes.+BABY DONT HURT ME+All in all I WOULD reccomend this as a game you can hop into and SLOWELY develop your realm and then exit and do other stuff, that is assuming you are not plannign on purchasing gold. If you are hopping for a cool medieval total war game you will not find it here. But if you just want a game to pass the time with, and kick some♥♥♥♥♥in some hokey battles than go ahead, I am enjoying it but its definetly not a game I can spend hours at a time playing like other TW games.You can add me in the game or on steam to duel me and let me farm your troops for xp, I will sure be willign to return the reach around/ favor. my lords name is Hershey and he is a grizzled peasant badass.

There is lack of tooltips and explaining, despite there is a short tutorial. TWBK begins easy peasy but it starts to get very hard if you played it a longer time than just 20 hours, as most of the reviewers did. TWBK, traditionally to Total War games has a great concept and fresh ideas, and it could get somewhere. If this small CA works hard to aim this game also for casual players, instead of tailoring it to people with no life, or a big wallet for getting ingame currency, it will be fine. Currently it is disencouraging for me.Sad enough some blame me I play it "wrong" because I don't have conquered 3 regions in a couple of hours, just because I too have a real life somehow.Review Update regarding patch 0.3: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/rometotalwarworldplayers#announcements/detail/743449876219265586

Posted: May 1, 2016
												I've been on Steam several years and this is the first time I've felt like I need to write a review.What is the point of this game?  It reminds me of Paradise Life with castles.  Quite simply no reason to continue playing.  Last month of gameplay for me was logging in for 2 minutes to gather resources and restart constructions, then exit and go play something fun.City building, terrain altering, and water mechanics were fun.Crafting system is terrible and very grindy, in addition to relying on RNG.  This is your alternative to the gold shop if you want the better available combat units and equipment; and not much of one at that.Battles are pay to win.  You will see people say that it is not pay to win because you can get all the same things if you grind enough.  That is technically true; but it takes so long to grind for those things that you are at a severe disadvantage for a really long time.  You can pay to win now, or grind to win a long time from now.In addition, I had first installed this game on my PC and played for a while.  Once it was released, I installed it on my phone and logged into my (same) account.  My Kingdom on PC and on my Phone were completely separate despite being on the same account.  Not cross-compatible.I do not recommend this game.  Do not waste your time like I did.  Go play something else.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												This Game has had mostly negative reviews, but I believe that is due to the miscomprehension of what this game actually is supposed to be. People compare this to other total war titles and, of course, it falls short of expectations. The truth is this really is something different. The only reasons it has the total war stamp is for publicity and because it also has a historical backdrop. However, this is not a bad game.1st - it is multi-dimensional: There is the aspect of building your land, yes, but there is also the aspect of battles. 2nd - there is change: water rises and lowers; there are floods and droughts, and there are seasons which significantly change the way you play the game, so it stays fresh. Also, there are a lot of combinations of units you can use in battle, and even more unplayable units, for example danes and picts. 3rd - waiting is not crippling: Remember this is a mobile game. Things take time to build, and people have lives. If there was no waiting, a dedicated idiot who played 16h a day would win the game easily. Instead, everyone has a chance if they can actually fight, which brings us to battles. if your units don't lose too many people, you don't have to wait. Waiting is a punishment for losing battles, or a necessary thing for building and collecting resources. Also, people keep saying this game has 8h waiting periods, but most times the waiting is 20 mins or so. It is like that with units and most collecting resources. If you decide to fell a whole forest, yeah, it is gonna take 8h, but that is dumb to begin with. Forests don't just grow back, certainly not when you wipe the whole thing out at the same time.4th - though gold can help you win, you cannot pay to win after the first few weeks. Once people actually have time to craft some special units, it becomes impossible to pay to win. The only ways you can help yourself with gold is by not waiting (which helps very little) and by getting special units (which you can also craft, though that takes longer), and special bonuses (which, again, you can craft). It is a known fact that, if you spend too much money on a game, you get bored easily and stop playing - too much money, too little reward. So after the first few weeks, older players who stick with it will be mopping the floor with younger players with lots of money. 5th - Again, this is not a proper total war title. This is for waiting rooms, for work breaks, for commuting, etc. If you want a past time for that, this is a good choice. If you want a game to play at home, do yourself a favor and buy rome and/or attila. That's what steam sales are for.6th - comparison with other mobile games: this game is so much better than any other mobile games i've seen, it is not even fair. Candy crush, farmville, and the like are basically the same thing over and over again. There is very little difference. Also, here at least you get a (very tiny albeit existant) bit of history. You at least learn that there were picts and danes in england. To be honest, there should be more information about that, as well as about the game mechanics. But this is a beta, so I expect that will eventually show up - I HOPE. And you can just enjoy a casual game. If you want something else, something more encompassing, get another game.Still, not bad. For what it is.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												As an early starter and being quite active I had an advantage over other non pay to win players so I would win a majority of PvP battles, that was quite fun and the win money helps build up the kingdom, however there's a % of players that pay to win and befriending them you get free gold on their gold purchases. I was amazed at the amount of money they were pouring into the game.Over a few days the gulf between me an non pay to win against a pay to win was evident and very frustrating as it is almost a guarentee that they win the PvP. I would get the same pay to win person over and over. Other non payers must be loosing interest, also being frustrated.On the other hand you don't need to play PvP and can do quest/mission battles instead. However at 20 mins wait for a lvl 2 unit to heal if NOT PAYING means I waste too much time looking and waiting for things to click....So the micro management, A lot of the time you do things and then find out you can't get what you need, ie you build a 2nd knights quaters to recruit more knights only to find you are restricted to only one knight. The reasource collecting is not bad at first but becomes painful as you progress with high costs and too many things you need to improve to increase your reasource pool, with things having different producer times you can spend hours on the game looking and waiting 5 mins between doing something and really when you look back you haven't actually achieved much.It's a nice looking addictive game and the battles can be fun and frustrating, the tactics are quict simple and rely more on differences in army units and how quick you can click but over all there is little strategy to the game. The strategy is basically what to build where, how to maximim and prioritise reasources.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												First, ignore any review that mentions this not being like other Total War games as a negative. It is not meant to be. It is also not pay to win, because there is no winning, and the wait times for things like growing crops and such are a few hours, perfectly reasonable for this type of game. Now for my review. To put it briefly, good idea but needs work. The game essentially tries to combine elements of Total War, Civilization, and farmville-style games into one. The problems?1. the Total War element, the battles, are terrible. Wayy to basic and repetetive, battle maps are too small. Not fun. Also the rewards are so minimal there is little incentive to do them.2. There is no purpose, drive to the game. No reason to push forward and in that sense the farmville-style element of it is a little too strong.For the above two reasons, I would not recommend this game. As I play this, I really just get the urge to play Total War or Civilizations, it does not do what it should to mesh these game types together in a way that can stand alone.

number of helpful: 20 of 28 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I'm extremely conflicted about recommending this game.  So let me say that overall I'd recommend it as a single player game, but the multi-player mode is just as most reviews here say.  Multi-player is pay to win.There are enough reviews that talk about just how pay to win the multi-player part of the game is and that's the part I would not recommend, so I'm just going to skip talking about that.  Let's just say those people are absolutely correct and there are plenty of reviews that talk about it if you want to read about it.What I do recommend is playing the game as a single player game.  It's a pretty okay simulation if you avoid playing against people who have paid to build themselves up.Alone you have this season changing strategy game where the elements can work against you.  Most people will be warned about Flooding early on, semi ignore the warning, and then be wrecked when that first flood comes in.  You can build dams but they can break depending on how much pressure is on them. Every season brings changes to the game and some things you have to do over a number of seasons.  For instance, you can semi recover from some flooding issues and get land back if you build temporary dams and then make a channel that leads the water to the sea - but there will be some places that the water can still be stuck depending on how you dug things out.  If you try to deal with it during most seasons the water is too deep to do much and you can't build it up.  If you wait until winter when the water freezes, you can chip out the ice and then bend the landscape to however you want it - considering of course that the high waters will return sometime along.As you play more functions open up that are somewhat interesting.  And while the game may not be super deep at the moment (there's a Campaign that supposedly is coming but it isn't in the game yet) it's pretty decent for a free to play game if you just do the single player stuff.You can take as much time as you want building up and such before doing things in the single player version, you see exactly who and what you're going against before you take them on, etc.The novelty of what happens during the season changes will probably wear off over time and all I'm sure.  But for a while if you stick to the single player version of the game it's actually pretty cool and recommended.Fighting others is completely voluntary, so if you want to try this game out you can do so without fear of being destroyed by overpowered pay to win players.There are always options in expanding your realm so far so that you can avoid ever having to do the multi-player part of the game if you don't want to.  It definitely can be more costly than just doing some multi-player battles but at least there still is a way to avoid them if you want here (although that's only a good thing because the multi-player game is pay to win, if it was more fair there wouldn't be a lot of reason to avoid it).I know there will be people that are upset the multi-player portion is pay to win and they won't play the game at all, they will keep far away from it because of that.  That is fine and great if you want to do that.  For me I'd rather just play the single player portion and let the Devs see I'm happy with that part of the game but not the multi-player part.  It's totally up to you what to do with your time but if you want to test it out you can get in with a quick download and test the waters (so to speak - you'll see what I mean :P) in the single player portion without worrying about dealing with the Wallet Warrior Whales that may dominate the multi-player game.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												Reached an unwinnable battle (enemy AI had all the "pay to win" units) Gives me an option: pay money for extra unitsNice idea. You start with some currency, I'll use it now. Causes game to freeze at the taunt screen, sit there for 10 minutes watching the same animations, eventually takes me not to the battle but to the main screen "thanks for the gold purchase, you lost the battle and we won't give you that extra reward we told you we'd give you for buying battle support (even though the "buy support" mission has been ticked off your to-do list)" I was going to write a positive review, talk about how as part of an "easy game" genre it was quite good, but bugs like the example below kept cropping up not daily, not hourly, but every minute. For a pc that could run Rome 2 easily from launch with very few bugs or crashes it's dissapointing this game is so poorly made (there's not even an option for graphics at this point of writing, the upgrades and most of the buildings and units don't have explanations for specific ablilites, forcing you to spend on them to find out what they do - you can see descriptions for soldiers only when you first recruit them, so grab a pen and write them down, especially the pay to win ones wityh bonuses against certain units because the AI uses them a lot to make it harder).Tl:dr, its free, and for something free its more fun than most free to play I see, but it'll stop being fun after about 2 days when the bugs start getting to you. Install it if you want, but don't put any money into it, it's not worth it (also when the game asks you to sign up, just exit the pop up, you don't need to unless you want to be able to play that save on another pc or have multiple saves)

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Honestly before the 0.3 Update it was fine. Now, no. Firstly, they shrank the size of the map, not just overall but also the individual territories, this makes no sense whatsoever. Yeah sure they said it was too "allow for easier management of towns" but that is Bull because it was easy enough as it was. Now it's just too small and everything is increadibly cramped. Secondly, the water is completely screwed to hell. Seriously, I like the fertile land idea, where tiles within 2 of water are considered fertile, that makes complete sense for wheat field, but not for forests. Thanks to the shrunken map I can't even find a "large" forest to use the tracking on. Which is also increadibly broken now. FLOODING is out of control, even when a dam is built on a "Very High" tile (which is the highest elevation in the game) I have dams breaking left and right and flooding entire territories now. Thirdly, Quarrying. This mechanic was not broken whatsoever in 0.2 but now it is beyond okay. Sure the prospect mechanic was a nice idea but the follow through looks like one guy in a dark room put it together in 2 hours. It's completely worthless. Why? Because it will put it say, next to the water (where you wouldn't dig ever anyways) or in the middle of land that can't be dug because of surrounding terrain. We need to control this not hte AI, give us control of where we dig for things and it will be fine, but as it is, this mechanic is broken beyond all hell.Overall this update (which reset all accounts costing everyone everything) is worthless in reality. The follow through is terrible, the shrunken map is terrible, and the quarrying is terrible. Honestly the update is much like a massive step backwards and I would seriously wait to play this until they either patch these horrible things (the map being too small now, the prospect mechanic being illogical and the flooding) or just waiting for the 0.4 update. This game was a ton of fun to drop in for some time and collect resources, do a few battles and then go off and do something back. It's not fun anymore, thanks for the worst update ever.

number of helpful: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Firstly let's talk about the positives:- I love the period, really nice choise, due to the fact that there were a lot of small kingdoms in Britain since the Saxon Invasion;- The art style is amazing, even in the lowest graphics, the game still looks nice and the medium graphics don't consume a lot. The soldiers look amazing and historically accurate, the buildings are cool to gaze at;- I really enjoy the feature of having an ever increasing map where you can build your kingdom the way you like it, aswell as being able to manipulate water, props for that one;- As a Medieval fan, I do enjoy how you start as a small lord commanding only levies and slowly growing your army to more professional units, according to your kingdom development, the idea is there however it's dampered by the ever present and obligatory need to pay. (Point will be developed in the negative aspects);- Finally, I enjoy the battles. They are very simple yet once you get to command a decent size force, you'll be able to see that one wrong move and it could be devastating, making it a more realistic and intense game of chess.Now onto the negative aspects:- I do know this is a Beta, but never have I seen a game forcing you so much to pay-to-win. After the tutorial (which is quite fast due to the bountyful gold you have at your disposal) you start to realize that the game isn't all it's cracked up to be;- I do enjoy the battles as I've previously mentioned but they aren't as large scale as the advert promisses. Allbeit, the game is not ment to be a fully fledged Total War game, however, you are very limited to the quantities of units you can have at your disposal, this could be fixed if a fourth line could engange instead of only three, but looking at the tendency of the game I'm sure if this feature is implemented it'll require for you to pay;- I don't like how you have to wait almost and entire day to do anything productive. Like I said, after the tutorial, the game slows down due to pay-to-win restrictions, however there are some features that can't even be bi-pased with money such as gathering resources through the facilities. I also have to mention that once you are able to withstand the patience of waiting 8h or more to harvest a resource, you only get a tiny tickle of that resource, making the waiting so insufferable;- Once again, the pay-to-win is definatly a must in this game, due to the fact that players tend to have the most fun battling other players, but this game has a hug disadvantage for players that don't really wish to waste that much money or no money at all. If you are like me, who doesn't risk real-life money on games like this, then don't bother playing the Duel feature. Every player I have met had dozens of pay-to-win units. I don't even like how all you can do is just battle the players, you can't even influence or destroy their kingdom or even sack it. All you do is click on search play and one will be provided and you have to hope to the GODS, that you don't face a rich player.- Finally, it seems that the game still needs to be balanced. I noticed a huge difficulty spike when I upgraded the rank of one of my levies to 2. The NPC battles just became mostly unbeatable, maybe I'm just bad but when those Viking 3 ranked units appeared agaisn't my ranked 1 swordmen and rank 2 levies, there was no need to even bet on who would win, so I just stook to Normal and Easy battles just to get a bit of fun out of the game.Veredict:As it stands, Total War Battles: KINGDOM, is a game full of potential for growth and could become a very enjoyable browser game and could attrack casual gamers for a more military historical style game and maybe even convince them and a few others to join the amazing Total War Community. The game is fun at first, but the huge need to pay for gold really makes the player feel bored and outraged with how it shoves in your face how you really need to pay your hard earned cash to build that tavern!If it wasn't for this huge need to pay-to-win and a bit more variety of gameplay instead of just battling the same army over and over again until you level up a few decent levels, then, the game would actually be good, but right now it's still bare-bones, and that is visible in the Multiplayer aspect. Let's hope CA manages to fix all these problems.I give it 4.5/10

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												"1 friend wants this game:" ...lol, no, no you don't.   Being 'Free' does not make something immune from criticism. So here we go.   I am a pretty easy person to please and this is actually my first negative review amongst all the other positive reviews i've gone over, so I hope in knowing that this adds just a little more gravity onto how I disliked this "Game".   I don't think it is as harsh as some make it out to be but it sure isn't anything special, far from it. Compared to the other Total War Games, this feels even inferior to Medieval Total war 1 which at the time I had a hell of a time playing. If the combat at all is even the slightest related to the other total war games then it is an extremely bland and boring version of it. If my Horsemen are at all in trouble of spearmen why can't I dog pile the rest of my men to help aid the in trouble horsemen from the spearmen? But whats that? I can volley arrows at them and hit my own horsemen too? As realistic as it is my other men standing around with nothing to do either behind the horsemen or next to them can also not engage for a sheer number pile up.   I guess it's entertaining for a few minutes but just gets bland. There isn't any real mechanic or system that makes it fun yet. It's pretty mild through and through and it does an annoying job at giving you offers to spend gold on....probably anything and everything in this game which of course makes it PTW. This is definitely more the speed of IOS. Yes, IOS. It feels more ment for IOS then PC and if you want my honest opinion i'm seriously sick of these PTW long time wait and manangment games which dangle offers of temptation to caress your thigh while they ever so seductively slip their other hand into your pocket and take out your time and wallet.   "I don't wait for games, Games wait for me." -It is a known fact video gamers hate waiting to play a game, probably the #1 most annoying things in video games....did you guess it? Loading screens and any means that breaks the player away from the game for amounts of time. If anybody ever says they like waiting on games be it loading screen or timer, it will probably be because between that time they can have a moment to grab a few more potato chips.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												So Total War Battles: KINGDOM is a mobile game that you CAN play on PC.And the mobile game design is integral to this game. Basically this is an incremental base builder.Gather resources, build and upgrade buildings, recruit units and play missions/battles. This gameplay happens over the course of days. Time walls and cooldowns take a lot of time, and the reason for it is...A. To reinforce habitual gaming (rather than binge gaming), so the player keeps coming backB. And to play against the player's patience and need for immediacy, so that they pay real money to get 'gold' and speed up progress.It's important to know games like this aren't made to be games and have fun, they're made to take your money. It's market researched and psychologically tested to get you to spend money.And the game REALLY wants your money, like all games of this type. I quickly hit a wall in which to progress I had to spend perhaps another week gathering the resources in order to upgrade buildings over the courses of more hours so that I can get units that aren't trash and can continue fighting battles fairly.The sad fact is that the game is so close to being fun and interesting, but it's just stuck in a mobile time-sink design.----------Who cares past this line the review is basically over----------I have a theory for as to why Total War is in the title... And that (theory) is that the SEGA publisher is interested in expanding the brand name recognition of Total War which could make the real games sell better.Consider how the Fallout Shelter mobile game is played more than the actual game series of Fallout. ( http://www.ubergizmo.com/2016/02/fallout-shelter-game-sessions-more-than-fallout/ ) mobile games are free, and fun ones will be played by anyone... Like my dad.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												If I have the right to give points to this game, I'd give it 5,5/10. I know it is the first day of release and it is possible that a lot of content are going to come in the future, but this phase of development are still filled things that deeply dissatisfies me. Some of the reasons are listed below:1. Too much freemium. 1.a 50% of the units you can train ingame can only be bought (at this moment) by gold, which is the real world currency translation ingame. Albeit these units are beatable, it would took a lot of effort to beat one, especially the cavalry units.1.b To upgrade your units with armors and weapons, you need gold. Sure the first upgrades are purchasable: +2 damage or +2 defense for 18 golds. But +4 damage for 3 times the price? And +6 damage for 8 times the price of the 1st item? Personally I'm not going to think its worth my while.1.c Costumization ain't costumzation at all. First, the original costumization is very, very limited. And guess what could you do to get another color or pattern scheme? 45 golds at minimal. If I'm to unlock all costumization possible, I'd probably able to spare for a meal in a restaurant.1.d Speeding up times; unless you are very patient on your woodcutter and farm, you might want to check this game once every 20 minutes, since it is usually the interval between starting things and things get done. 20 Stones for 1 hour is long enough, 20 silver for 4 hours and you have to collect workers and send them to work in the smith? The quicker way to get money is really just being a problem solver: fighting picts, rebels, and vikings.1.e Your army is too weak to beat up vikings? Don't worry, just with 2 or 3 golds per battle, you can gain support from mercenaries, or buy flaming arrow for the duration of the battle, or hire an old man as your short-time military advisor.2. Landscaping system: your enemy and your friend. With thelandscaping system in place, players are faced with new challenges in city building: floods and height control. Some buildings require landscaping which albeit payable with ingame resources, are quite fussy. There are some restrictions on landscaping which might forces you to destroy and rebuilt buildings quite often. I just visited the forum and found a thread about flooding. If this is true, then you would want to keep watch on the game for flooding, since flooding literally disrupts your army and silver income.3. Complicated building system. As said, you don't only need reaources to build buildings, you need other things you want to consider before building things: leaving enough space for other buildings to connect indirectly to your castle being one example. The other one is how much space would your farms take to maximize your food output or the reach of your woodcutter to maximize your wood output. Or how many houses or slums or mansions you have to build if you want to keep your blacksmiths running smoothly.4. Quests that are "too demanding" SPOILER ALERT: DO NOT HUNT ANY DEERS, COLLECT ANY BOULDERS, OR GATHER ANY DEADWOODS YET IF YOU ARE NOT YET LEVEL 10 (or about that level). The quests might look easy, but if you're a type that plays expansively (gather all the resources as soon as possible, etc) this might be quests that are unfinishable, since respawn of such resources took quite a long time if they respawn at all.5. Time. Yes, this has probable been the major complains of everyone: the game time. The battles are too short, the resource gathering took ages. If you've wasted all your resources on a building, getting it back might took hours and the games' pace would be significantly getting slower. A quite difficult battle might last for 3 minutes, while gathering resource took 20. The damage sustained by your units are healable between 18 to 5 minutes, so if you lost a unit in combat, you have to wait for a couple of minutes until it reaches full health, or pay gold. Although the healing are automatic and all units are heals itself directly after an engagement, the time between would leave a gaping hole of doing nothing.6. XP system: The XP system are probably the real reason you want to set throught those 17 minutes of healing your cavalry to get it readey for the next battle, since the more XPs you got, the more you can spend them on your units stats, which makes fights easier and more managable. If you're a military genius who can keep all your units alive at the end of the battle, it might not present as much difficulty, but if you're just a casual player, be careful since the drill is real. Although the enemies catch up to you (so the difficulty keeps increasing) the XP does not. After beating an easy battle with all your units surviving, you might get at most 9 XP points. In chalenging battles you might get 12 or more. If you want to add 3 more soldiers into your unit, you need 250 XP. which means getting more than 20 chalenging battles done with all units intact. Add waiting time to the equation and you get about half a day of grinding before you can add 3 more soldiers into your unit. I guess that's all of my complaints for now at this game. Besides the almost unbearably slow speed of this definitely freemium game, I feared that if the development team keeps up with this kind of freemium-style gameplay, things would crumble pretty quickly, and I would personally avoid PVP since playing PVP in this game would seem to be a long stretch for your regular ol'gamer. Yes the design and how the battle works are actually quite good, but with the system currently in place, I'd say you'd rather save your money for other games instead of putting it in this game, maybe on rome or shogun II, or other titles you might like, and generally, stay away from this game for the time being.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I wanna write this review because the game seems to have been deeply misunderstood, mainly due to the fact that mobile gamers are a different breed than pc/console gamers.TOWN BUILDING:For what it is (a mobile strategy game) it does an excellent job. The town management part gives more freedom than any other mobile strategy game i have ever seen. Instead of building the same pre defined slot-based setup town, you have a hex map on which you can do whatver you want and get any sort of layout you want. As you play you unlock more build space and get to build more towns and you can do stuff like dedicate a certain town to a certain type of production or unit etc.COMBAT:Combat is a Total war-ized version of a deck building game, in which armies advance toward each other, time during which you get to fire away some skills and some slight maneouvering. The more you advance in the game, the more control you get over the army. Again, for a mobile game, the quality is amazing. Animations are top notch (i would even go as far as to say that at times they are more fluid than actual TW games) and I find the mechanics to be exactly what the mobile platform supports.It's a mobile game. Commanding actual TW armies in the way TW games work would be a mess. Scrolling, flanking, skills, all that would be a mess in the classic sense, I feel what they got here is the best streamlined version they could think of and for me it feels great.OVERALL FEEL / UIThe game feels good, it feels like a quality product. You're not bombarded by ads, you're not bombarded by notifications and it doesn't feel like a chore. Compare this to Clash of clans which ends up feeling like a chore and a stress factor (is my village ok? have I been sieged? I need to collect my resources!). This is not like that. Animations are great, artwork is great, textures are great, UI looks great. No glossy bs, no flashing buttons, no "SPECIAL OFFER!!!! CLICK HERE!!!!" anywhere". The real currency tab is called "Trade". That's itMICROTRANSACTIONS:Yes, they exist, they're in the game, but since you did not pay for the game, it's normal. Whoever is distraught by microtransactions clearly hasn't played a mobile game before. They're common place. IT'S A MOBILE GAME!Yes, for the last time, it's not a PC game. It's a PC edition of a mobile game. These games are persistent. When you close them, they still run on a server, so the PC version provides another client from which you can access the game. It's not supposed to be the next Total War, it's not supposed to be Medieval TW portable. It's a spin-off. Enjoy it for what it is, look around the app stores for strategy games and you'll clearly realize it's one of the best mobile gaming has to offer as far as strategy games go.If you're looking for a TW spin-off or a solid mobile strategy game, go for it, it's one of the best. If you're looking for a portable classic TW game look away, it's not this, not yet.NOTE: Ignore my steam game time, i've been playing on iOS

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												First of all : this is not a Total War game ! This is a medieval city-builder with some battles elements, designed for phones. If you're looking for a total war skip this and go play total war arena instead.Does it make it a bad game ? No. Well. Depends what you're looking for.Pros- Nice atmosphere. Immersive and relaxing.- Fun city and terrain management. Nothing complicated.- Batte system is great once you understand how it works.- Not P2W, but....Cons- Takes forever to get gold by playing. If you are duelling other players you'll be at a disadvantage until you get a good economy.- If you want things done fast... don't play.- If you want a deep total war battle system or campaign, don't- if you want deep city management, don'tTo sum it up : if you want a relaxing little game where you build cities and battle, then it's good.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game started out fun, but it's bogging down for me.  There isn't enough instruction in the tutorial on how to play, e.g., where to set up quarries.  There seems to be no way to determine where to build them.  It's not like setting up lumber camps (next to trees, of course), or farms (near fertile land).  But quarries?  Do I build them on high, medium, or low terrain?  I've tried them all and it's a crap shoot on finding stone.  It's frustrating to build a quarry, prospect, and dig only to find nothing and be told "the area isn't suitable for prospecting!"  So then, where?    With the battles and my troops, I've reached the point where I almost HAVE to spend my gold to win battles and progress.  Either that or get defeated over and over again, only to get a few experience points and gradually upgrade my troops over an eternity.  I play games to relax and have fun, and take my mind off problems.  It's not fun to have my patience tested to the limit.  I don't mind paying for my fun, but having to choose between buying gold and endless work and waiting on a game just discourages me from continuing.  I'm just about done with this game.
