content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												A good concept, but hampered by its Free-to-Play model. The Good:I love the art style, and the music is passable. The hexagon-based simple city building has promise. I like the variation of the seasons, and that they actually have gameplay effects. I like how terrain, especially access to water, affects resource gathering. I like how terrain will change—grass will spread, trees will regrow. Combat is simple, but fun. A good mix of units, and there is room for effective tactics (and not just spamming orders buttons) to change the outcome of a battle.The Bad:I do not like the running-clock mechanism; it makes the game feel like FarmVille or other FtP “FaceBook games.” Construction takes no appreciable time at all, but gathering resources hours or even days without forking over cash for in-game currency. Some of these times work (e.g. about 20 minutes to fully refresh an army after a defeat or pyric victory), others don’t (hours of quarrying for a measly 20 stone). So, really, what I don’t like is that it is free-to-play.The Ugly:I think if they had kept the core of the game (the map, the combat model, terrain modification, hex-based town construction, seasonal variation), but instead reworked it as a stand-a-lone game WITHOUT the FtP model and constantly running clock, this could have been a solid “midrange” or “light” game. If seasons were “turns,” and certain things (planting, harvesting, etc.) could only be done during particular seasons, the game would be much more enjoyable to just sit an play—instead play for about an hour or less then log out and come back in 12 hours or so. Such a game would necessitate a complete reworking of the way resources were handled, but a price-point of $30-40 would have made such a game a must-buy for me. As it is, I’ll fiddle until I get bored of the grind, then shelve it—and they likely won’t have made any money off of me.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Before I start I just want to say that I grew up on Total War games starting at Shogun. Being a diehard strategy fan, the series rubbed me in all the right spots. Unfortunately this one is a blemish on CA and the series. I understand that it may get better and that it’s still in development but oi vay. Anyway on to my review, the good points are that this game has a fun geo terrain aspect to it in which you can alter terrain to move water and rivers around. This can be fun and challenging at times as during flooding season your whole city can be flooded if you don’t know what you’re doing. I also enjoyed the tile aspect of buildings in which you can get different bonuses depending on how you pair up buildings and where you place them. The battles are scaled down obviously as this is aimed for tablet and phone platform. This kills strategy completely as battles come down to how upgraded your troops are and what gear you have purchased or smithed for them. Early on the only way to get good gear is to spend real cash on it, this gear will open up and be possible to craft later on in the game but you have to make it far to be able to do that. This makes the early phases very pay 2 win as you will struggle against even AI w/o gear. And dont get me started on other players, I didnt even mess with PvP after a few tries as the 5 people I tried fighting completly demolished me because all their troops were high end and fully maxed on gear where as I did not spend money and decided to get ther gear the hard way. The other aspect of battles is the charge mechanic in which you dictate when your squad charges the enemy. Your troops slowly start moving toward one another and if you time it right and click on the squad at the right time to charge you can get a damage bonus. This is very basic and has no strategy to it, to me the total war series was all about the battle mechanics. Now I know you can’t make a massive battle game work for touch screen but I feel they could have put more effort into it and included other detail. I do still want to see how it plays on my touch device though. The other downside is the ridiculous wait times to gather resources such as 8 hours for some (which has been mentioned before). I feel as though this game is aimed to take your money and nothing more, hopefully they improve it as it stand now this game was made to take your green paper with little to none fun compensation. For now, I am giving this one a thumbs down.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I've seen a lot of bad reviews of this game from people approaching it as a pc game, This is not a pc game, it is a mobile game you can play on your pc. Taken from this perspective, I find it to be a very enjoyable game. I started playing it on my phone for a week before downloading it and it only improved the experience. I can't tell if there is more detail or I can just see more detail but it adds to the enjoyment, and battles are easier to manage. I found this game while looking for something new to try on my phone for free. I ended up downloading it on my pc because it was so enjoyable.Despite what others say, it is not a pay to win game. Duels are the only competative aspect and while your opponent may choose to spend money in order to gain special troops, the advantage this conveys is countered by proper troop placement or some extra xp upgrades. There is always a chance to be outmatched in a duel but they aren't crucial to progress in the game. If duels seem unfair, winning a few single player battles will bring up the level, quality, and number of your own troops to give you better chances in multiplayer battles.  The other big complaint I've seen is the timed construction aspect. Once again, this is a mobile game you can play on your pc, not a pc game. The appeal to this is that you can play on your phone or tablet when you are away from home and play the same game from the same point at home. TLDR : It's a mobile game you can play on your pc; set your expectations accordingly and you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I have played this game just for few hours and haven´t even tried all the features, but I would like to share my opinion anyway. In general, the game could be cool, but from my point of view it needs a lot of polishing and maybe some mechanisms should be changed completely.Let´s start with concept of time. Personally I hate when you are gathering resources by clicking on them and these are not flowing automatically into your storage over time. Different resources people included have various time of "spawn", so you are forced to enter the game relatively often. The same thing is with battles. You fight, you win BUT when your units get hurt, you must wait until they will be allright, which can take some time and since you have nothing to do in between, you switch off and then on again to fight another battle. Once I was entering the game every 15 minutes just to fight. You can have more units and switch the healthy ones with the hurt ones but this is just a lot of senseless clicking for me. So you must be online a lot. I suppose people have life and who would like to check his online kingdom fifty times a day, right.Of course this all is so annoying in order to make people use the gold and make the game profitable for the creators. I understand making game is not a cheap adventure but this microtransaction thing should have been made differently. Instead of pushing people into using gold a lot, some real added value related to the game should be offered like special statistics, real bonus features (these what we see now should be mostly free to have things, I was badly surprised when I saw some units may be only purchased by gold!!!) and other stuff. Players could gain increase of production or whatever, but none of it should leave the impression of pathetic need for player´s money. The gold is present like EVERYWHERE which doesn´t make a good impression.I would still not call the game Pay to win, but Pay to make it playable.And the last thing I wanted to talk about, the battles. When you realize it is only rock paper scissors concept, it takes all the fun out of it. Not even two units of pikemen defeated one unit of swordsmen. Also you really can not swith unit´s places, just at the beginning of the batlle, after that, no chance. I know I know, there are these abilities and everything but I still have a feeling that you either win easily or lose "easily" depending only on what the deployment of armies at the beginning was.I was really looking forward to this game, try to give it more time so that I would see all the things, but honestly some things should be changed. So I am giving NO recommendation for now.Btw If anyone knows how to make forest grow or whatever, I would be gratefull, maybe level 2 woodcutter plants them? Slowly all the forests are disappearing from my country and I dont know what to do with it. :D

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												A fun, easily understandable game format.The strategic part is about developing your land. You place buildings in hexes.The tricky part is that some knowledge of river dams and river bank management is needed to avoid catastrophic land management decisions. Flooding can be such a pain as everything is destroyed and it takes ages to restore.The combat part is arcade like with units moving in 3 lanes and with a maximum of 3 stacks. The fun is hitting the unit to make it charge just at the right moment.Warning: Rome isn't built in one day and in this game, certain things take a day to complete so be prepared to do something, shut down and come back to it the next day.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
UPDATE 0.33 BROKE THE GAME SO IT IS NOW UNPLAYABLEThis isn't the Total War I know and love! Downvoted! Rawr, rawr, rawr!I never played the Total War games so I don't have to contend with the usual "I love this franchaise, lets watch it get disemboweled", but having played this game I would like to play more TW games. This game is almost the usual free to play fare in that you have a city to build and it has timers. If you have played ANY free to play game then you know the deal.What I like about TWB:K is that, get this, you don't recruit peasants and then turn them into soldiers! You build a barracks and BAM you get troops. Troops also don't die?! Is this even a free-to-play game!? Instead they go on a cooldown/respawn timer.This means you can fight and fight as much as you want. Yes you read that correctly, no stamina system! This game does so many things right compared to its competitors thats its almost a full fledged game in its own right. If the town didn't have cooldown timers for building things, you would be forgiven for thinking it was a full free game like Relic Hunters.The downvotes and negative reviews this game has do make sense however because had this game been called, Flower Patch Kingdoms it would probably have had a lot of good reviews, but as it stands, it is not a Total War game in almost any sense of the word so for people who play Total War games you really want to avoid this game.For everyone else, this game is fun, I recommend it. With, however, a huge 'Cavet Emptor'.This game is balanced, very balanced infact oddly too balanced infact. You can't pay for an advantage, which I like, always a fan of that but what makes this game so 'oddly balanced' is that each troop has about 3 counters to it so their is no 'best unit'. This is fine for PvP and tough skirmishes, but when you are grinding mooks for resources you can't take a break and just hammer out fights for resources. Every fight demands your full attention because one wrong move, wrong match up, wrong ability used at the wrong time, failure to charge, you get the idea. The battles are busy so grinding in itself becomes something you need to mentally take a break from. A real life stamina system as it were.That doesn't mean the game is bad, but who is the target audience? People like me who are new to TW? Or casual gamers, whom this free2play market is usually targetted at?If you ever wanted to get into the Total War series then this is the game for you. If you are a casual gamer, give it a try as it costs you nothing anyway and you might enjoy it. If you are a Total War veteran, download it so you can downvote it You know you want too.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												So Total War Battles: KINGDOM is finaly here but what does this really mean. In the last year or so we have seen so many of these games, mine resources and anothers base. However never have we seen something like this on this scale, on PC. This mix of continuous world strategy and good old real time strategy battles seems to work quite well, however some of those battles can get a little confusing. Issues such as markability and platform prefrencing are big issuse CA is going to have to think about. One of my biggest issues with this game is the realism scenario, does CA really expect me to sit at my computer for 30-60 mins playing a game like this, its not the sort of game you do that with. I dont know about you but I dont really feel like sitting at my PC waiting 30 mins for something to be collected.Now dont get me wrong there are a lot of good features about this game and I thought battles would be one of them, I wouldnt say I was wrong they do have some fun parts to them, like seeing those little guys dance for victory or the dead corpses for lose. But one of the battles most basic mechanics have been totaly screwed up, 'charges' more like a nice walk in the park unless the person controling you is sliding his mouse across his desk back and forth like a maniac. Look I seriously think that this could work on an iPad or Tablet but seriously a PC?I think there are large chunks of this game that are really purpose built for iPad's and or Tablets. Overall I wouldnt say its a bad game, because its not but there is still a lot of improvements to be done before I will consider calling it a polished game. I know lots of you die hard fans will disagree with me but that the point of a review, me giving my opinion. And there it is!TheMooseConqueror (Aiden)

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												At first I thought it was a Total War game similar to Rome, Medieval, Empire and Shogun just to name a few in the series and the title of the game was responsible for that.  (Quite misleading) The game was very different and quite intriguing at first and was entertaining. I liked the little battles and the style that was used. I also very much liked the land management and kingdom building side to it. Overall and after quite a considerable time playing it I have found it to be full of a wide range of bugs and also the battle mechanics although I will say after some updates it has been improved. But not vastly. I found it really monotonous and repetitive which was quite dulling on the allure of the game and experience. From my personal view and opinion I would not recommend this game and for that reason and many others it gets a thumbs down. I will say that if problems are addressed and resolved with a lot of improvements then it has the potential to be a entertaining game. However there was enough reasons to put me off this game and therefore I won't be continuing it for the forseeable future.

												I have to say, this is something I thought I would never have to say about a Total War game. There is only one word I can say to truly describe this game; disappointment,  I have bought and played nearly every Total War game and loved each one. This is just ridicuous. Basically a "pay-to-win" app store game. For instance the one review, that I personally liked, described how to build a farm takes 8 seconds. Then to grow wheat it takes 8 hours. But all you have to do is use gold to finish instantly. Do not get this game. And to Creative Assembly; Do not ruin your legacy. If you do this, you will without a doubt lose everything great that you have worked on for so many years.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Honest review from a PC and Moblie gamer. I often have to work late and have long periods of time where I have to kill free time. Since acquring the Iphone 6 Plus, I've started playing games like Clash of Clans, COD heros and other forms of mobile games. Games that you can have quick action, such as couple of battles... then attend to resources and or upgrade buildings if need too. Saying that takes 10 minutes, then you are done, recieved a fix and move one. That's what a standard mobile game has become, that's what people do with mobile games. Play with it until something else comes up, and you come back to it in 15 minutes or 10 hours. Which total war kingdom follows that same pattern. The PC master race me, wants the climb to the tallest building AND SCREAM LIKE F*CKING INSANE PERSON at everybody! This is simply not a pc game, NOBODY WANTS TO WAIT for construction for 8 hours, PC games aren't a pick up and stop games like mobile games. This game has no right to be called a pc game and should have never launched for the pc. When I play total war on the pc, I want hard throbbing, none stop action like a chick in a gangbang. This pc version, fall quite short of that. Then again, I am looking forward to it on my Iphone 6 plus though.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												The Total War series is epic and then......poo.  I think that Sega ate something bad in order to produce this pile.  From the washed out colors to the lane based fighting,  the game really just rains all over the Total War series.  Instea of sweet flanking moves your stuck with lane based fighting.  Instead of huge expansive fighting maps, your stuck with tiny maps that just barely fill a 1080p screen.  Oh the graphics btw, their washed out.  Really really washed out. I mean they took the most awful pastels they could find and used those for this game.  Also, where the hell are the options?  OH, I see, the game was designed for mobile apps and then uploaded on steam. Hmm, where does it say that it's a mobile app, oh thats right it doesn't.  Also, wtf is up with these time based buildings. Want some wheat? Want some ore? Yup mine it, and uh oh, it's going to take 18 minutes for that to happen.  Ofcourse you can spend gold to speed that process up.  Hmm sounds like some other cash grab games.  Oh those resources you just sped up, you gotta manually pick them up.  What a complete pile of poo. Sega should have given us a good version of Total War.  Hell I love the series and would have paid premium  prices for it. Instead we are left with........bleh....

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												FirFirst off it is not a bad game it just needs to change somethings. It started off fun for the first few hours as I was learning how to play and changing the landscape to maximize the best outcome for my resources. They did a really good job on that and there are some pretty cool late/end game builds for maximizing resource outcome (if only you’ll make it that far). The line battling has nothing that isn’t already in other games like this so if that’s all you’re here for then move along. Now I’ll talk about some of the things that need to change are the use of gold (real money) to progress your army. When you build your second barracks, archery range, stable, knight manor, etc you will be able to choose a new unit and this is where the game becomes frustrating. The game offers you the ability to buy the unit with gold which isn’t a problem all f2p games do stuff like this the problem is the need for those troops in order to progress in the campaign and regular missions. You are also able to acquire them from crafting them at level 21 but the resources to craft them takes days to get and all you will get is one unit for what is a weeks plus of work IF you are constantly checking up and gathering you resources. Also the PvP battles are unbalanced because of the gold (p2p) system. At the start of each battle you are offered the choice to spend a little gold to buff yourself in one way or another. You are also able to craft one of those one time buffs but if you do you are going in a negative direction of getting new troops that you will need. But aside from that I found I was being matched with players who clearly had paid for their troops because of the level they were at. I understand there will be people who do that but the problem is the fights had not been balanced and I was somehow expected to defeat an opponent who had better versions of my entire army. At the end of the day it has fun city builder/land transformation tools but the battles and PvP need to be reworked.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												This is a definite NO. I have been playing TW since the beginning. I downloaded and tested this game, and also bought a basic pack of gold to see, how far can I get with that. It is ridiculous. It is not only, that its a pay2win game, but it is almost impossible to do any advance (unless you spend hours every day for several months). In addition it is a terribly balanced game even with some gold. - The more effective units (knights, trebuchets etc.) can be only "crafted" with horrendous amount of resources or large pack of gold. - For example: a kinght with batlle axe costs 410 gold. At the merchant guild you can get 500 gold for 5 EUROS (REAL MONEY). So, practically even with playing the PAY version, the exchanges are RIDICULOUS. One knight with battle axe for 5 euros in a virtual game? COME ON!!!  The TW guys really went insane.- Unfortunately lots of people tries and pays until they realize that to complete the game would require so much time and money that no game would deserve that, especially not this one.- This is just the business part. I could write more about that the battles are jokes compared to previous TWs, nothing close to that. It is a pitty, because the game as a tap-and-play tablet game would be ok in terms of graphics and idea. This game is nothing more than a resource draining venture of the evil cigarette smoking Grey Gentlemen from MOMO, COMPLETE waste of time and money.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I stupidly decided to play for 3 hours yesterday.  Went to bed, woke up, and realized how stupid I was.All I can really focus on are the negatives...1. Pay to win- The better units require gold (which is purchased, with a very small amount coming from random events and such).  For example, a barracks allows you to recruit swordsmen, spearmen, macemen, and axemen.  The macement and axemen require gold.- the game is about gathering resources based on timers, but the timers can be instantly finished by spending gold.  Want tons of resources?  You can pay to get them!2. Complete utter timesink- Assuming you're masochistic enough to decide to play, all the timers are ♥♥♥♥ed up:Some are 4hours, some are 6, some are 8.  So if you want to maximize your income, you better log in all the time- There are battle missions which you can constantly do for more resources.But heavily damaged units require time to heal (or, of course, spend more gold!  PAY TO WIN!).  These timers take around 5-30 minutes.  So again, the more you play, the more resources you get...  better check into the game all the time, or else you won't get those resources!

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												This game is awesome . People dont recommend this because they dont understand how the game works and they think its pay to win . Its not , everything (exept some cosmetic stuff) is free . You just need time to get it . For example if you want longsword knights , you can buy them for 400 gold (real money) or craft it what takes some time . Battle system is pretty interesting though not that good but it has good concept . The economic and building system is really unique. You need to find places for your farms , sheeps , cattle , woodcutters and quarry . Once you understand how it works , , its easy and interesting .  For example , farms in order to plant and harvest need to have water/river near by . BUT if you do one mistake , river can go crazy and flood that farm and everything that will stand in its way . At that point you can try fixing it with lots of dams or just restart .Or you can accidentally cut down whole forest and you will be without wood.  People just need to understand how it works . Production is pretty much just taking when its ready , you can have tavern and blacksmiths who will produce money but you need workers to that building so you need houses to have workers. Productions is slow , but you can get some resources by completing missions . OVERVIEW : Game is very good , good concept , soundtrack is good , battle system is interesting and challenging , production and building is also challenging and sometimes very risky . I totally reccomend this game to everyone , its not like any other Total War game , but it is unique . Try it , see yourself .

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												In short:I like the game, it has lots of potential .. but it's an ill conceived cash cow that will milk you dry.Things that ruin this game:* Increadibly long periods of time to do even the most menial tasks. This is a game where you click and then walk away for a day, a week .. half a month (Yes, chop down and tree and it will take half a month real time to grow back).* No auto activity feature .. forcing you to micro manage even the most basic resource collection (see previous point).* Huge reliance on gold to speed things up (purchased with real coin) to make this game even playable (see previous point).* Increadible difficulting in raising gold through the actual game (see previous point). So unless you fork out huge amounts of real cash, be prepared to wait until retirement before anything exciting happens.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												I give up on sega games with the total war series everything.  The shoguns never work, the rome is always the one they pay the most attentions to and if something ever goes wrong SEGA will never refund anything, regardless of a right or wrong scenario.  Used to be a dedicated Total war player since day 1 beta; no more.  This was a last attempt and ended in failure.  Game fails probably because they were making this while spending 99.99% of their time tweeking Total War ROME III...! Don't be fooled by the screenshots, you have very limited control and are limited so a small box frame to fit around your very few preset formatiomations (ON RAILS & BOXED IN) and can only attack to front+back or archers diagonal+front. It's trying to be SEGA's version of stronghold with the worst combination possible of the total war series. and fails horribly. Everything is expected and nothing shines bright here in any real unique way at all. Comment what you like and rate what you like; regardless I won't see any of the comments or even attempt to read them or come back to this crap...Not sure why it states 0.8 hours, I played 1.5-2 hours...Game rating = 2.5/10...don't waste the seconds to download...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Combat is boring, involves QTEs, and makes completely no sense (You'd think that if you kill everyone in a certain lane, you could now flank the enemy with your freed-up troops, but no, you have to wait or taunt, hoping that somebody is stupid enough to saunter into that specific column to fight your idling soldiers.)Why does it take seven centuries or paying in-game currency to harvest/mine anything in this game. During the tutorial, I found out that harvesting wheat would take either 20 min or 1 gold. So I decided to wait a bit and save up what I could in terms of currency. I come back 10 minutes later and find out that the game has crapped out on itself and needs me to sign back in so it can re-update. Not that bad in and of itself, but it completely canceled my harvesting process, sending the process back to square one, all twenty minutes of it. Let me repeat, this game traps you into paying Gold on what should just be a mouseclick and a bit of a waiting game, because the game cannot support itself long enough to farm the normal, non-idiotic way.I also learned that if you press a mouse right, your useless looking pitchfork wielders can utterly obliterate the front rank of trained cavalrymen mid-charge. Apparently SEGA didn't remember that this doesn't work ANYWHERE ELSE in the Total War series. Seriously, let's line some peasants up against cavalry and rush them head on in Rome I, Rome II, Shogun II, anything. See if that works.10/10, would uninstall again.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I have to sadly say that as many others have pointed out this is a pay to win Facebook game with a total war facelift. The resources required to expand the map are far too high, by the time any player who doesn’t drop money gets access to the higher quality units not to mention higher tier quality a player who drops money is so far ahead there is no way to keep up and be competitive on the PvP section of this game.The art is great, the combat system is fun and challenging [which is good] the map can be changed to a slight degree lowering and raising the land which is nifty. However the drawback of in some cases not being able to tell how many enemies you may be facing because they are off the battle field waiting to enter, the obviously pay to win model, and the lack of content long term, I would have to say pass on this game even if it’s free.Any total war fan will be left wanting more content and more quality, any Facebook fan will be put off by the combat and both parties will not like the pay to win model. Creative assembly get out of the facebook game and back into making AAA full release games.

number of helpful: 13 of 27 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												OK, this game is not the typical Total War game, and yes, its absolutely design with mobile devices in mind. But if you compare it with other games in the genre it is one of the best. Maybe Steam is not the best place for this game but it is a really enjoyable game, people say that things take a lot of time to get done, that is the point of this games and I am really sure is not that long if you compare to other games in the genre (like 10 to 20 mins to gather resources and most building take like 7 seconds to build, others take like 2 to 24 hours). Well the game has microtransactions, but nothing new, you can adquire everything in the game with actual in game resources without spending a single cent of real money, except some cosmetics, but you need to be patient and manage your resources. Yes, some units are clearly pay2win but not to make it only a P2W experience, and you can still "craft" them with in game resources.The game overall is pretty good, but you need to judge it by what it actually is, a mobile resource gathering game. I seriously think that it is going to be a great succes when it hits android and iOS devices. So for me solid 7-8 out of 10. Fun combats, castle and town "building" on hexes, and interesting water mechanics plus really fun weather-season system.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Great game, this.  It's in the same genre as games like Travian, Clash of Clans, and Tribal Wars with the major difference being that the kingdom building aspect is 100% safe from attack and being conquered by others.Combat reminds me of the boardgame Oishi if any are familiar.  it is an eastern tactical combat style boardgarme.  games are quick and easy though sometimes a huge fight will boil down to a few hearty troops which is always dramatic.  the combat feels 'jousty' where you have a little clash and then are on your way.Graphics are great.  The feel of the most recent rome total war is brought forward and refined in this newest total war game.  in the most recent rome total war the iconography felt like cheap clipart, but in total war battles, the iconography has been given the love it needs to become a beautiful part of the rest of the game which is already beautiful.One of the things that I like most about this game is that I feel like it's the BEST of it's genre because your kingdom will NEVER be destroyed or taken over by another player.  It is your kingdom.  you get 1 life, in that when you start the game you get your character name which is undeletable and tied to your total war account, so if you like your name, no restarts!  I digress though, since what you have is safe and yours, then you can develop your kingdom at your own pace.   I believe the missions scale to how much xp you've got in your army roster but I could be wrong.  Early missions are easy cakewalks and the easy ones can be done without the aid of the relics kept in churches so if you want to do a low religion level game (like for a long time in the beginning of the game, I destroyed almost everything and rebuilt, so my kingdom only had the holy grail providing a special 'order' power for my army for a good long time and I got by just fine).A last note about the spirit of this game, which I feel is important to talk about.  in other games in this genre, you're left feeling stressed like you could get attacked and lose your stuff at any moment, and the timers were like chains, binding you whether you liked it or not to the game.  In Total War Battles: Kingdom, since your kingdom is safe, the feel is totally different.  You can pick it up whenever you want, put it down whenever you want, take a break for a week who cares?  you can still come back to it and field your army and have fun battles at just your level and enjoy a stress free super beautiful castle builder on the side.Enjoy!It's free :)

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												THIS FREE TO PLAY GAME CAN BE AN EXPENSIVE RIP OFF!!!The two most serious problems I ran into are like boom - a gambling addiction I didn't know I had, and bugs like this one below that COST A PLAY REAL MONEY - boo-hiss.I had to send this into Tech Support, hope I don't have to pay $$$ to get a quick resolution and action like in the game. USE RENOWN TO ACCESS WEDGEFORD NOT WORKING!As I understand the criteria, to rule Wedgeford a player can either buy the territory which is IMPOSSIBLE unless one pays TOO MUCH real money for it OR proves right to rule by becoming a renowned duelist.Lady Evelyn defines renowned duelist as “OBTAIN DUELING RANK 18 OR BETTER.”After achieving a dueling rank of 20 for several days, I am still now able to USE RENOWN to obtain Wedgeford.Hopefully, this is a game bug that needs attention, or this game is really the PAY TO PLAY RIP OFF noted by far too many reviewers.I’m at the point where I must compare this game to getting addicted to on line gambling – slot machines.Is the game different from most other Total War games? Most definitely.However, the biggest difference is the FREE TO PLAY label is most misleading, thus far I’ve spent $55.00 bucks to play this so called free game. I have about $9.00 left in my game account, so when I (admittedly) foolishly get that ripped off, I’m uninstalling this game from STEAM.In fact the negative review I found to be my favorite is: About as "pay to win' as you can get. Shame on CA for stooping to a level I associate with doing the video gamer equivalent of running a casino direct targeting gambling addicts. A certain type of player will blow god awful amounts of money on this. The more rational gamers will be annoyed that those who spent a ton of money have such an advantage.There are definitely a few positives to this game, but the negatives far outweigh the misleading FREE TO PLAY BETA.Sincce this is a Beta, and SEGA desires feedback from those (PAYING TO) play this FREE GAME, I strongly suggest that instead of getting more folks addicted to gambling (like me), that SEGA put this much time, effort, and talent into turning this into a real traditional Total War platform and simply charge an up front price for the game. Here are a few other comments I found most useful.     - The tutorial itself teaches you how to spend money – REAL MONEY from your Steam Account.     - It's a "pay to win" game as you can get everything by simply paying.     - All customization and speedups, do, as expected, cost a currency that you must buy with real money.     - This game is terrible in how they are trying to market and profit from it. It is disgraceful to the Total War franchise

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												A totally different take on the Total War franchise. This is a much limited game suitable to be played on a mobile device. Do not expect to play a full Total War classic game, those games need beefier computers. So taking this game for what it is, a mobile game, it is surprisingly good, beatiful graphics and quite some Kingdom management options plus the combat aspect where the composition of your army, its positioning, upgrades and orders are all important. It is meant to be played esporadically, for 10 minutes at a time, loging a few times a day to manage your Kingdom. It is also a free game with no ads and a non intrusive gold for money shop. Money gives you gold which allows you to speed up everything (buying units instead of slowly gathering resources to slowly craft them; instant construction of buildings, instant gathering of resources or instant healing your troops after the battle instead of waiting the rrequired time). So the impatient will spend money to buy gold to progress faster... and that is good, because the rest of us get to play for free at our own pace.Every unit or improvement that can be bought with gold can be crafted in game, provided you manage your kingdom properly and take your time. Heck, I have got more gold in game than I need too.So enjoy the game for what it is, a beautiful, well done, FREE mobile game.---------------------------------------Note: Some personal advice, the game does not detail every aspect of how everything works. the way I see it, I find it more fun to play the game WITHOUT looking in internet for detailed notes about how the buildings work or how the seasons affect your economy. Play the game and discover it yourself without any external hints. It is supposed to be a challenge where setbacks leads to learning. Note that you CANNOT restart the game, but nothing you'll do would break it. You can always recover from everything that the game throws at you, so if a season drought or an invasion wreak havoc with your budding Kingdom, take it as a challenge and raise again without ♥♥♥♥♥ing at how unfair the game is.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Wonderfull kingdom building and planning  with military strategy elements game.I have been looking for anything that would come close to a browser game I once played. The game was called Knightsdivine (only some pictures remained if you google), and was for reasons unknown taken down. The mentioned game was free at first, my guess to why the game went down, cause of bad payment options - as I was to young to get a credit card, other payment options were pretty much inaccessible for me back then (no prepaid option or mobile).I have been trying different tiles whatever I could find and nothing came remotely close. Well, this is not same obvious, while it has at same point gave me some satisfaction it makes me even more lust for this game to develop further.What does it miss a multi-player regional camps, where lords fight for the ultimate title "king of kings". Instead of using today model of destroying a player it took just a proportion of lord's land and the rest claimed as vassal lord and thereby open up a political hierarchy within the kingdom. Truly revolutionary. I have not seen this here yet, but I hope that once you claimed sectors something like that will be possible or implemented later.Games thrive to use renown, as progress upon unlocking better and new buildings (where in Knightsdiveine you had to spend learning points). This game is slow paced, but the renown and battle options can keep you occupied during  your waiting times. And it seems, the more regions you have, the more you'll have to do.I am excited about how this will develop on. Definitely has nice potential, and is a nice game already. It is real slow, but it pauses when you don't play (except seasons, the continue to move onward, that is great however).

												so stupid how people put "not recommended" simply becouse its FTP. its fricken free and your complaining that they try to make money like EVERY game? oh spend 40$ per game and its a fun "real" game. but have it trying to make 1-5$ off you and all of a sudden its a crime. i hate you FTP Haters, and i know you are going to say "not helpful" becouse alot of you are arrogant Nerd-Trolls. to sum it up, the FTP haters is the "Gaming version of Racism".Edit: i didnt really mention much about the actual gameplay, so i will now for people who dont blindly hate a FTP label. Pros:Good Graphics. considering this is FTP which usually dont go over-the-top for many things the graphics are good.Battles: i dont own Total War. so i cant say about wether this is good or not compared to the rest of the series. however compared to all other FTP strategy games this combat system tops it off. not only can you actually see the battles occuring but you can make tactical descisions. like it should be.Terraforming: this is a unique feature which i find nice. itd be even cooler if there was a map editor.Speed: the speed of the game moves along pretty fast. you can build building for only a couple seconds. however the things taking hours to make can give headaches.Cons:unit Depth: compared to alot of other games there isnt alot of variety of units. basically, Pikes Archers Calvery and Swords, and Siege weapondry.multiplayer: as far as i can tell its more Singleplayer, with some MP added in. nothing like some games with entire empires controlled by a single player, or "Houses" with many factions with 10 people minimum.Sounds: this isnt a con, i just had no where to put it. i alway have mute on so i can tell you wether the sounds used are good or not.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Well it’s been a while since this came out and now I will write what I have to say on it. Like its real time predecessor total war battles shogun the game is different in nature to other total war titles. However for this version the gameplay was split. In battles shogun you had to build buildings and train troops during the battles which behaved in a similar format. Your troops would mindlessly march across the hex based map and the only thing you could do to them was switch lanes. At this point not counting the pay to accelerate system in place there are a lot of gameplay problems with the game. unlike total war battles shogun the management and battles are split up. In this version  you have a hex based grid where you build villages that take forever to gather resources and also require player interaction to do so. The battles are summed up with your troops mindlessly go towards the enemy with a few player interactions in charging and ability’s to break up the boring aspect of battles. Now the part that really pisses me off and arguably breaks the game is the difficulty system. The game scales difficulty based on how powerful your army is and the game was designed with the logic “hey let’s make the AI more powerful than you all the time to make the game challenging.” The problem with that logic is that you get to a point where the AI is so powerful it takes any fun that’s left out of the game. Worse is that when the AI is weaker than you there is no reward for winning. The ridiculous difficulty is seen with the raiders that attack your villages every so often. Now for some reason raiders are not scaled with your army for difficulty. Instead they are scaled with the number of regions under your control. So I have 4 regions and am facing armies that have troops that are so powerful that I can only get through one line of troops with all 3 lines of my troops filled.(there are 3 lines in total for both sides and apparently the AI can get reinforcements) Raiders steal your resources and destroy your buildings so you have to get rid of them. If you can’t defeat them in battle you have to pay them silver (one of the resources in the game) the problem there is that the raiders demand ludicrous amounts of silver in the last case they demanded over 4000 silver which drained days (and I mean real world days) worth of resource gathering. That’s not mentioning the yearly droughts that dry up the rivers over halfway up the map, and the pay to accelerate system that is in place. It’s worth noting that this is a beta and I do hope that many of these problems get fixed but until they do I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

												Since I started playing this with the expectations most of the reviews had given me I find this game quite enjoyable. One can't expect the ordinary Total War game, because it isn't. It is an online rts game and that's why I don't find it strange or annoying with long building times.I would say this game is a mix between Total War, Civilization and Stronghold Kingdoms. Sure there are some bugs but it's still in beta and it's running better than I though it would on my laptop. So far I haven't felt that it's a pay-2-win game and that is also positive, since there are games like this out there that you can't progress in if you aren't paying a ton of money.All in all I think it's a good game, and since it's free you should at least try it out for yourself and make your own opinion!

content:

												There were days when I thought of Creative Assembly as developers who not only value, but also love their client-base, us Total War gamers. When they released awesome games and supported them throughout and then even improved them further through add-on such as Medieval 2 Total War Kingdoms and Napoleon TW. Those were good days when I bought the games without a second thought being certain that it will be a quality product made with love and respect. Sentimental so far hey? But then there was the biggest ever beta test of Rome 2, it lasted a year. Then there were DLC for playable factions and blood and gore, and now this... this is the final nail in the coffin where I buried my respect to CA and SEGA (I don't know who to blame) as this is the most greedy TW project that does not even deserve the TW badge.... 8 hours to spawn a peasant 4 hours to harvest etc... It is as if they took Godus and though "hmmm, how can we make this even worse and still earn money"....Shame on you CA and/or SEGAFor more reviews join - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview/

												This game seems pretty fun. Altough it should not carry the Total War title + logo since there is almost no aspect from a Total War game in. Kingdom Wars - Dawn of Fantasy had more in common that this.There are some things that bothering me. #1. First of all the Drought. The tides in the game seems to be really annoying and weird. I am dealing with a severe drought problem, half my farms are dried out and the lakes are empty. this is going on for 4 days in a row now and only got worser.#2. The combat is a bit odd. I get it that it is a freemium game but paying for a 1 time fight upgrade (like flaming arrows or an extra mercenary unit) is really stupid and unneccesary. I know you can craft bracelets to use them too but that take ages so no one would waste their time on that.#3. Construction speed is odd. You don't build a whole city in one minute and demolish it in 10 minutes.#4. As last I want to compliment the Mods on the Forum and support. They are really active and helpfull.

												The game has potential, but in current form it is useless and unplayable. You start of building your first castletown, conquer you neighbor for more land, expand your resource income, fight missions for coin and resources. Then the fun ends. After playing one day. Waiting time is ridiculous, Cost of gold to speed everything up. Limitations in recruting troops. I manage to upgrade my first castle to level 2 and hoped to unlock some new features. I did and they to cost an ridiculous amout of resourses. Game is way to slow. And the way you can speed things upp with money just is not worth it.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Firstly this is not the traditional Total War game so do not go in expecting that; it never claimed to be the full blown experience that you get with the latest masterpiece. It does however have something else to offer and that is a mobile or quick game when a long campaign on the latest Total War is just not possible. The essence of Total War is there but made more accessible in a number of ways. Being cross platform is just a start but I do believe the actual mechanics of the game are easier to understand for those who do not have the time to invest in or concentration span for the main series. This game is a pick up and play kingdom building experience with combat, level progression and upgrades.Would I recommend the game; well yeah it is Free to Play, playable, nice enough graphics which any hardware could probably handle, audio is good but not sure about the speech at the beginning. Don't get me wrong there are still a few issues that need to be addressed but nothing major anymore.Great game for having Total War on the go which is good for when you don't have too much time to play or just want to give yourself a break from more demanding games of the franchise.

												A nice stripped down version of Total War. I'm enjoying this a lot and I'm looking forward to the campaign. 												I found this actually really motivating as a mid-core strategy game, certainly not as deep and intricate as the bigger Total War titles, but tailored for shorter (10 - 30 minutes) sessions of town management, resource collecting and nicely animated battles. content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Its an OK to average kingdom building game but its very limiting and aggravating doing battles because the button cooldowns are so insanely slow, and the constantly having to readjust the ground levels to dig some things and then only be able to place certain buildings at certain heights of ground and having your kingdom flooded when it doesnt work out right.  Would be a great game if you could manipulate your troops in real time and not have some standing doing nothing and cant use them yet because of formations, and for the love of God reduce the cooldown on how fast you can select targets for the archers, the 5sec cooldowns makes me not even want to use them at all, and the constant releveling of the ground is overkill, a waste of resources, and stupid.  So in short its a great game with great potential for fun but is killed and made annoying to play by too many rules and limitations taking it from thumbs up to down and 5 stars to 1 star

												I've seen some pretty interesting games, but this one is definitely a first. I was fine with the 20 minute collection times, but the 4 hour wheat field growing times seemed to put me on the edge. Furthermore, I was shocked when I realized that it takes 20 days for the trees to regrow. 20 days! real time! This game is definitely not recommended to anyone by me, and if you want a decent game that's fun to play, I would never suggest this game. The wait times are insane, for any gamers out there. Stay away from this game folks, there's plenty real ones our there that won't take 20 years to do anything :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												I've not played any of the Total War franchise before. However I can do compare this as a minor version of the Total War series in a simplifed version, mainly for the mobile gaming. You can compare this as a better version of the Stronghold Kingdoms. Well for one thing, Total War lives up to the name of complex management of battlefields. But don't expect too much management here, as it's still meant to be mobile gaming. You get to assign your flanking and foward platoons, cast a few Order skills. The city planning management is easy, but needs in depth planning on how your placement of structures in order to fully benefit its ultilisation. It's still based on the traditional hexagonal warfield gameplay. So strategising your placement is important here, as they will influences other subsiding hexagons as well. You won't be placed together with other human players, just other NPC controlled regions. So it may seems like "YOBA" gaming. But human players are still out there, during Duels.Ignore about the reviews, saying it's a P2W game. All mobile games needs cash credits to survive. That's their marketing. However I'm very sure this game doesn't really needs those Gold in order to play. In fact the usage of Gold, is only to unlock those cosmetics stuffs for your flags or appearance of your king/queen. Yet in fact, all these cosmestics will still be unlocked as you level up. So Gold doesn't really matter here. No point spending your gold on rushing the buildings as well, since they get built very fast. Compared to Stronghold Kingdoms; where you can get to days just to build finish a building. And if you login daily, Gold will also be awarded to you. Quests also awards you with Gold.Within two hours you can easily unlocked till Level 14. That's qutie substantial for a developed castle. Well maybe not on the resources side. For resource wised, the game has been spilt into four resources, Silvers, Food, Stone, Wood. Silvers and Wood are plenty of them in the game, and should generally earn you quite fast. Whereas for Food really depends on the seasons you are in. There will be times where the Winter has come and you have no plantation for the farm to grow on, so you have have to survive with the icy cold fishes hidden below the ice, or killing some cows and sheeps. The hard part will be getting the Stone, since getting a Stones are pretty hard; comparable that it just generates 10 Stones per 20 minutes. Therefore there are Missions for you to fight for, to earn some pretty good stash of Stones.Generally this game would not be leaving you there hanging, waiting for buildings to get done or waiting for resources to be collected. The cooldown of the soldiers, after going through a battle is very fast. By the time you finish a battle, you are ready to collect your resources. So it's just a cycle. There are unlimited Missions, Battle Quests for you. Campaign is the next upcoming update. Each Missions has it's own difficulty as well, resulting in different payout.For networking wise, Total War has done a good job in having the seamless synchronisation of the account. You get to play the game at home on your Steam, and on the go as you use your mobile to play the game. It maybe hard for those first time, as there seems to be no way to sign up for a Total War account. But fraid not, after you have completed your tutorial. You will actually be asked to create a Total War account. At first I was also clueless on how to create them, as I didn't want to have two accounts separately. For Duels (Humans), the networking really depends on the time of day. So far the matchmaking are mostly two levels higher/lower than your current duel level.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Took part in the beta for this game. This game was not fun, in any capacity, which is extremely disappointing as I am a big fan of Creative Assembly's other titles and have been since CA's inception. I would definitely not recommend this game, as it is primarily designed to function on a touch screen device. If you're planning on playing this on a touch screen device as a time killer on the train, plane or long bus journey, it's not TERRIBLE for this function, however it's not breaking records by any stretch of the imagination. It's main saving grace is that it's free, at least that was something they got right!The interface is clunky and unintuitive, the combat is pretty dull. I would not recommend you play this game.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												Actually not a bad game. Long wait timers so easy and relaxing game to check on once or twice a day. It's not pay to win, everyone is open to the same stuff. It's a mmorts with a twist separating it from thousands of Clash of Clans rip-offs. You can customize the terrain around you to maximize profits on your resources, water management is key as it can flood your land if you're not careful. Battles are fun and you best be ready to focus and time your unit's abilities just right. I personally can't wait for Campaign Mode which allows conquering of other players. It has surprising detail within its basic graphics, I would encourage anyone to at least try it, and not let the negative Steam review turn you away, anything with microtransactions(no matter how small or justified) tends to send the community into a flaming rage.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												After playing this for some time, and ignoring all other reviews so that I can play the game thoroughly enough to form my own opinion, I can say that the game is not just pay2win / progress.. it's also grow-old2win / progress.PvP review:-Do you want a chance to get to the top without putting in any money at all? you won't get it here.. why you ask? well for pvp you can call in "extras" like fire arrows or better melee power to even calling in another unit to help you out.. the catch is that it costs gold OR using up a bracelet which can be crafted... the downside is that the crafting takes 80 hours to produce and you're not guaranteed to get any bracelets at all.Take for example an average outcome with "master crafting" (which is more expensive than normal crafting) you may get 5 bracelets in 80 hours, your top pvp opponent does not need this as he just pays 3 gold for his advantage each and every time.. that puts you in one of three camps.1) pay2win the same as your opponent for an equal chance of winning (if you don't take stats into account).2) use one of the bracelets it's taken you almost 4 days to make and get a win or two granting you a few places higher in the ranks.or3) save up a huge amount of bracelets so that you can get the advantage in pvp the same as the pay2win folk do 100% of the time.This leaves you be one of 2 players, either Pay2win or grow-old2win (by which time no one will be playing anymore / game will be shut down).You may enjoy this if you just want to attack AI and you only have about 5 - 10 minutes every 5 hours to play (as this game was very much aimed at the mobile market) or pay for everything, otherwise it's just frustrating, unfair and a complete grind.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												This is not a Total War game, it is just a pay2win mobile game. By hearing the title Total War I expect three things, a campaign map, epic scale battles and extended use of strategy. Unfortunately,I saw none of those main features in this game. Instead, it is mainly a city building game. There are the main resources that you use for costructing buildings and recruiting units. However, some processes take hours to be finished and you have to use gold which can be collected by two ways, or by completing missions and objectives, (which are just to build a number of specific buildings ,fight battles or to conquer new parts of the map, ) or by spending real money. The only thing that I personally liked was the teraforming feature because lakes and rivers can affect both positively and negatively the production of some resources. The battles are just a huge dissapointment because they are not huge and they have no strategy at all. Furthermore, you have to deploy your units on three lines , with maximum three units per line, they march towards the enemy and you have to just order charge at the right moment to have some bonus and there are some special abilities that give advantage to your units for a short time. Except from that, your units cannot move on a horizontal axis to help their fellow soldiers, they can attack only on the units that are in front of them. And the worst part is that the battles last for a few seconds.The visuals are great for a mobile strategy game. The map and the battles are 3d and generally the game does not look ugly. Instead, it looks quite beautiful. The audio is decent except from one part, the voice acting of the soldiers is the same from Rome II and no matter the fact that the British used to be christians back then you may hear them say "praise the gods". That shows how much some people from CA probably cared for their game by throwing in it files without checking them.After years of playing Total War games and trusting CA for making one of the best strategy game series, I got dissapointed by the fact that they use the Total War title for games that have nothing to do with the specific series. This game claims that it is a TW game while it is not. Moreover, it has no strategy, nor epic scale battles, nor a campaign map (I personally don't consider the map of the game as equal to the ones of other TW games) or any other feature that could make this game a part of the famous strategy game series. To be honest, It is addicting and fun,I will download it immediately when it will be released on android devices. On the other hand, I would not play this game on my pc, I would prefer to play some REAL TW games. I like it as a mobile game, Irecommend you to download it on your mobile devices, but it is not meant to be played on pc, it just screams out that it is designed solely for mobile devices. Please CA, if you want to make some good mobile TW games, you could just release the first games of the series (Shogun ,Medieval) with some grafical improvements that mobile devices can handle and some gameplay features of the newer TW games implemented.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												The game has a very interesting and nice features. There are a lot of negative review about this game regarding a slow pace of the game but the pace is actually very much O.K. because the game will progress when You log off, so You can decide how much time You spend micro managing to do things faster or just ask a batch job complete while You are busy with other things in Your real life :)Also as I have been playing the game it is really free and while You can buy things that will boost Your game it is not required by any means because with patience You seem to be able to achieve everything by Yourself. So this is really a free and interesting game to play.And there are some very interesting features that stand this game out in a crowd.The most interesting is that You can alter a landscape very much and the game will react in very interesting ways, depending on Your changes.The rivers will change their direction. You will see animals spawn in Your forests if You let them grow, providing You with a hunting opportunities. Or traders will settle along Your roads and a lot of other interesting events will happen.The seasons will change. Rivers will freeze. You will build housing for Your people that will spawn workforce for Your smithies and other type of "industries". You will build barracks to house various types of troops.You will arrange and maintain a small army from different kinds of troops that will gain experience and level up.A recent "project" of mine was to design a larger river around my borders that would have a deep waters for fishing. This took a lot of patience and trial and error to learn how to do it the best way.The features that I have not yet tried out is crafting and equipping Your troops with different kind of equipment.The only drawback is that a battle minigame is kind of silly a bit. Your troops will advance like blocks in tetris game and You will have to manage where they "land" and time charges properly, cast boosts for the troops and try to win. So in the sense of military simulation this game is far from being something You might expect from total war game. But as a city builder game this is really, really nice game to play.In my opinion this is a much better game than all the latest big budget SEGA games because here You have actually an interesting strategy game with all good for free - all You need is patience and no need to pay for additional dlc to get an actual content.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												This is not a Total War game, it is just a pay2win mobile game. By hearing the title Total War I expect three things, a campaign map, epic scale battles and extended use of strategy. Unfortunately,I saw none of those main features in this game. Instead, it is mainly a city building game. There are the main resources that you use for costructing buildings and recruiting units. However, some processes take hours to be finished and you have to use gold which can be collected by two ways, or by completing missions and objectives, (which are just to build a number of specific buildings ,fight battles or to conquer new parts of the map, ) or by spending real money. The only thing that I personally liked was the teraforming feature because lakes and rivers can affect both positively and negatively the production of some resources. The battles are just a huge dissapointment because they are not huge and they have no strategy at all. Furthermore, you have to deploy your units on three lines , with maximum three units per line, they march towards the enemy and you have to just order charge at the right moment to have some bonus and there are some special abilities that give advantage to your units for a short time. Except from that, your units cannot move on a horizontal axis to help their fellow soldiers, they can attack only on the units that are in front of them. And the worst part is that the battles last for a few seconds.The visuals are great for a mobile strategy game. The map and the battles are 3d and generally the game does not look ugly. Instead, it looks quite beautiful. The audio is decent except from one part, the voice acting of the soldiers is the same from Rome II and no matter the fact that the British used to be christians back then you may hear them say "praise the gods". That shows how much some people from CA probably cared for their game by throwing in it files without checking them.After years of playing Total War games and trusting CA for making one of the best strategy game series, I got dissapointed by the fact that they use the Total War title for games that have nothing to do with the specific series. This game claims that it is a TW game while it is not. Moreover, it has no strategy, nor epic scale battles, nor a campaign map (I personally don't consider the map of the game as equal to the ones of other TW games) or any other feature that could make this game a part of the famous strategy game series. To be honest, It is addicting and fun,I will download it immediately when it will be released on android devices. On the other hand, I would not play this game on my pc, I would prefer to play some REAL TW games. I like it as a mobile game, Irecommend you to download it on your mobile devices, but it is not meant to be played on pc, it just screams out that it is designed solely for mobile devices. Please CA, if you want to make some good mobile TW games, you could just release the first games of the series (Shogun ,Medieval) with some grafical improvements that mobile devices can handle and some gameplay features of the newer TW games implemented.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Now, despite my rating of this game I actually really have enjoyed my time in it. And for what it is its not a bad playthrough. But just some disturbing trends in it almost completely turn me off of it. Needing to pay gold (the games cash to coin currency) in order to unlock better units, such as spearmen. Though there is alternative options, such as forging them, not only do they not work 100% of the time, but you also dont even unlock it till later in the game. I was also rather bothered by the resources system, resources collected drop tiles which you need to click on in order to collect said resource. Needing to click on the tiles in order to collect them means you need to play the game in order to advance at all, and for the game being what it is I think its a dumb feature that would be immensely improved on simply by removing it. Also stone is very difficult to collect in large quantities, while you will never have any problems with wood or food, spending stone will usually leave you scraping the bottom of the barrel at early levels. And the combat system, while not being bad, isn't nearly good enough to hold my attention for long enough to keep my constantly playing in order to collect resources so I can advance.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Not terrible but certainly not good. Falls down on the use of the total war name most of all in my opinion (explained below). It's a tablet game and nothing more, if this were a play store or Itunes review the score would be very different. It's not a PC game, f2p or not, end of discussion. But if Sega insist on offering it as a PC game I shall review it as one. 5/10I did have to think quite a lot about whether I could recommend this game and while it’s not a bad game per se it certainly isn’t a good game at the moment ( I appreciate it’s still in beta and a lot could change) . In fact to be fair to this game as a free-2-play it’s not too bad and miles ahead of Stronghold: kingdoms in both art style and mechanics. On the positive side I thought that the building and settlement creation were quite well done though they are a little basic. Kudos to the team for pretty excellent terrain height, excavation and water mechanic programing, it really helps to create this felling that the world itself can be shaped to suit your needs. The time required for building and resource gathering was pretty good, not obscenely long as in most free-2-plays (read as free-2-wait). On top of this you can even find and mine premium currency allowing any player no matter how stingy to gain some of the advantages. In fact if the game was purely the build section then I would actually recommend it.There are however massive issues with the battle system. And by massive issues I mean JESUS CHRIST WHY DID YOU THINK THIS WAS A GOOD IDEA? Yeah that level of bad. I do have to admit that most of my issues with the combat are simply that it is difficult to accept calling this a total war game. I am a die-hard fan of the series (hell I even like empire) and like many total war fans I love the complexity of tactics one can to utilize to win. The battles of Battles: Kingdom seem to have stripped all this away to be replaced with clicking to charge at the right time….what?..... WHAT?.... HOW HAVE YOU TURNED YOUR COMBAT INTO QUICK TIME EVENTS? QTEs in total war now, along with day one dlc you’d be forgiven for thinking EA had bought CA. That said Sega aren’t much better look what they did to sonic. I have't played Shogun 2 Battles but i see that the combat in that is turn based, why didn't they keep that? sure its not total war but at least it's still tactical not ♥♥♥♥ING QTEs!!! But my issues with the battles don’t stop there. I have a few other problems with it as well like why is there a cool down for ordering archers to fire? One unit fires on one enemy unit and I have to wait a good few seconds before I can order an entirely separate unit of archers to fire on an entirely separate unit of archers. The orders system is a nice idea but I don’t think it is well realised. The unit special abilities and general abilities from Rome 2 would’ve been a better style of system and each ability has advantages and disadvantages meaning that they are a tactical choice. The orders on the others hand you just spam every time the cool down timer is over.How did they mess this up so badly?Not something that gets my personal recommendation but if you’re a looking for a well-balanced f2p and you don’t consider this an affront to the good name total war then it’s not all that bad under the surface.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												I"m having a good casual time learning and playing this game. The combat is tricky to learn and engaging enough to want another battle. Win or lose. Combat troops are rock, paper and sissor types, but if a mistake is made, the user can use sideline buffs to help regain control of the situation. The art style of Total War shows through in the battles.The building system is pretty straight-forward with a good starting tutorial. I love how you can manage the terrian. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Not terrible but certainly not good. Falls down on the use of the total war name most of all in my opinion (explained below). It's a tablet game and nothing more, if this were a play store or Itunes review the score would be very different. It's not a PC game, f2p or not, end of discussion. But if Sega insist on offering it as a PC game I shall review it as one. 5/10I did have to think quite a lot about whether I could recommend this game and while it’s not a bad game per se it certainly isn’t a good game at the moment ( I appreciate it’s still in beta and a lot could change) . In fact to be fair to this game as a free-2-play it’s not too bad and miles ahead of Stronghold: kingdoms in both art style and mechanics. On the positive side I thought that the building and settlement creation were quite well done though they are a little basic. Kudos to the team for pretty excellent terrain height, excavation and water mechanic programing, it really helps to create this felling that the world itself can be shaped to suit your needs. The time required for building and resource gathering was pretty good, not obscenely long as in most free-2-plays (read as free-2-wait). On top of this you can even find and mine premium currency allowing any player no matter how stingy to gain some of the advantages. In fact if the game was purely the build section then I would actually recommend it.There are however massive issues with the battle system. And by massive issues I mean JESUS CHRIST WHY DID YOU THINK THIS WAS A GOOD IDEA? Yeah that level of bad. I do have to admit that most of my issues with the combat are simply that it is difficult to accept calling this a total war game. I am a die-hard fan of the series (hell I even like empire) and like many total war fans I love the complexity of tactics one can to utilize to win. The battles of Battles: Kingdom seem to have stripped all this away to be replaced with clicking to charge at the right time….what?..... WHAT?.... HOW HAVE YOU TURNED YOUR COMBAT INTO QUICK TIME EVENTS? QTEs in total war now, along with day one dlc you’d be forgiven for thinking EA had bought CA. That said Sega aren’t much better look what they did to sonic. I have't played Shogun 2 Battles but i see that the combat in that is turn based, why didn't they keep that? sure its not total war but at least it's still tactical not ♥♥♥♥ING QTEs!!! But my issues with the battles don’t stop there. I have a few other problems with it as well like why is there a cool down for ordering archers to fire? One unit fires on one enemy unit and I have to wait a good few seconds before I can order an entirely separate unit of archers to fire on an entirely separate unit of archers. The orders system is a nice idea but I don’t think it is well realised. The unit special abilities and general abilities from Rome 2 would’ve been a better style of system and each ability has advantages and disadvantages meaning that they are a tactical choice. The orders on the others hand you just spam every time the cool down timer is over.How did they mess this up so badly?Not something that gets my personal recommendation but if you’re a looking for a well-balanced f2p and you don’t consider this an affront to the good name total war then it’s not all that bad under the surface.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												This game probably has the potential to be considered fun, but it certainly is not right now. The reason is that you are limited in every aspect of growth, required to spend Gold (pay currency) in order to complete tasks instantly. This becomes maddening very quickly once you realize you require gold for basically every aspect of growth that in other games you would unlock with time and experience. The best types of units require large sums of gold to hire, leaving player who do not pay incapable of feilding a force containing more than one of these kinds of units without playing for eternities or paying. The actual battle system has very little to do with total war, instead playing like an automated combat rpg in the style of Disciples, where units are on a grid and almost exclusively deal with the units directly in front of them. Thus almost the entire combat portion of the game is fighting pre designed layouts of enemy units, which are designed to cause trouble for players without any of the top shelf units. This over simplification of combat reduces Cavalry to a rock-paper-scissors role rather than a strategic weapon; artillary peices are outright removed from combat  and instead offers periodic direct fire. This bait and switch for combat would be tolerable if the system was not designed to make you wait up to an hour for your units to "recover from wounds" for each unit that takes noticable damage during a fight. After three hours, every part of the game is reduced to a painful crawl if you refuse to buy gold. Upgrading buildings costs several hundred of multiple resources, things you gather 20-40 at a time of. Combined with several pay mechanics like advisors and contracts there is just way too much content that is purposefully put in place to make you want to spend. I'm sick of the meritless "well they got to make money somehow" arguement that is perpetuated by these sorts of schemes. They could of just as easily made the pacing much easier by increasing the amount of gold given to you and reducing costs, etc. There are ways to make the game bearable, they just did not want to do it. If the game replicated the total war combat system in the small space the battles took place, reduced the arbitrary timers, and offered more in the ways of appearance items for those soldiers than I would of been interested. Sadly all we get is an off-brand Stronghold online game, which is doubly odd because most consider Stronghold the off-brand travian. All in all, a very shoddy attempt at turning Total Wars into a mobile phone experience. The combat is designed to limit strategy and only respect hard counters and luck mechanics and the buildings aspect is the equivilent of giving a painter this gigantic canvas and asking him to pay them for every mark made on the canvas, all the paints, the honor of being there working on the canvas, as well as the "canvas using" tax. There is very little "Total War" anything besides the presence of units that look like they are from Total War.
