It's great as a casual game played on a tablet, a triple-A title it ain't.2) yes, it's pay-to-win, but who said you need to "win" a casual mobile game? Duelling mode is clearly full of people who did pay to win. Consider this a tax on stupidity which makes the game free to play for you, just enjoy it for what it is for a couple of hours and have the maturity to quit once the grind is setting in. conclusion: it's a cute little game, it's free to play, so take it or leave it, don't b*tch about it not being what it never tried to be.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												A review about Total War Battles: KINGDOM is simple as this... Is this a good PC game? No, not at all... Will it be good for mobile? Probably one of the best. These "browser-like" strategy games that we're all used to from way back in the early Facebook days, with games like Evony, Tribal Wars, Kingdom Age, Dawn of Fantasy, etc. don't work as a stand-alone PC game. Their models are pay-to-win, everything takes minutes to hours to harvest or build... These are the types of game you quickly jump on in your sparetime on your iPad or various other tablets. At this point, I'm only continuing to play the game to prep myself for the mobile release so I have a good basis to stand on when the switch to mobile comes. Basically, me doing what I can with this accurent account to transfer to my iPad and keep playing.You can definitely tell this game is meant for mobile as well. They way the battles and castle-town building functions just screams, "MOBILE!"Final review? Don't bother while it's PC only. Wait until the mobile release to really find out for yourself if this game is worth it.

												This game really isn't for fans of previous Total War games but it's charming in it's own right. Even when you loose battles you'll progress which makes the game less discouraging and the quick play times means this game directly appeals to the mobile market. Unlike most MMO's out there TWB Kingdoms won't suck the soul out of your life once you start playing it.On the downside though, you'll find it difficult to obtain special weapons and troops without spending money or doing some serious soul sucking grinding. Overall it's OK, I enjoyed my around 12+ hours I spent playing it.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Ive been playing for a few hours now. I see how the game is supposed to be, but they dont seem to be able to reach that, the gathering times are too long, the resource respawning is too long, and the AI in battles can be realy hard to beat when they have 3 units of mercs and i have mostly Levies.It could probably become one of the best games on the mobile market for this kind of game, if i didnt have to wait an hour to get my wood from a tree then wait for tree stumps to vanish, then grass to grow, then trees to grow, all this work will probably take a day or 3 and for what? 20 wood? i need around 500 wood to be able to UPGRADE that wood cutter. Then again. it is a good game, its nice to be able to freely expand my town/city while having to worry about rivers and hills to be able to build my town. the combat is 200x better than all the other bad/weird mobile games (except games like Clash of Clans wich have a pretty good combat system for Mobile games) I would not recomend this if your hoping for it to be a "conquer the world with a massive army" like in the other Total wars. Ofcourse i wouldnt call this a Total war game if i was CA though. I would recomend it thought to people that feel they want something to do while they are bored or have nothing better to do. Dont think that when you install this you will be met by being able to build hundreds of buildings in under a minute, its not, this is a time game, you will have to wait for your buildings, wait for your resources and wait for your army. I like that CA is expanding into new territories of gaming, but using the same name for some totaly other game is just not right. Even though i can see that calling it Total war would be able to make more ppl download it....smart move CA, smart move.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Despite this game have the Battles-Part in the name I decided to give it a try. After all the game looked good this time around and the city-building seemed interesting. This sadly led to me wasting around 2 hours of my life.Now let's take a look at the good points first:-The graphics are great. From the landscape to the buildings and even the units (not that you will have a lot of time to   look at them)-You have the ability to build some truly impressive cities. it won't be easy and it sure as hell won't be anytime soon that  you have one, but in the end the player is (theoretically) able to do it.Sadly the downsides easily outweight those good sides:-The combat is lane based. I personally HATE those kinds anyway but I thought "Hey, maybe CA actually made it good",  but the answers was a loud all-encompassinge "Nope". It's just run-of.the-mill lane-combat. No flanking, barely any   control over the units/battlefield, a very limited amount of troops, both in numbers and in variation and in general all   the suckage that is lane-combat.-Upgrading your units takes a lot of time. And I mean a LOT of it. The first upgrade for any of the basic attributes costs   20 points, the next 40. Now I dont know if I'm just bad or what but I got around 7-12 per fight. That wouldn't be so bad   if the fight themselves would be fun (they are not) and if there were no freaking enforced break after every battle (if   they were harmed). You can of course skip it but that requires hard gold aka real money.-The game in general is just slow, by the way: did you know that grass grows faster than this games plays? Okay that   was exaggerated but the fact remains that the amount of time you spend waiting is ridiculous. Gathering ressources   from random spots takes 10 minutes which is okay, same goes for excevating stone but gathering wood and wood   takes days and this time I'm not even kidding. Wood and crops both take 8 hours to chop/gather and then another 10  hours for crops and up to 2 (or 1 and a half) to regrow. Now it wouldn't be so bad if you would at least get a decent  amount but you only get 10 per field... 10! Though you can once again skip all this waiting with gold... hooray.My verdict is:  BEST GAME OF ALL TIME 13/10!!! *shot*  Stay away from it, at least for now. It isn't the worst game of all time and maybe even not  bad game all together but it certainly if on the wrong platform. It might have been fun on a tablet or a smartphone (yeah sure) but for the PC?A easy way to improve the game would be to reduce the amount of time to do... well everything. I wont demand the removal because that will never happen (hell not even the reduce will happen). But if the taim for the ressources would be halved and the time for unit-recovery, unless they were annihilated, removed it would already be a way better game. Oh and add more strategic depth don't forget that... especially the flanking.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I do recommend this game if you're looking for a strategic battlefield simulation game. It has everything you need, and an easy levelling system, easy resources, and a tough setup that will keep you on your toes. Water works well into the terrain, and the layout of the buildings are well-done. The only downside I could find to this game is the PvP. You can be a low level, and it will literally put you with someone 7 levels higher than you just because they have a rank close to yours. This is extremely unfair and should be fixed, but I'm sure they're MUCH too busy to do that. Otherwise, a good game. I do recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Man, CA really wants money... unless you can wait for years, this game forces you to spend all your gold (real currency for special currency which you've seen a million times on mobile games) on producing materials to build more things. I love the idea but simple things like farming in a pain in the a**. The battles are cheap and very lame, whoever taps the charge button at the right time wins the battle. The beginning is great, you have so many resources and it seems like you can build a massive kingdom, but if you want to do anything you have to use all of your resources to do it. Roads are useless, buildings have to touch in order to build more and a bunch of other cr*p. I'm getting fed up with these mobile games ripping me off by using time against me, I just wanted a game where I could build my own kingdom the way I want to, without the restriction of having to spend all my real money on freaking farming and mining and getting silver (silver is impossible to produce, it takes forever just to get 20). Roads should count a connective material for buildings and I should be able to change the land without having to change 1000 things around it first (there is a height thing where the surrounding land has to be a height before you can change the height of the intended hexagon). You level quickly and gain a million things quickly but because castles can only build a few buildings you are fu*ked (you need a castle in order to build on a 15x15 land). To summarize, it's like a generic mobile game with a few interesting terrain features and a semi unique battling system used in previous total war mobile games. I have not played for long but I really want future players to know that the beginning rocks until you notice that you're sh*t out of materials. As well as I do not believe that other players may attack your kingdom and take all your resources, I do not know if that is a thing in this game but it seems unlikely (I really like that feature haha!).

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Ok I have played the game for some time now and have 3 regions and only one level 2 castle which took forever to grind  to get there. I tried to get the 4th region but the units they have are all level 2 and  3 units and they also have a onager that just flat out wipes your level 1 units off the map. So I figured yea this looks to be pay to win so what do I do I drop $20.00 to get some better units . Oh guess what you can only buy 1 of those units lol.... but your enemy has 3 of that unit and they are level 2 and 3 you lose. So next I figure I will just try level the one unit but guess what you need to level that building first!! OMG!!!.... yes for every unit you have you have to level that building up first to make it rank 2 unit and it costs 1800 of one resource and 1500 of some other resource to complete just one building.  Not sure what it will cost to go rank 3 but I can imagine a heck of alot more for sure!!....And you still have to grind to level up those units too. My concern is I noticed in the video it says that you protect your lands from other players. Though I have not been invaded by any players only AI so far.  But my concern is after all the time you spend on trying to level everything and spend real money just to lose everything to someone else who is Rich and wants your Land . your just SOL.. Not sure if thats just multiplyer version or not.  Single player version is all that is available atm.  But you can battle other players in what they call a Duel..  So my 2 cents is if you have alot of time and money this game is for you if not stay away.  I'm going to continue playing it since I have already donated to it and see what happens down the road when the campaign part opens up. I will then post another  review then.

												I screamed when I played my first battle in this game, wait, nevermind, I didnt play any battles, I just watched a one.This game has none of the features of a Total War game. There is no total war, the battles are disgusting in how they foul the image of previous titles, and there are no kingdoms, just glorified estates. This game could have been a quirky simple, mainstream version of total war for free, but all it is, is Clash of Clans with a respected name. This game screams for your money, and while i expected that a free to play gme would need it's way of earning money,this is just disgraceful. This game does not deserve the name it bears, and to watch this game explain its mechanics to me like I'm a brain damaged horse, is to see the horrible future for this franchise.I for one wanted a Total War game that had the same micro transactions as Team Fortress, or DOTA, a game that is simplified but still has an enjoyable, simple combat system, wih small armies, but soldiers that matter, that you'd care about. But unfortuntely, that sentence doesnt have enough $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
TL;DR at the bottom.People need to realise that this is a game designed for tablet / mobile thus not a title between all the other Total War games but an offshot for a completely different platform. Imagine playing the latest Total War on tablet, not happening.How can you tell? Controls. Mouse only, no keybindings.Mobile games are coming to steam! So are console games! Deal with it! To start a hate train because a game seemed to come to the "wrong neighbourhood" is unsightly. They can do their part on steam too but you are not forced in any way to play them.This game is also "F2P" (Depending on your definition) which with most certainty includes microtransactions like most F2P titles (Big suprise there). Being F2P also creates paywalls which are either non scalable because the content behind it is exclusively for paying users or tough but not impossible to reach for players who do not want to spend real money. And in the end becomes a slowpaced game for everyone who decides not to spend money.First of all I'd like to dispel some of the false or lacking information on which most reviews are based creating a maelstrom of bad reviews from players fresh out of the tutorial.The most popular : Harvesting wheat / felling trees -> 8 hours waitingAfter building your farm wheat fields start to appear around it, depending on the distance to water the time until they are able to be harvested differs.After the wheat is finally harvestable you are given TWO CHOICES: 1. Harvest a single spot : 20 min. = 20 unitsor2. Harvest ALL spots : 8 hours = 10 units / spotAs you can see option no. 2 is the worst possible choice.If this is the reason you quit playing and gave the game a bad review then you should have paid more attention to what you are doing instead of causing a temper tantrum for no reason.It is quite a waiting game at the beginning, but every sane gamer would not stare at the monitor waiting for the counter to drop to zero, that's why this is more of an inbetween games game.The most concerning : Pay to win / Paywall (Paying users exclusive content)I think we all can agree that in a situation where you pit equally skilled players against one another, that the one who can pay real money to give him an edge in combat will most definetely win if the game is not heavily RNG-based.However the real question here is: Is the equally skilled player condemned to never overcome this hurdle even with zeal and competetive spirit? The answer to that is : He can, with time.Let me explain:There are NO paying users exclusive : Buildings / Units / Buffs / Equipment, every player has the same selection and arsenal. Unlike other mobile games where the best buildings and units are exclusively obtainable through real money.All players do not have acess to everything on the get go. You need to reach a certain level regardless wether you want to pay or not to have buildings (and their corresponding units) unlocked. Every military building comes with a selection of 3 to 4 different units depending on the building. Example : You build your first stable and it can house only one mounted unit. After building your stable you choose which one you want. (F2P ALERT) The first two of the three units you can choose without any hitch (100% free), however the third is behind a real money paywall (That shook you a little, right?). But against all odds you are able to "craft" the third unit and kick out the one currently stationed (no money paid).Those units are statwise superior than the other but not unobtainable for non paying users.As for Buffs and Equipment those can also be crafted like military units and given to those or used on the battlefield.As for the game itself. It is pretty slowpaced but steadily gains velocity as you progress. You start off with 1 of 6 regions and you have a restriction of how many buildings you can mantain within this region. This restriction gradually decreases the more regions you liberate and castles you upgrade within each region. Effectively increasing your playtime each session. I do not want to venture any further into the building system and the little tricks therein, because a little trial and error doesnt hurt.The tutorial is rather short and gives you the basics of the basics but not all the vital information you desperately need. In my opinion this is a bad choice of tutorial, instead of having tutorial pieces pop up when you need them, say changing seasons, new buildings, new units, new regions, small events etc. they leave you out to fend for yourself and figure it out on your own. Along with the tutorial the tooltips also lack information as well as numbers.Tooltips need a desperate overhaul and the tutorial needs to be more than just an introduction to the basics of basics. To counter a lack of information a compedium of such would have been a nice way to make wating somehow enjoyable. The combat is a squad based rock-paper-scissors system (if that makes any sense). Every unit consists of multiple soldiers and counter or is countered by another unit. Lance > Rider > Shield > Archer > Lance > and so on. Additionaly armor is a factor Mace > leather + chain , Axe > Plate.If that wasn't enough, in the beginning the two facing units charge each other to engage in close combat depending on your timing, you do heavy charge damage before the brawl begins or none at all (pre-emptive strike). But wait! There's more!Every unit can get one of two abilites purchased through experience acquired through battle. Making your units more diverse and useful in certain situation. For example switching your shield units with a your mounted units which are engaged with lance units (rock-paper-scissors, remember?) to avoid certain death for your horsemen.To top it all of you can have in your 9-squad army up to 3 and at least 1 siege unit. Ranging from ballistaes, trebuchets or mangonels. Ballistaes hit only enemy units for moderate damage, instantly killing weak armored targets. Trebuchets hit all units for a good amount of damage. Mangonels leave the area they hit burning and damaging any and all units that remain in this area. Every siege unit act as an ability with their own innate cooldown before you can use them again. But if you have 3 siege units and 6 fighting units and on the other hand your oppenent has 9 fighting units which disperse your 6 quite fast you have lost even with the siege units still intact und unscathed. (I don't think you can actually damage / destroy siege units)Quite the arsenal and not as simple a battlesystem I dare say.After every battle your units need time to recuperate depending on how wounded they are 10 to 20 min. or if unscathed not at all. However you cannot engage in another battle while a unit in your army is still recuperating. Yes, you can skip waiting with a little bit of moneyflow but if you are eager to fight battle after battle it can become very expensive and you should play another Total War game.The experience your units gain can be used to either upgrade the unit itself thus adding more soldiers to this unit, upgrade melee damage, range damage, armor rating or charge damage. Or as already mentioned purchase one of two abilites for this unit which may turn the tide of battle.TL;DR: It's a F2P inbetween-games-(tablet)game with no content locked behind a paywall (no paying user exclusives). Paying players cannot exceed the limits of a non-paying player. Slowpaced at the start with steadily increasing session lengths. Lack of information may result in uneffecient use of terrain, buildings or units. Not a game for the impatient.This will get downvoted to hell because those who do, are either those you didn't grasp the concept of the game or jumped on the hate train for the lulz.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												I have been playing this game for some 17.6 hours over several weeks( whic is constantly upgrading and waiting), I think it is extremely difficult to understand alot of the game mechanics. the water fluidity mechanics for example can completely ruin your entire map if you try to excavate and change your terain to build over the winter. come spring everything can flood before you realize your mistake. the crafting system is absurd in the fact of the amount of resources per crafting stage..yes 5 crafting stages per item with more materials then could reasonably be put into a shield for example. Combat missions for begining players is at best a slaughter, which is designed to make you pay for gold to heal your units..pay to play..the map is not big enough to correctly build roads between the first new area you can win/pay tribute to gain. By the time you try to build roads adjusting the terrain to do so, you ruin the correct aspect of farming/herding/grazing mechanics, and oh yeah dont forget the flooding. It took me along time to build/rebuild buildings to locate them properly within the given terrain..its bearily possible because you place x amount of buildings before you level which unlocks the buildings you should have placed corectly the first time..woops wasted time and resouces again..then to realize the harbor once you can make one doesnt work right because the ships cant get up the river to the fish..lol..demolish.. rebuild terain..try to make a river to reach them..oops you cant lower terain uphill to the level of the fish..ugh..I hope the game has a wipe upon release because I really would do so much better now that I know what I should have done if the information would have been available to learn how beforehand!The game has great potential if some better information was available to new players before they make game ending mistakes..flood entire map for example..hard to recover from..with no option to delete and start anew.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												It's one of those facebook games where progression is based on how long you wait and gameplay consists of getting stuff ready to wait for. The combat consists of waiting for your ability cooldowns and wishing that you could order your archers to shoot something (but you can't because you have to wait on a cooldown since you already told some completely different archers to shoot something else). The objecive of the game is to gather resources so you can improve your infasructure so that you can raise an army that you can try using to keep yourself from getting bored while waiting to gather resources. Another great strategy is to play a different game to keep yourself from getting bored while waiting to gether resources, but then since you won't be needing those resources for anything since you won't be bored enough from playing this game to need an army to attempt to stave off that boredome, you might as well just not play this game to begin with.On the plus side, it's kinda pretty. You can watch the little knights pace back and forth, and the birds fly in circles, and the peasants walking down a long road that leads nowhere, and a tiny little fisherman sitting on the lake in his little boat as he waits for the fish to bite.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Overall its one of the best free to play town building game. Has some great concepts such as game effecting seasons and terrain modifying. If you like a slight mixture of civ 5, past total war games, and stronghold then you may like this game.But I do think it would be a more popular game/ better to play if it was buy to play or if it leaned less on paying for gold to actually get/do stuff. It could focus more on advisors,perks,customization with the in game purchases rather than pay some gold to buy a unit or to get tons of resources to upgrade a building/ craft a unit. Also a sort of info panel on units, buildings, game concepts, etc. would help. Because sometimes I would find myself building in an area where it will not function or building something like the knights manor where you can only have one unit of that type.Pros:Casual (if you like that)Good ConceptsGood EnvironmentCustomization of units,town,environment, etc.Quest systemCons:Casual (if you dont like that)Some things cost rediculous amounts of silver/resources to upgrade, sort of forcing the player to grind for days or to use goldNo info panelSummary: You should give it a try, though depending on who you are you will probably uninstall it. It is in beta so you can't really hate on it because it is still being developed and does require info from the community to help out devs. To an extent you can play the game f2p but there will eventually be moments where you will end up spending gold to advance. It is built more for mobile device users who usually do spend $ for in game currency rather than pc gamers.I will probably continue to play it. But I do hope that it improves and leans more towards pc user gameplay rather than casual mobile players.

												I've played this game a few hours now and have mixed feelings.It playes like a browser multiplayer RTS, except that the city building is much better, everything has a timer.Pro:- Like the city building and resource management system- GFX is good for this kind of game- Like the easy, but strategic combatCons:- Miss seing other players on the map- Miss interacting with other players (other than duels)- Where's the alliance system?- Should be player controlled land and cities to conquer (Have not seen any yet)They have created a good plattform from which to expand with many features. It's war, so let us wage war agains other players too!I'm gonna keep playing and expanding my territory for many hours yet, but what happend when the six regions is mine? What's the end-game goal then? You should try this game out and let's hope they expand with more features tuned toward player interaction :)

												Total War Battles series for mobile plattforms.Most people seem to confuse the Battle series which is a more casual approach towards mobile plattforms for the full blown Total War games. These are ment to compete with other mobile freemium strategy games out there on tablets etc.Kingdom is by far the best game Ive ever tried in this category and I look very much forward to have it on my iPad. The really neat thing this time around is that you can play the game on all plattforms. PC, Tablet etc. and that is a great feature for a mobile game.For its category it has great depth and immersion and Im totally hooked and played close to 40 hours of the Open Beta with 3 characters in parallell. Of course, being a Beta you must expect a lot of issues and be patient.Looking very much forward to having this on my iPad :).

content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I really enjoy the terraforming, city planning,  and the battle. but the games really need a restart button.Should not try to rush the game, but play it in an interval of period of time.battle only takes around 2 minutes. As you progress, the battle become more difficult and you have to figure out ways to counter the enemy.Terraforming and building city is great. such as drying out an entire lake to redo irragation and fishing pond or forest land. takes forever, but the final outcome is supprising. The resource ouput increases without any battles.City planning is difficult, because the game is still in beta version and their are no tips or help wiki. You learn by mistake.At the start focus on controlling the first two regions by building up an army and a battle strategy. After that,  I went into complete domestic planning (farming, controlling river, quarry...) to increase resouce output like food, stones and woods.Silver can easily be earn by battle, so do not waste too much time on that resource.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												I didn't get this originally because of all the negative reviews.  If you go into this expecting "total war farmville" like most of the reviews make this game sound like, this is actually really well done.  You all but NEED a touchscreen computer or tablet though, because using a mouse is just inconvenient.  However for what you're paying (nothing) this game is really enjoyable, and if you don't mind a game you can only play for 20-40 minutes a few times a day the pace is actually pretty well done.  Yes, you can pay for things with gold to speed it up, and at the very start I would suggest doing that, but now that I've played for a while I have enough troops I can cycle through them and play for a comfortable amount of time before stopping to do something else.It's not a total war game, and if you thought you were going to get anything like a full total war game for free you're insane.  This is a large step above and beyond pay to win games right now.  Yes, if you want to be the best you have to pay, but if you don't care about how well you rank on leaderboards and just play the game at your own pace it's kind of zen.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												Game has many interesting concepts yet fails to deliver sustanable long term interest. This game is essentually a micropay journey through a sandbox that becomes smaller and smaller with every acomplishment. The further the player progresses in the game, the longer it takes to acomplish simple tasks such as upgrading troops and and buildings. While the game allows for multiple stradegies to "farm" resources, the cost of advancement is clearly designed to frustrait the player into buying gold. Unlike most micopay gamers, buying gold does little to quicken the play of the game. The gold component simply allows you to puchase better units that allow you to advance game play a little farther, prolonging the agony of farming for days to upgrade buildings or units. Oddly enough, after all of the time you spend saving and gathering, once you finally can upgrade a building, you have to wait a few hours more or spend some gold. One silver lining is that the games use of changing enviroments . While lost on this game, this feature could be very interesting in other more high profile turn based stradegy games...

												It's hard to get into the city building part because it's sooooooo slooooooow paced.  Wait ages to get a pittance from your resource supply nodes.  Battles are a joke.  Minimal control over your units once battle starts.  Global cooldowns* applied to multiple units makes any kind of on the fly deployment reorganization or [ranged] target change a huge hassle. The four hours play time I have/[had at time of review], is about 10-12 sessions because there is so little to do.  * They don't seem to apply to AI though.  I had one enemy end unit move two times in a row, to the other end slot.  It was a cavalry unit so I had my spears lined up to them before the battle.  I started my move before their first move was over, but before my units were finished swapping, they were already starting their next swap.  Before my move cooldown was up, the fighting had begun.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												All the negative reviews for this game compare it to all the other total war games, such as Shogun, Rome, Medieval, etc. Compared to them, yes, this game IS not good. However, this is a MOBILE game (At least not at the moment). This game was made to be played on a tablet as well a computer. As a mobile game, this game is great. So before I say more, I will be treating this as a MOBILE game in this review.Battles: Pros:Great detailSimple and funStill requires the use of tactics and stretegyCan be very challenging at pointsMany different units to the game, from mercenaries to vikingsCons:Only 1 unit against 1 unit in close combatCannot destroy artilleryRecharging orders to shoot, move, or stop shooting- probably the worst part.No flankingCampaign/Empire buildingPros:Great detailExpanding your kingdom is really fun. You get to conquer territories and expand you empire usint tiles, which allow you to create your own cities.Cons:Wait times for building, gathering, etc can be a very long time (12 hours is the longest I have seen so far.) But compared to other free mobile games, wait times are really not that bad. *cough* CoC *cough*This game is definitly one of the best free to play strategy games I have played. If you like the genre, this is a game you should try out. The only thing I would change is to make some things not require currency (Gold) that requires "micro-transactions" (I qoute that because you CAN get gold without paying for it, fairly easily compared to other games) But other then that, Im having a great time with the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 10 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Now I love(d) the Total War series, I've played everything from Rome I to Rome II, and I can say, that as a long time TW player, I don't think this is a good Total War game, infact I question if it should even be associated with TW. But, as a video game player in general, I think this a decent game. Sure they expect you to pay microtransactions, but I havent payed a single micro transaction and my game is going fairly smoothyl, this isn't a waiting game, this is a game that you should play for about 10-20 mins a day, go about your business and maybe check up on your Breton town with your electronic device. If you expect, a grand strategy, amazing, award winning, strategy game that can keep you entertained for hours on end, than you will be in for a sore dissappointment. But if you play it for what it is, than it will be a perfectly good game to spend some time playing.=======Pros=======-Battles-Graphics-City / Town management-Territory Conquest=======Cons=======-No Byzantines (Yea, I was kinda dissappointed we could only be Bretons. Can't even be Saxon or Norse, just Bretons... Hey I guess you could be King Arthur though)Now some of you might think that there has to be more problems to the game than 'No Byzantines.' Yea... not really, it's a free game and if you want you can put a few dollars into micropurchases, these micropurchases aren't actually needed to play the game though. Oh, and did I mention, IT'S FREE. There is nothing wrong with this game, people don't like it because it doesn't fit in the 'Grand Strategy' category that most TW games do. So, there is no reason, not to get this game. So get it, play it, hate it, love it, I don't care. This game gives me much more hope in the TW title than Attila (That over priced DLC that they call a game) ever will. Just because, this is a unique game that is fun and you can kill some time on. Comments are welcome. (Within reason)

												Due to the time it takes to build and perform certain actions - from a few hours to a day, in real time - it's the kind of game you'll probably jump into, make some adjustments and then come back to it in a few hours or the next day. The game is fun, although I'm not sure about the controversial "gold" situation yet; in some cases it will just take you longer without gold, but in other cases such as buying powerful units, you need gold. You start off with some gold, you can make gold yourself through gold mines, missions etc., but the amounts you get in that manner are quite limited - maybe 1-5 gold per mission, whilst some of the powerful units cost around 150 gold. I'm sure in the later parts of the game, these units bought for gold can be hard to get around. But then again, it's a free game. By the way, did I mention gold?

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												This is very much an adroid/ios mobile rts freemium game, the typical expectations of such include but are not limited to long wait times to build stuff and the further you go the faster you can expand because you will be making so much more income at a time than in the beginning.  You can do absolutely everything for free it will just take longer, which is typical of a mobile freemium game.The game is quite aesthetically pleasing and the little nuances of weather and what the different seasons do to the land scape are a very nice touch.  The combat is pretty straight forward with some tactic and foresight required, very rock paper scissors with some buffs and debuffs you can use but only up to 3 buffs/debuffs at a time that you can unlock as you go.All in all it makes for a great mobile game, something to check in on or play for a few minutes to an hour a day, but not a good PC game due to the amount of time it takes to do things and the style of play, I dont think it was ever originally intended to be a PC game and was the original design of it to be a mobile game, in which case I believe it excels very well.  As such I recommend this game and am patiently waiting for it to come to android, however if this had been originally designed for PC(which I know it is not) then i would be agreeing with the sea of negativity this game seems to have on steam.

												This is a very good f2p game, interesting concepts that are not too coplex but still offer good gameplay. The combat is a little unbalanced right now but the kingdom building is really fun. It's not a game that you can play constantly but rather one that you can pick up now and then, it is very casual and doesn't force you to spend any money. From what I can tell money speeds up the process but doesn't get you anything that you couldnt get without spending money. The pvp part is a place where spending money matters, but I would expect that to change as people level up. Overall a fun casual game.

												                                           (I have spent no money on this game not even within it)           When i first decided to play Total war battles: KINGDOM i thought it would just be a waste of my time like all the reviews said it would be... I saw one review that said it was good... and it was. This isn't just any ordinary game you can do so much with it.You can...-Build multiple citys-Change the terrain-Arrange and edit armies-Fight with the armies-Take over other sectors-and so much more         Personnely my favorite of those is fighting with the armies. You can actually tell your men to move, when to charge, and archers who to shoot at. Changing the terrain is awesome as well. Most the time in games like this, you get a terrain and your stuck with it no way to change it. In this however, you can raise, lower, clear, and do even more with the terrain.        I highly reccomend this game to you, and remember i spent no money(not even within the game) to play. I hope this was helpful

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Yes, recommended: But be prepared. Essentially a Clash of Clans-esque game with the Total War logo. Played it for about 3 days straight. First of all. To all those naysayers, and I know there are many for this game. This game is not a traditional Total War game. It's essentially them trying out mobile games. And it's amazing, in that regard. Then, for those people saying it's pay to play. That couldn't be farther from the true. It's the perfect homework game. Start mining, start farming, then do your homework. It is not pay to play to play, in the three days i've played, i've been doing just fine, winning online matches aplenty, rank is 16 and continuing to go down everytime I do an online match. It's an amazing game overall, simply understand that this isn't a traditional Total War game. The game was never meant to be a traditional total war. 8/10

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This game is nothing like all other total war games. And most gamers who like a series do not like to see that series do something different (like all shooter series). This game is more like tribal wars and settler online. If you like those games you will love this. Also the slow start will scare most gamers away, but like most building games you start with nothing and you will gain more when you play. Ones you have your second castle and 8 units (12 with militia) at your hands things will move faster and faster until you do not need to wait until your units are healed. By the time I'm writing this I have played the game for 4 days and I now have 4 castles and have 20 units and have not spend 1 gold. Gaining new lands is important and not impossible if you play smart. Also it takes time and practise to make the water your friend instead of your enemy (but then again I’m Dutch so building dams and cannels is in my blood)Pro's: Water: is vital for growing grass, tree’s, grain and fishinteractive map: you can built more things on this map than another free to play game out there. From canals to serval city's. (but you need to think ahead)different seasons: these will change the map and how fights look but also create new problems and opportunities (like droughts in the summer are great to change the flow of the rivers)You can build all things: No need to pay for stuff with gold/ real money to get all stuff in the game.interactive fights: the fights are interactive can be won with pure skillupgradable units: you gain experience, learn skills and you can build new and better weapons for your unitssmart AI: the AI will use skills and will change formations of his units to match yoursdifferent ways to gain gold: You can gain gold trough serval ways without paying for it with real moneyGreat graphics: best graphics for a game of this kindcons: Player vs player sucks: from cheating with buying all stuffs from unfair match making combine that with low reward and in sort multiplayer no fun.slow start: If you are not able to gain new area’s fast (by fighting) you will have to few unitscons/pro'sNo player raids: you cannot steal from others and they cannot steal from youRaids :  sometimes a raider will appear and steal your resources if you not beat him in 24 hours (or bribe him)Verdict: 8 Great game for those who are willing to spend

number of helpful: 0 of 9 people (0%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												As far as free to play games go this one is ok, but the only reason it is good is due to it being a TOTAL WAR game. If this didn't have its title no-one would play it.Pros:-Adds a new spin on city builder games-Addictive-Not hard to get good-competitive with friendsCons:-Autumn flooding is complete bull ****, you spend loads of time in summer trying to ge water through your lands and then along comes the f***fest of rain. One river overflow and 2 towns got flooded, 3 quarries, 2 farms and all of my f***ing roads were destroyed. But I can't do anything about it until winter comes to get rid of the sea in the centre of my kingdom.-Secondly the combat is completly broken, when taking over new regions the firs two are fine, the third is hard but not impossible and then comes the fourth. All you have to do is look at the army and realise it is impossible without paying them off. It seems as if they don't want people to progress without spending their life savings for an army. Also when you go into online duels there are no matchmaking, all that happens is they put you with some random person without looking a if you spent money or your level in game. In 3 instances I have been against people who have obviously spent loads of money which means I definitely will not beat them. A couple of times I have been against people using the starting units when I have a very strong army without spending money, this system is completely broken and must be fixed.Although it seems the cons are much greater than the pros I must still remind you it is in BETA so this game still has a while to go before it can be judged as a full game like Rome 2 was.

												Pay to win- Yeah Have I played alot of pay to win and never pay a dime- Always.This I dont mind sure slower but a time waster.Speed of game- SlowLike I said if you want something to do and dont mind clicking around and waiting or coming back to it then this game is not bad.People complain about the 8 hour time it takes for certain things.(It can happen) If you want to harvest wheat then do it individually and dont press the Harvest All or Fell All button which takes longer instead do it individually to minimize time.I Like the fact that before bed I can click then harvest all and come back in the morning to see it ready for me.Graphics are nice simular to the CIV games and Total war games.Battles are different but whats wrong with that sometimes. If you play this game dont expect the same gameplay as the other Total War games.I do think this game would be more enjoyable the farther I get and when it comes to mobile, I can play whenever and wherever I am at to waste time.All in all not bad if you enjoy this kind of game 5/10 from me here. Again Its free to play so give it a try, I dont complain much when I get free things.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												This game is good and fun despite what the naysayers with 30 minutes of playtime are saying.To dispel the myth of Pay to Win...-CRAFTING - This game is not Pay to Win. It is Pay to Go Faster like most F2P's.  You can craft everything so by definition, not pay to win.-Many ways to obtain gold - Mine, wolves, tombs, daily tribute, markets, taverns, battle quests, challenges, conquering regions.-Wait times - typical of Free to Plays.  Get used to it or move along to buyable games.EDIT: ~6 hours in and I am just about at Lord level 15 (PVP unlocked at 15).  You unlock better units and coat of arms customizations too sometime after level 10.  There are a bunch of ways to earn gold for free too.  Could use a decrease in times here and there and some better explanations on certain aspects but I think it is a neat little game. Sorry not sorry.EDIT 2: 10 hours in - I have multiple ways of getting gold now, but slowly.  I am level 19. Still liking the game.EDIT 3: 20+ hours in - Level 27 Lord - a few cosmetics unlocked, 27 gold earned/received so far, 2 battles lost to the AI (which actually was smart in the last loss, dayum son).Update .3 ReviewOverall I'd say it is an improvement.  I played 53 battles on the first night of release.+Reduced times, mostly. 20 minutes >> 1 minute.  1.5 hours > 19 minutes, etc.Gold 100% on daily login. Tombs now give goldNew things to mine (although not as intuitive). Silver, coal, gold, stone.Adjacency bonuses - might still need tweaking but overall an improvement-Realm sized reduced. This is bad. We'll see how bad it is late game...Fertile grass should be removed (wheat can't grow if it is 3 hexes away.)Quarry has a massive range and can't be built next to each other. We're pressuring them on forums for change. Removing a lame prospect takes 12 hours which is absurd.Gold prices for some units have been increased (others reduced).

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												You know what they say; "You don't change a winning team".Or do they?Total War formula revolves around the hybrid turn-based management/real-time strategy and it what defines it. Creative Assembly and Sega are probably exploring new grounds on the "free-to-play" market, a realm filled with casual players who don´t mind spending a buck or two for a few gold coins that will give them an edge like upgrading a unit or instant harvesting of a wheat field. Battles: Kingdom picks up the same battle mechanics of Total War Battles; Shogun and adds an hexagonal map were you build and manage your kingdom, similar to Civilization V, Master of the Arcane or Endless Legend. This is truly the high point of this game; you can actually terraform the environment to your liking, building dams to divert rivers and raising the terrain to your advantage. I spent hours just messing with all the options available. It´s alot more fun than the Beyond Earth terraforming features for example. Honestly, this doesn´t feel like a Total War kind of game but it doesn´t mean its bad. Just make sure that before you venture into it, be prepared for something different that you are used to.

												***written when in BETA with 7.7hrs played***Upon seeing all the negative opinions for TWB:K I decided to take the time to give my thoughts.  I've been a fan of the TW franchise for quite sometime and don't usally play games such as this.  The game will have more appeal when it is cross-platform as the lack of hotkeys and dependence on a only using the mouse cursor to do everything becomes tedious.  I will continue playing this game despite the flaws I've seen in the BETA.  Oh, don't click the book in the top right it'll crash your game.Pros:f2pbeautiful graphicsruns on low end PCsnovel game concepthilarious victory twist dance by spear menCons:pay to progressisn't made clear that gold is a cash currency (tutorial forces you to use gold to speed up production which can lead one to believe it's nessicary to do so and thus you waste most your gold at the startall the blunders you make early on while learning how to play are permanent and will haunt you laterforced to use cursor and no hotkeys availableno bloodcannot see the resources required for a building you will soon unlock therefore planning ahead in that regard isn't possiblewhen you finally unlock the ability to change your flag it costs you way too much gold anyways

number of helpful: 4 of 26 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												CA's Marketing Team does them no favors here: This is not a "Cross-Platform Total War". It's a mobile-designed City Builder with above-average mobile-designed battles that, for some reason, is only being beta tested on PC. The tablet app is still "coming soon", apparently.When you and I think of "Total War", we think of great real-time battles. The battles here are more interactive than the Game of Thrones game or Stronghold Kingdoms, but it's not to the level you're led to believe or expect. No mobile game can pretend to be a full Total War, but CA's description here leads you to believe otherwise.City building is more interactive and strategy matters more than in Stronghold Kingdoms. But Stronghold is about playing Lego Master with city walls. Give this a shot, but understand that it's not a Total War in the way Empire, Rome, Attila and Shogun are; this is a tablet City Builder.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Total war has taken their own twist on a different strategy game.PROSBattle gameplay better than all similar gamesIt doesnt take forever to construct. I really like this, games such as clash of clans may take hours for you to do upgrades, constructions, recruitments. This game however shortens it, making it a better experienceResources dont run out quickly. I love this because in similar games, resources run out very quickly, in which you may have to wait hours to gain back. But total war battles makes it so resources are very well keptYou dont lose your army after battle. Yes you can keep your army, this makes the game even better, because you dont need to waste resources on another armyCONSFeels very slow paced. It just doesnt excite you.Battles should feel more like total war battles. I prefer it when you can move your army about, and not have your army auto moving. You should have more options to what you can do with your army.This isnt really a PC game. It more of a mobile-style game, but oh well.Turns. You know in these other total wars where you have turns, and after it recruits units and finishes constructions. I like that, however I suppose this isnt meant to be like it, I can accept thatOverall I enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 6 of 31 people (19%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												First of all - addressing most of the negative reviews of this game: Do not treat this as a total war game. It may have the name Total War on it but it was never meant to be compared to the standard TW games. I started the game up expecting something similar to Tribal Wars and nothing more and that is exactly what this game has offered. A highly polished cross-platform casual game with fast (but fun) real-time battles.As with all games of this genre there is an option to pay for gold to speed up your progress and recruit different (not overpowered, just a slightly different role) units. You can still earn gold in-game but unless you intend on playing this game for long periods of time in one go then gold is not neccesary. The Kingdom building is fantastic, you can terraform the land to your liking, build it how you like focusing either on your military to capture enemy (AI) settlements or on your economy to buy them out.The PvP multiplayer aspect I haven't yet reached but I'm assuming so far it is for 1v1 army duels only so I can't comment on this. You can customise your coat of arms with a variety of options which will then show up on the shields of your units, loading screens, and various other places.Despite looking rather simple, the combat actually does have a lot of depth to it. In fact compared to any other casual-like game of this genre it has the most depth I have seen. There are 9 unit slots and you can build your army as you wish, individual-stat / ability progression per unit, special  ability-activated buffs you can earn from building churches and so on. There is more to the combat than this - try it! It seems mind-numbingly simple at the beginning but as the army sizes begin to grow and as you gain more abilities the game reveals more and more depth which was a very pleasant surprise.Overall unless you buy gold with real money (you do get A LOT of gold for a small amount of money!) apart from at the beginning this is not a game that you can play for more than an hour at a time due to the nature of the game, but for playing half an hour or so every now and then it's brilliant. A fun, casual game. I highly recommend it!

number of helpful: 5 of 29 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												This game is actually spectacular.Of course, there are plenty of problems, and mainly this game being made for mobile devices. However, the world is quite beautiful, and there is always something to do. Battles are short and enjoyable, however the tactics previous Total War games are known for are swapped for a arcadish style 3 lane battle map. This is still very enjoyable and quite refreshing.Total War Battles: Kingdom is far from a pay2win game like many are saying, but you can see from their lack of playtime they have an opinion formed by others and nothing. Seriously, you can't buy extra resources, you can't buy XP boosts or anything like that. All you can do is speed up harvesting/collecting.Although the map is quite static at first, over night, one of my regions actually partially flooded, and now one of my farming estates is underwater and now appears to be really very dynamic. Build cities is also very enjoyable. There is a challenge to handling resources efficiently. Sure you can set the woodcutter to 'Fell all' trees around him, but that would prevent the opportunity to hunt deer until the forest returns. There are some nice terrain molding tools, although the way damns work are still unknown to me. The army builder is interesting, with an initial 5 places for units, with more slots opening with a higher level. You also can use XP gained from a battle to upgrade certain aspects of a unit, and can choose to keep collecting XP so that you can level the unit up, or use a small amount to level up a certain attribute. My advice is play it now if you really want to help with the development, otherwise, await a spectacular full release :)

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												1. Yes it feels like a mobile game, so it's more of a casual pick up once in awhile and collect and fight etc. The fact you can play on all your devices makes it a good mobile game.2. Yes a lot of units you have to pay in game gold, which is bought with out of game real money. But with that said, I haven't felt like I needed the extra strong units to win battles. And it feels like more of a pay to get ahead quicker rather than the pay to win like everyone claims. People really have a stupid view of what pay to win means.3. I haven't encountered many bugs, and since it's autosave if the game were to crash you wouldn't lose any progress. Loads real quick also.4. The battle is very submersive, you feel like a commander, commanding his troops on the battle field. You command when your units charge and who your bowmen fire upon. Do you shoot the men your horsemen are battling and risk killing some of your own?5. Reminds me of a slow paced Ages of Empires. The graphics are nice and simple, but still pretty and colourful. It's a free game despite what the idiot masses would have you believe. It's not very pvp focused so you don't have to fight people who pay for units, etc., and get slaughtered. Just play it as a casual medieval times simulator.Some things I would like to see implemented are, naming your towns, being able to move peasants to other towns, multiple profiles if I want to start a new game, more things happening graphically on the map i.e peasants walking around, trade carts moving from town to town, barracks has soldiers training, etc..Total Wars games are usually $60 on release, the fact this game is free should tell you people that it's not going to be like a Total Wars game. It doesn't take 8 hours to farm crops, it takes 20 minutes, it takes 8 hours if you want to farm all at once. You should have to take an intelligence quiz before writing reviews, people are dumb.

number of helpful: 11 of 45 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Seeing quite a few negative reviews I was hesitant to try this simple game. Is it a total war? Well.. Technically yes, but only at the bare minimum of comparisons. Is it a good game? Yes for a simple slightly more advanced "facebook" style of game, it is.  Is it worth all the negative reviews? Well that depends on if you were ignorant enough to go in expecting a Total War Attila style facebook game or not. If you don't like Facebook games, you won't like this. It's a good game to just manage when you're bored, or sitting waiting for something on your mobile. The Game Itself:Alot of reviews are claiming this is just another usual facebook game with nothing new. Obviously they didn't spend any longer than a few minutes in the tutorial. There are quite a few interesting things in this game. Of course it is a pay to win setup, as all facebook like games are, however that doesn't mean there aren't alternative ways to getting gold. There are 2 currencies in the game, Gold and Silver. Gold being special currency to buy advanced soldiers or upgrades for soldiers. The main way to get Gold is through paying money. Silver is used to buy everything else, and is gained through Blacksmiths, Markets, etc. ingame by waiting for the timer to loop like most facebook games. This doesn't mean paying Gold is the only way to get gold however. Linking several Taverns together can net you some Gold, as well as Mining. Mines can uncover Gold deposits as well. Chopping down tree's and uncovering ruins can also net you surprises including Gold. Completing Quests and Objectives will net you Gold as well. There are other unique features as well, such as being able to raise and lower the land, fill land in, or use mines to dig land out gaining Dirt. Or simply raise and lower it. Why would you want to do this? Besides being able to sculpt the land to your liking for cosmetic reasons, there is water on the maps. Dams can be made to stop water flow, and make usually unuseable land, useable and buildable.Battles The battles are pretty basic. With special skills gained from the churches you build, your soldiers are lined up 3 x 3. Like most Total War games, the basics are there. Swordsmans vs Spears, Spears vs Horses, Horses vs Archers or Swordsmans. Choosing the correct time to charge as well nets you bonus's. Comparisons  I mentioned this can be compared to other Total War games at the very basic and most minimum. The only real comparisons are the fact that soldier types are rock paper scissors at the basic like other Total War Games, and that you are essentially building up multiple towns to upkeep your armies... yea.. not really much comparisons, you can still argue it's not a Total War game at all, and I wouldn't say you are wrong. This is a facebook game however, so expecting more is lunacy.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I have played over 500 hrs (or so Steam says; it must include time the compurter is active even though I am not).The game is okay, but not great. Now that I have occuppied all six territories, I am not sure what would motivate me to play again. There is not much variation in the game; gather resources, update buildings and/or units then go fight a couple of battles, then repeat. The battles are boring, the waiting for some some buildings and upgrades are boring and the battles do not come close to representing medieval warefare.The game starts out stating that it is 915AD.The English did not have longbows in the 10th century. The Welsh may have had longbows that early. They certainly did by the time of the Anglo-Norman invasion during the later part of the 11th century. Edward I (kind of England 1272 - 1307is generally regarded as being the one who introduced the use of the longbow into the English forces. There were no knights in England prior to the Norman invasion in 1066. While the Thegns and Ceorls rode to the battle on horseback, they dismounted to fight.I have no idea what composite bows are suppose to represent.Crossbows and longbows have similar ranges and impact (killing power) but longbows have a much higher rate of fire yet in the game, they seem to fire at the same or nearly the same rate. Longbowmen took years to train while crossbowmen took an half an hour at most to instruct, yet in the game you have to pay real money or spend an eternity to make crafts to acquire a crossbowman, while a longbowman is available immediately.Javelin men usually only carried two javelins which were expended as a preliminary to a melee charge. Yet in the game, they have an unlimited number of javelins to throw. The effective range of a Javelin was about 20 meters while the effective range of a longbow and crossbow was in excess of 100 meters, yet in the game they have essentially equal range to the archery units.Spearmen vs mounted knights, this is an absurdity. Until the advent of pikes and halberds, the knights were the kings of the battlefield. Prior to the battle of Sterling Bridge, there was no significant battle in which a knightless force defeated a force with knights. Pikes and halbards were effective against knights but the Pike did not come into common use until the later half of the 13th century and the halberd about 100 years later.Knights should be extremely expensive and rare and virtually industructable. Longbows and crossbows could bring down a knight, but mostly they brought down their horse and knight was trampled by one of his peers or foes.  It took years to train a knight. They started training at the age of seven as a page. After seven years, the page would become a squire and after another seven years the squire might become a knight. An exceptional squire might become a knight as early as age 18. however, not all pages became squires and not all squires became knights.So if the game is to be about England and you want knights, longbowman, and pikes, the it need to be set in the middle 13th century, no the 10th centry.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I've never played a 'Total War' game, so my review of this game doesn't come from having any expectations associated with that name.  I have, however, played a lot of these types of strategy games.  This one is a bit different from the ones I've played (I'll go more into that as I go), but I still found it was one I will keep playing for a while to see where it goes.  I've played 34 hours now and have started over three times because the game does not really walk you through all you need to know as a newcomer to the scene.   After searching through forums, I found most of them outdated, as are some of the complaints in this review forum.  Not everything you read here as pro's/cons are relative anymore.  They've changed up a few things that were people's pet-peeves  (thank goodness).  I can appreciate game designers who do that.  So, take everything you read here with a grain of salt.  Also, this game is not for someone who likes to rush to the top.  It is the slowest-moving game of this type that I have played thus far, but it used to be slower from what I've read in some of the negative reviews here, compared with my experiences.  I have gotten to level 22 in the first day of playing, but that only helps with unlocking more buildings and more objectives (it's easy to level up in this game).  What takes up the most time in this game is the timers on everything. There's timers on construction, deconstruction, food, troops healing, people becoming available to use in your economy buildings, on trees re-growing (although, it used to be worse), etc.  Most put this game in the category of being one that you pick up and play for a few minutes, then come back to a few hours later.  I didn't do that during my time going from level 1-22, so there were some stretches there that were boring.  However, you have to do a lot of battles in order to keep the flow or resources coming in, as well as working on leveling your troops, which is important so that can keep you some-what busy.The things I find the most frustrating about this game are (Con's): 1. There is no real need for the timers.  I don't understand why they exist for everything.  Some games like this require them to make the game competitive with other players, but in this game, you choose when you do any PVP business so that pretty much eliminates the need for timers.  You aren't fighting against the clock because your protection lifts in so many hours, type of thing.2. The materials you need to build or craft anything are astronomical.  It is a bit ridiculous and it is not like they are that easy to come by.  3. To level your castle to level 2 is a pain.  I found a way to do it "easily" but it is still a pain, nonetheless (I peeped on a forum where it was 'theorized' you could build three castles in the first two sections of land you acquire and I did it, but it came with a very steep price and I am not talking about any real money or game currency - I used up a lot of resources to do it, which means a huge loss of time making them back up).  It is imperative that you level your castle to level 2 in order to get anywhere in your duels, which opens the door to you obtaining your third tract of land to build on (I still have yet to do that).   I also have yet to level a castle to level 2, but was thrilled to finally open the door to it being possible now.  It's imperative to do so I can level up my military buildings, which opens the door to being able to level up my troops to two-stars.  That is necessary for dueling, which leads me to the next con on my list...4. Duels are where you finally PVP with other players.  They are just like the battles with AI, so there is no need to defend your castle(s) or village-folk in fear of being plundered, you just have to survive on the battlefield.  I don't know how their match-up system works, but my first attempt at dueling I was set up with someone that had 2 more slots open for troops than I had, which made them way more powerful than I was.  They wiped me out fast.  I do not like their match up system, whatever it is.  It does not seem balanced at all. 5. Also, along with their fail matching system for duels, there does not seem to be a lot of people who play this game.  I have sat and waited a long time before I was matched up with anyone and I attempted three times at different times of the day/night before I finally had any takers.6. Last but not least, I do not like how you are basically left to your own devices on how to figure out how the game works.  You have no clue that it is important to build certain structures next to certain other structures in your villages till you throw a few down on the tarmac where you can finally read about them in their 'menu' that you have to manually open and read.  You also don't have any idea exactly what a troops strengths/weaknesses are till you find your troops strewn about the battlefield dead before you realized it.  There are no tool tips and no up-to-date forums on such things anywhere that I could find, so I am learning by trial and error.  Some folks like that, I prefer more of a balance.  I don't want my hand held, but at the same time I don't like making costly mistakes that set me back several hours.  For the Pro's:1. Quality of graphics: It is a beautiful game for what it is.  It's free to play, but looks better than most.2. Game play:  It doesn't have bugs in it from what I've experienced thus far.3. It's a pain to advance at different points along the game, but that is what keeps me motivated to push forward. 4. There are seasons in the game, with positives and negatives that affect your overall progress in the game and I think that is awesome.  I have only experienced spring thus far, but look forward to seeing the other seasons, as well as the other areas on the map.  I just hope I last that long before I give up, lol.  5.There's no need to pay to play, or to win.  You get plenty of gold bars just playing the game and meeting certain milestones, or finding them in a tomb/cave.  6. The game is not easy.  I like that.  7. This game is expanding my patience thresh-hold. :D  It is not fun waiting for things to finish up, nor is it a lot of fun to grind out levels on my troops, but it is satisfying when it's done and you see/experience the results.  Overall, I am recommending this game despite it's pitfalls.  It's worth trying out, it doesn't cost you a dime....only a few new gray hairs or a sore forehead as you learn by trial and error what is going on.  :P  Enjoy and best of luck to ya.  Hope to see you on the Battlefield.

												Well I do not do reviews often because I do not wish to come off wrong nor be trolled. But this game has made me wish to try.First this to me isn't even worth being on PC. It is pretty much an app game or facebook game. I have played for a bit and grew bored of the similarities to app games harvest times and crap. Also fighting battles on normal and having lord units destroy me over and over and the tiny amounts of exp battles give is useless, granted if you wish to spend real money you can instantly get better units just like in an app/FB game... I wish this game was more like other total war games or even like shogun total war but with knights and your hero could fight in the battle...but alas your leader is a useless image and that's it.  I am not impressed with pay to win games. If i spend money on a game i expect to get cool dlc, new units (that do not break the game or whatever), or cool looking appearances for characters not the ability to instantly buy high tier troops, buildings, cancel out timers or whatever. I would not... No Can not recommend this game to people. If this is your thing fine but its a waste of time when there are so many great free to play games out there. Sorry if you like this game that's fine, this is just how I myself feel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												TLDR:Long waits between actions - spend gold to avoid.Simple, but fun, combat - made un-even by buffs bought with gold before each battle.The units you buy are limited - use (lots of) gold to buy better/more advanced ones.Don't want to do that? Spend vast amounts time/resources instead. Use (some) gold to make it faster. (Oh, you might fail in crafting them, too.)AI frequently uses higher leveled, advanced, units.Competative Multiplayer has all of these problems, made worse by wonky net-code.A fun, casual, strategy-lite game. Or, it would be, were it not spoiled by a steep powercreep in the combat minigame.  If it were just a game designed to be tough, that would be one thing.  Unfortuantely, giving attacking AI with full exp, top tier units and then calling that "challenging" (the term they use for medium difficulty) in the mid-game reveals a cynical attempt to push the player to spend gold (money) to even the field.It doesn't get much better in the 'campaign' section, where you are hampered by long waits for just about every action.Don't be fooled by the intial gameplay; the initially speedy pace slows dramticaly as the tutorials end.  Incidentaly, during the tutorial they give you some gold - which you then have to (as in, the game tells you to and does not progress if you don't) spend that gold to get around the long waits, establishing that this is 'normal' gamplay.Now, this might not be a problem in and of itself - you can just dip in and out, gather your rescources, play a battle or two - log off for an hour or two and then return.  However, this is a more expertly designed freemium game than that.You soon realise that the AI is using the units you don't have access to, generaly further leveled up than your own too.If you want those units, you either have to spend significant amounts of gold up-front or spend lots of time gathering stuff for crafting.  Then, wait a long time for the crafting to happen. Then, do it 5 more times for each item. If you decide that you can wait it out, gather your resources and use them to make a better army, you are attacked by AI periodicly.  If you fail to beat them or pay them off, they take a percentage of your resources when they leave.I'd give this a miss, folks.  Save the money you'd spend on gold - spend it on a game that has been designed and balenced to be entertaining.This is designed to extract the your gold - I mean cash - from you.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												           This is a pay to win game, Honsetly a pay to play. You will be flooded endlessly and will run out of trees vary fast, so you will need to buy Gold to use to trade for wood. You might be able to get by for 2-3 days like this. After that you will be straped again for wood. Wood lets you build dams, and change the ground elevation.  You can only plant with in 2 hexes of a fresh water source.  So a lot of your teritory will be useless to you. Because you can only build off from your castle when it comes to your town, with the exception of mines, woodcuters, and farms. The combat is poor at best, you cant manuver your troops, flank or do any kind of stratigy.  instead the armies march strait at each other. Vary dumbed down. In order to gain a decent reward for the random battles, you will have to face higher difficult enemies. But in order to win once again you have to use Gold to buy advatages in battle. Such as artillery, flaming arrows and so on.    Conclussion: If you like to rebuild your town daily, because of the floods, and have no problem wasting real money on a game, this may be a game for you.
