number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												OK WE GET IT all you poor little -takes a second- people... you wanted something that was already around right? THIS GAME IS NEW, it is not a copy of any other game, it is an industry leader, and I am in <3 as of my current hours in-game I have not paid a penny into it, and the price for the "Gold" is really good- i have decided i will only do the 1 time purchase and the 50 bucks after cause it gives you almost double buying the five dollar when you add up 10 $5 buys- I will save up and stop playing hard if need be lolThank you Total War for creating a game where you don't HAVE to kill everything else on the map- nice change!!!100% Casual game, once you know a few very important thingsblacked out lines are walkthrough of basics I discovered!1) Seasons matteryou start in spring, things grow fast and stone is slow- look at the strange season wheel2) let time be timedon't pay to skip seasons so your little kingdom gets productive again- losing winter's special gift is just as bad as paying for trebuchets "because you can"    i) I have made it a policy to only use gold when i get it and the price is under 4(usually I wait for 1)    ii) Don't use gold to buy resources- it is completely unworth it3) YOU CAN MAKE GOLD WITHOUT PAYINGI really didn't see this in the other positive reviews-    i) it is not a lot but a castle will give you 1-2 every day or 2     ii) also you can make gold with with taverns (have yet to get that- its like a 3% chance or something -shrugs-)    iii) exploring tombs gives you gold, and leveling up gives you 10 gold     iv) there are a few other ways I'm sure4) Please, know the surface and remember gravity!!! TOTALLY MODIFIABLE TERRAIN LEVEL and other things can be manipulated as well (grass/tree type)    i) I was warned, and I laughed when it actually happened- lowering terrain next to a river is stupid if you didn't want the river to flow somewhere new ;-)     ii) lowering 1 plot at the top of a hill with a river can literally flood 30 tiles as it goes down- don't flip out, just build up about 300 coin and wood and stone so you can rebuild if you screw it up- and do this B4 you modify it you must also have at least 1 market (it will kill you to do but it is still a better deal then using up the construction gold) I have 7 markets and only now is it dealable to trade (I will expain markets better shortly)    iii) just because a prospecting zone wants you to lower terrain does not mean you have to- demolish the damned thing if it will require you to kill off trees you don't want to harvest or get rid of other production buildings or roads- they have (so far) not been worth it at all to do so    iv) walls will protect from floods- build them on the sides of your land that border a river if you want to change it's flow- if there is one terrain level not protected it may flood- and it happens FAST    v) beware of fall- but do not avoid it!!!4) Markets, Taverns, Castles, Cattle Farms and the connected land effect    i) connecting land is not simple- you have to think of how much land your taking away from other things (don't build too many roads within 2 plots of water unless you don't mind the cost in future output of food- i didn't risk that in one area and did in another)    ii) Markets, Taverns, and Castles all need to be connected to gain bonuses and upgrades    iii) cattle need to be connected to a market to buy cattle5) you have to have the people to use some of your buildings     i) 10 peasants = 1 crafts man the transfer is not worth it early- just save the craftsmen and use the peasents as often as you can until you are full then trade them in and start raking in the stuff!6) multiplayer is a side-note    i) I chose to do the 3 rank 18 battles and it was not an easy road toward the end, but much more worth it than as 1500 or every resource!!!    ii) it is much more fun knowing someone real is playing against you7) modify troops b4 going into campaign, to match the needs of your victory8) keep learning- I still haven't gotten into differing tree types (it matters) or masters (pains in the asses) or the fact that at first you think that all of the back slots for troops have to be filled by siege so you end up having 3 balistas and doing great for the first 6 days then you hit a all and go WTFM???? then your like "oh" and you feel so unlearned you want to punch 5 holds in the brick wall your desk is in front of9) only pay-to-win-multiplayer and I have not reached the last unlockable place yet so i do not know how that would be to pay forwill update but you have all you need for the early game

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												As far as I can tell most of the negative reviews are gamers expecting this to be like normal Total War games. These players seem completely unfamiliar with the MMORTS genre. It is VERY different than other total war games. I am a huge total war fan and if I was comparing this to other total war games I would give it a terrible rating. But the reality is, for the genre, this is a fantastic game. Few other games I've played in this genre (like Stronghold kingdoms) are as well done as Total War Kingdoms. It has graphics, a fun playstyle, etc. The biggest issue it has are the pay to win elements. I would ultimately recommend the game, but make sure you're looking for what it's offering. If you go into it with low expectations you might be pleasantly surprised. :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												This game is designed for the mobile, microtransaction market and it shows.  There are so many things wrong with this game that I don't know where to begin.Here's the biggest problem I've had so far: I spent hours building up an area and gathering resources in order to pay tribute to a new area.  The original area I built up showed no water source to the north.  However, upon conquering the area to my north a river suddenly appears out of nowhere and floods my original area, wiping out my roads, farms and mines.  I built dams at the source only to have them break several hours later, once again putting the entire region under water.The wait times in this game are ridiculous.   Build a farm and it could take several days before you see any food source appear from said farm.  Build a woodcutter and it will take several days for the land to turn to dirt, for your workers to plant trees and then several more days for the trees to grow so you can chop them down for a meager reward only to repeat the cycle over and over and over.Armies are small compared to other games in the total war series, yet you always seem to face an army that is twice as large as your own.  Your army to limited in size and if you choose to train the wrong type of soldier you're pretty much SOL until you're able to upgrade your baraccks.  However, upgrading is so tedious it'll take days, if not weeks, to get said upgrade.If you're a glutton for punishment and love "paying to win" then this is the game for you.

												My biggest beef with this is that I know the Total War franchise knows how to build games.  It has build countless award winners and pushed it's genre with each new hit (there are exceptions to this rule too ie Rome Total War, latest Attilla expansion). number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												I gave this game a shot for a couple days. While the game looks nice and many key elements are there, they are arranged all wrong.  Here are some my issues with the game. Very little in game information or help.  You can only figure things out through costly trial and error, and I mean cause a flood that destroys your whole town kind of errors. Nitpicky resource collection that requires checking in every 15 minutes for a tiny amounts of reward.  Resources that are essential for growing your economy I should add. Ain't nobody got the time. Wildly divergent difficulty in the battles even when they are rated the same level. The battles themselves are paced horribly.  It takes a minute for them to even start, and when they do you have 5 seconds to issue as many orders as you can, but most have global freaking cooldowns including picking targets for archers! And then you just wait while some sort of confusing magic happens and either you win or you lose.  Impossibly long waits for duels and when you get one its often somebody you already fought recently.  The matchmaking pool is about as deep as a Kardashian.  Crafting menu looks like the controls to some alien spacecraft, in other words indecipherable.  No online resources.  I realize this is not the domain of the developer per se, but it is a bad sign if no one cares enough about this game to even make beginner's guide. Tiny icons.  I play this on a widescreen monitor and I can not imagine playing it on a mobile screen.  I would rather smash my gonads with a hammer than try and click finicky little buttons with my fat fingers.  Hidden virtual dead ends. It is easy to get yourself into a spot where uninformed choices will lead you down a path to obsolescence, either militarily or economically.  Which leads me to my last point.  There is no do over button. There have been about 12 times I have wanted to start over in the last 4 days I have tried this game and I have found the lack of this ability incredibly frustratingAll in all I recommend staying away from this poorly designed mess until they streamline the gameplay.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I will actually give a review that isn't childish hate for hardwork. Or a fluff of fanboyism.This game is free to play. So in reality they need to make some sort of profit off of it to make it worth their time and money, Keep this in mind when you begin playing it.This is a game built to cater to total war fans AND tablet F2P fans. Keep this in mind when you begin playing it.It is designed to let you play for a half hour to an hour. And then set it aside and do something else. When you come back the next day you are rewarded with the things you did the previous day.Hate this model or love it.But this is a well built F2P game.Looks beautiful, has a strategy battle system that is fun. But can become a little annoying because it is very rock, paper, scissors.If you are willing to pay for your enjoyment, then you will be getting the accelerated experience. But it is no different then someone who doesnt. Just comes to you faster. The F2P idea is interesting. But I am not usually a fan. I love creative assembly and appreciate their hardwork on every game they have ever made. Because they do things no one else is willing to try.These games are more rewarding if you are willing to be patient. But I will probably spend between 10 - 20 dollars on the game if it continues to pique my interest.Don't turn away from the game based on the haters. Give it a try, and actually give it some time. If its not your thing then remember that ITS FREEEEEEEE.Thanks for reading, and hope you found this useful. Have a good day!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Loaded up game. Graphics are okay, not fantastic but not bad either. Followed my way through the tutorial - game crashed twice here (tutorial window would lock and not proceed, had to keep restarting the game). Tutorial walks through buildings and terraforming the land, which is kind of neat. Did my first tutorial battle. Stared dumbfounded at my screen as I did literally nothing and the battle was won. Was rewarded gold for winning the battle where I stared down my enemies?Decided to try this battle thing one more time. Ordered one group of archers to attack an enemy. Clicked on the other group of archers to issue the same command, only to discover "attack" is on cooldown. Watched while one group of archers engaged an enemy with deadly arrows, while the other group just sorta sat there and took it like a lil ♥♥♥♥♥. Battle doesn't pause, it's like being forced to watch the train wreak of your troops as they throw themselves forward for slaughter. I won the battle again somehow, must be rigged.This game is a lot of clicking and a lot of waiting. The battles are boring and oversimplified. Everything in the game boils down to spending gold to buy something - boosts, heals, equipment, etc. You know, that Pay2Win model that's so popular on the mobile games market.I'm almost disappointed Creative Assembly went this route. I'm not about to start logging into TW:K every 4 - 8 hours just to harvest wheat. This is not really a Total War game, but I guess a lot of us already know that. /uninstall

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Many excuses for saying such things (especially for people who considers the game a pay-to-win video game), but this one has a small potential of success due to three things:1) Construction - building on a Total War game is the first thing I ever seen, yet it's no wonder due to the fact that also, in Total War Battles: Shogun, you had the ability to build. The building materials, even if require patience for cutting trees in eight damn hours, are very well handled because, in the previous Total War games, you had to pay gold to build a keep or a harbour.2) Battles - these battles still remained as realistic as possible. From splattering swordsmen with a rain of arrows, to the horsemen who bangs through the spearmen, I can't say, but the battle physics are well done.3) Real-time physics - maybe I spelled wrong, but the time of the game is very realistic. Putting seasons and flooding, the game looks more harder to play, and I really like this.Other than the fact that you have to pay gold, the game is remarkably nice and realistic.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Don´t get misled by the name Total War. It has little to do with TW-series when it comes to gameplay.While that being said, it is a nice little game itself. Don´t expect serious challenges though.Main focus is on managing your keeps or villages and their surrounding resources. Has a nice little(!) touch of keeping environment healty, instead of devastating it all for quick resources.Secondary task is to maintain and upgrade a small force of troops to defend your realm and attack NPCs and other Players.This keeps you entertained while you wait for your resources to be harvested and building to be build.Overall:  It is a pretty decent game for lazy hours, but it is far from being as thrilling as real TW-series games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												The only reason I am recommending this game is because it is in beta right now and, despite the problems, it has potential. What problems? Crashing isn't really a problem, because when it does happen you lose nothing and it is very easy to get right back into the game because it is constantly running your scenario somewhere up there in the cloud.-Gold is a problem, not a solution. I have no idea how to get it. It is far easier to spend than get, so don't spend it, but then what is the point in having it.-Resources, in general, are a problem. Everything gets gathered so slowly you can't do anything without spending gold, which, when you do, you run out quickly and then can't do anything because you can't get gold. Either increase the yeild of basic level resource gathering facilities (because it costs way too much to upgrade them) or reduce the time it takes to gather the resources themselves. When you do have renewable resources like cattle and sheep, you can skin them for hides or sell them for 'honour,' but they don't let you keep a couple of them in order to keep the herd alive. Nope, they cut them all up and then you have to buy more cattle with the swiftly dwindling resources you no longer have.-Getting good units is a problem, because whenever you have a single type of unit of quality, like longsword knights, you can't make anymore. You can make other knights, but they cost gold and you can't get gold so you shouldn't spend it. You could craft units, but that takes a ridiculous amount of silver and hides, and as previously noted, resources like silver and hides take absolutely forever to gather in.-I have found that when you harvest something the results of the harvest can change dramatically. I have harvested all my wheat fields at once, but somehow get less per field than if I had done it one at a time. Ostensibly, the reason is that you don't have enough workers to get the full yield out of the wheat fields if harvested all at once. Then why did I sow all the wheat fields at once? And if we are going for reality, why don't we harvest wheat in the autumn and increase the yield to cover the year?-I have gathered wood from deadwood piled up on shore in odd places. The store of the deadwood when you click on it says 100. When you gather the wood though, you get 50 and the deadwood disappears. -Fishing takes longer than harvesting wheat. And fishing should replenish itself if you spread out and slow down your efforts. It does not, however, replenish itself.-Battles can be quite maddening. The good news is you never completely lose a unit unless you delete its training facility  or disband it. Mission difficulty seems to increase with your rank, but your troops don't really keep up because it costs so freaking much of the resources you can't gather fast enough or gold which you don't get just to upgrade training facilities in order to upgrade the unit, which has experience points from battling you can't use unless you do upgrade the training facility. So, as you continue along, you start to lose a lot of battles because your troops just can't keep pace. I'm losing about half now.-the Total War folks do put out codes to redeem in the game for free resources, which points out they are aware of how ridiculous it is to grow/gather your own stuff, but they seem to think that giving them out as 'single-use' codes is a good idea, so that only one person can use the code and then it is no good for whoever else is next. There are millions of gamers out there and I'm not tuned in to Facebook at all hours of the day, so I have given up on getting a code. Ever.That's a lot of complaining, but I do like the game. The persistent timeline is cool, I don't have to be playing for everyone to keep on working. All this having been said they have a lot of good stuff going on in the game and I am eager to see it developed further in its gameplay and in ways to play, like tablets. This is definitely better than the Total War Battles: Shogun.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I'm just five hours in and somehow I think I'll be quadrupling that figure in not too much time. Yeah, there's the fact that you can buy gold for your precious dollars, but you don't have to. There are many ways you can gain gold in the game, namely completing quests, mining, taverns, tracking, exploring tombs and tributes from your people. They bring in little and that not too often. Just enough to support your vanity and let you buy a new hairpiece once in a while.Landscape management is just a blast: getting that damn water to flow where you want to is a challange on its own. Personally, this is my favourite part of the game, and the most engaging. Battles offer just enough depth to keep them fresh, but they're also a reminder that this game was made for mobile. In terms of tactics, there isn't very much going on here.All in all I'd recommend you give this game a try if you've got some time on your hands. Preferrably on your phone, because for a mobile game, it's gorgeous.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												This seems like the type of abomination they'd put out because the executives and shareholders at sega demanded a game for the IOS platform. My best guess is that they put a small portion of the dev team to work on this because the larger portion is working on Total War: Warhammer and Total War: Arena, which may explain the drastic shift in gameplay type and why it differs so much from the Total War franchise in general.Here is a basic rundown of why it's terrible and should be reworked to the point where it is either almost an entirely different game, or just dropped entirely.1.) Building-Obviously meant for mobile devices, the building system makes getting any visible progress tedious and boring until you start dropping good portions of money on it. 2.) The main reason I even installed this- the combat- is slow and unintuitive. Don't expect to be making any decisive military tactics here, the only possible strategy is to walk forward until the AI get within range to attack.You are basically an observer in the conflict, which is almost painfully terrible in itself. I haven't played long enough to get to the so called "Multiplayer" and I don't intend to.This game has literally no saving graces, pro's, or anything gameplay wise atleast. The graphics aren't great for PC, but it's clear they were shooting for a mobile audience here too.Avoid this game and don't give it any money, for at the moment, it deserves none.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												This shouldn't even be a game with a 'Total War' title, or even a game at all. Give it a try, but you'll be disappointed.All-in-all, this isn't a brand-spanking new installment in the Total War franchise. Oh no no. It's just a ridiculously 'farmy' mobile title that claims to be something fresh. The graphics are actually quite nice and crisp, but it's useless having a visually decent game when there is little to nothing of interest to actually do.If you're a person that enjoys waiting 10 minutes to harvest some wheat, or a minute to build a house, you'll love this game. Alternatively you can pay-up some real money to instantly complete these 'jobs'. Once you've waited for minutes on end to complete some useless stuff, now you can go fight......on a three-laned 'Plants vs Zombies'-styled battle, where your only input is pressing a button at the right time.Seriously, just don't spend your precious time on this 'game'.1/10 (1 point for good art style and graphics)

												Well, I have read other reviews, played this game for few hours. This game is not really bad actually. Let's say about it pros and cons:Good:_Graphic is fine, work well on old/slow PC._It's free... so heck.yeah.Bad:_Take time to wait (waiting is fine with me)_No mini map. You know, the game is pretty wide, but no map == really..._Pay to not waiting._So hard to earn gold, I mean nearly impossible to earn it beside doing the quest._The amount of resources collected is not really much._Boring combat. Limitted number of units. Seriously, only 3 lines fighting. *sighSo anyway, this game is pretty fine to me. You know, go in game, do stuff, then exit to do your own stuff then come back. They dont put the knife to your neck and demand us to buy gold.However, some people are right, this is better to be a mobile phone game. It looks like Class of Clans (waiting and waiting) combined with Civilization (hexagon area).

												Well I do not do reviews often because I do not wish to come off wrong nor be trolled. But this game has made me wish to try.First this to me isn't even worth being on PC. It is pretty much an app game or facebook game. I have played for a bit and grew bored of the similarities to app games harvest times and crap. I would not... No Can not recommend this game to people. If this is your thing fine but its a waste of time when there are so many great free to play games out there. Sorry if you like this game that's fine, this is just how I myself feel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Edit after over 2 months: After over 2 MONTHS since my previous review, I figure that this game should be a lot better. Plenty of time to patch and improve things, right? WRONG! What do I see? The exact same, pay-to-win garbage. I was hoping that this wouldn't happen, but it did. This game is cashing in on the (fairly) good name of Total War. I am incredibly dissapointed, and will likely not play again.THE REVIEW BELOW IS OUTDATED:As a fairly experienced Total War player, I can say that this game still has some of the spirit of the other  games in the franchise. Keep in mind, though, that I am recommending this as a free-to-play mobile game. Do not expect the same amount of depth as other Total War games. Combat:For a game of this type, the combat is amazingly good. For once, a mobile game allows you to have some control over your men (unlike letting them "roam free" as in similar games).Graphics:So far, so good. I really like the overall atmosphere of the game. The lighting, textures, and objects all look crisp and good.Pay-To-Win:In the tutorial, battles were fast, building built in minutes. After the tutorial, it's a different story. I was quickly slammed with a 9 hour wait time. Advice for CA:Lower the building and clearing times in the beginning of the game. The jump is just too large after the tutorial. Also, try to lower the building restrictions.Should You Play?I think that this game has enough potential to give a reason to play. Although, to go from "having potential" to "great", changes have to be made. It is in Beta right now, so I am confident that CA will make the changes necessary for this to be a great game. Try it out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												This may be the first positive review...!In short, it's engaging, dynamic, fairly effortless and solidly immersive. A game to snack into from time to time.It's Civilization meets Travian meets Total War - and done fairly well.To be clear, the idea of this game is to be a cross-platform thing you can dip in and out of: Battles are tres petit and your actions generally take several minutes to several hours to complete on the campaign map. With that in mind, it's not a typical Total War game to sit at for 18 hours solid conquering. If you come in  with that expectation, you're going to cry.Instead it's like so many similar time-based multiplayer online games (Travian, Tribal Wars, Clash of Clans - there may be haters, but they're good fun with work colleagues when you don't have a lot of time on hand). Only difference is that this is so far more immersive and much more fun. Battles are suitably tactical and challenging and deliver a quick buzz (handy for coursework breaks).So far, the campaign map's relatively well paced and there are plenty of new glossy things getting unlocked to keep me interested. It's a massive hex map that you unlock new theatres by defeating the army there - in each one it's a mix of terra-forming and town-building (lots and lots of little houses), trying to twist streams where you want them to make life more fertile and sustainably milk the land. It was an emphasis I wasn't expecting, but a lot of fun.I haven't felt at a disadvantage by not buying any things yet either.Negatives... Haven't found any significant ones yet, other than it's eating too much of my productivity.Give it a go - just don't expect MTW3.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I have played over 500 hrs (or so Steam says; it must include time the compurter is active even though I am not).The game is okay, but not great. Now that I have occuppied all six territories, I am not sure what would motivate me to play again. There is not much variation in the game; gather resources, update buildings and/or units then go fight a couple of battles, then repeat. The battles are boring, the waiting for some some buildings and upgrades are boring and the battles do not come close to representing medieval warefare.The game starts out stating that it is 915AD.The English did not have longbows in the 10th century. The Welsh may have had longbows that early. They certainly did by the time of the Anglo-Norman invasion during the later part of the 11th century. Edward I (kind of England 1272 - 1307is generally regarded as being the one who introduced the use of the longbow into the English forces. There were no knights in England prior to the Norman invasion in 1066. While the Thegns and Ceorls rode to the battle on horseback, they dismounted to fight.I have no idea what composite bows are suppose to represent.Crossbows and longbows have similar ranges and impact (killing power) but longbows have a much higher rate of fire yet in the game, they seem to fire at the same or nearly the same rate. Longbowmen took years to train while crossbowmen took an half an hour at most to instruct, yet in the game you have to pay real money or spend an eternity to make crafts to acquire a crossbowman, while a longbowman is available immediately.Javelin men usually only carried two javelins which were expended as a preliminary to a melee charge. Yet in the game, they have an unlimited number of javelins to throw. The effective range of a Javelin was about 20 meters while the effective range of a longbow and crossbow was in excess of 100 meters, yet in the game they have essentially equal range to the archery units.Spearmen vs mounted knights, this is an absurdity. Until the advent of pikes and halberds, the knights were the kings of the battlefield. Prior to the battle of Sterling Bridge, there was no significant battle in which a knightless force defeated a force with knights. Pikes and halbards were effective against knights but the Pike did not come into common use until the later half of the 13th century and the halberd about 100 years later.Knights should be extremely expensive and rare and virtually industructable. Longbows and crossbows could bring down a knight, but mostly they brought down their horse and knight was trampled by one of his peers or foes.  It took years to train a knight. They started training at the age of seven as a page. After seven years, the page would become a squire and after another seven years the squire might become a knight. An exceptional squire might become a knight as early as age 18. however, not all pages became squires and not all squires became knights.So if the game is to be about England and you want knights, longbowman, and pikes, the it need to be set in the middle 13th century, no the 10th centry.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												I do not recommend this game for TW fans as it is a very different game than the rest of the TW series. Furthermore, this game is intended firstly to make money without any real marketing strategy. The basic gameplay is directly linked to the purchase of gold with real money. Otherwise the game is very slow. An example: my character is level 24 and I've done (almost) all possible developments after 20 hours of gaming. To go further, I need to have a castle level 2, which means 1500 stones and 1500 silver. If you don't speed up the game using gold (i.e. real money), you're making around 100 silver every 2 hours. Same with stones... So, just to get this damn castle to level 2, I have to wait around 30 hours!  The basic gameplay should be the same, gold or not. I have no problem with paying some money to the developers. Gold should allow to improve the gameplay, not to replace it. But in this game, if you don't use gold, there is no gameplay and the game is just a mock up version of old strategy games I played in the 80's on my first computers. The combat system is obviously made for tablets, not for PC. It is dull, with very little strategy and tactical choices (the biggest stick wins). The only interest I found in this game is the map and the way you can change it. There is a good idea there but it's a pity: no action (except economics and construction) is taken on the map... As if the devs had never played Stronghold or Civ. Strange!

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												This game is designed for the mobile, microtransaction market and it shows.  There are so many things wrong with this game that I don't know where to begin.Here's the biggest problem I've had so far: I spent hours building up an area and gathering resources in order to pay tribute to a new area.  The original area I built up showed no water source to the north.  However, upon conquering the area to my north a river suddenly appears out of nowhere and floods my original area, wiping out my roads, farms and mines.  I built dams at the source only to have them break several hours later, once again putting the entire region under water.The wait times in this game are ridiculous.   Build a farm and it could take several days before you see any food source appear from said farm.  Build a woodcutter and it will take several days for the land to turn to dirt, for your workers to plant trees and then several more days for the trees to grow so you can chop them down for a meager reward only to repeat the cycle over and over and over.Armies are small compared to other games in the total war series, yet you always seem to face an army that is twice as large as your own.  Your army to limited in size and if you choose to train the wrong type of soldier you're pretty much SOL until you're able to upgrade your baraccks.  However, upgrading is so tedious it'll take days, if not weeks, to get said upgrade.If you're a glutton for punishment and love "paying to win" then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												A lot of fun. Really wish there was a detailed tutoiral somewhere. I messed up my initial position because I did not quite get the synergy effects from nearby buildings.  Also caused a lot of accidental floods, etc. but it's still a whole lot of fun.  Played for 12 hours without buying any gold from market. Obviously that's the way to get the best out of your troops via gear. but made it to level 20 lord with no problems other than building and terrain mistakes.   And some tactics errors in battles. but it is a very fun medieval sim.I like that the classic problems of resource management are factors.  flooding, lack of funds, deforestation, really enjpying the challenges, and watching and managing the little towns that are built.I think it is the right mix between tactics and a little bit of strategy, plus kingdom management.  And the battles have the right level of command from the rear feel. A few simple commands, give your tropps the right formations, and trust to equipment and luck.Even if the troops lose battles, they learn and get better.  And armies can fight on without getting wiped out completely,  lessons learned, go at it again, with better tactics.Learning the battles and warfare as I go is a nice progression, building skills, makes it a semi RP game at a very low level.   And the graphics are really good and have a lot of flavor.  But not too intensive.  Playing from dialup on an old laptop, it's not a problem, unlike many other games on steam.Great job, developers.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												Good game so far as I've played.  Combines strategic resource production and simple battle tactics for a fun game you can pick up and leave be as time permits.  There are (as always) some elements where those willing to spend money will be sligtly ahead of the rest that are wont, but not so much as to make the game hard or frustrating to play.   DO NOT expect this game to be like a normal Total War game.  But it's not suppose to be.  Normal Total War games require pretty in-depth planning and careful execution, I can average 30-45 minutes per turn not to mention the 45min+ battles.  This takes a simplified approach to the game, like I said above it allows you to pick it up play for 5 minutes and leave it be.  Its not bad by any means, just don't expect a normal Total War game.All in all I'd say 8/10 and considering it's free, I would highly recomend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This game offers a two mode game similar to Campaign and Battle in Total war, but remade as "mini-town building" and "mini-tactical battles". Think a slow moving yet somewhat compact version of a Total War with other feature in mind. I find myself doing more landscaping and "town planning" by hex buildings -  This aspect is quite new but interesting because it gives something to explore for new players who come sign-up (although from this point, maybe people decide whether the game is their style or really hate how it does not feel like Total War).For battles, don't expect to see huge army stacks in epic battle. But quick skirmish with smaller "army groups" but with upgradeable and persistent soldier units. If you like a bit of RPG-element of improving stats and selecting which one to focus (although, there are not too many to worry about).If you dislike the trend of "freemium" games nowadays by any type and aspect, please beware of the "time limiter" of progress of both the town building and unit management for battles (the replinishment). While gold can still be acquired in game, it is not plenty and if you are not the waiting type, you may have to choose between paying real-life money to speed things up.So, adjust your expectation, think more like a "small-town army" manager game - with "mobile-style freemium" limits to action. If you can do this, then Total War Battles: Kingdom is a quick-fix game you can have on computer and take with you if you so feel attached to your hex town and warbands of upgradable units. It can still be likeable depending on your initial expectation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												I've never played a 'Total War' game, so my review of this game doesn't come from having any expectations associated with that name.  I have, however, played a lot of these types of strategy games.  This one is a bit different from the ones I've played (I'll go more into that as I go), but I still found it was one I will keep playing for a while to see where it goes.  I've played 34 hours now and have started over three times because the game does not really walk you through all you need to know as a newcomer to the scene.   After searching through forums, I found most of them outdated, as are some of the complaints in this review forum.  Not everything you read here as pro's/cons are relative anymore.  They've changed up a few things that were people's pet-peeves  (thank goodness).  I can appreciate game designers who do that.  So, take everything you read here with a grain of salt.  Also, this game is not for someone who likes to rush to the top.  It is the slowest-moving game of this type that I have played thus far, but it used to be slower from what I've read in some of the negative reviews here, compared with my experiences.  I have gotten to level 22 in the first day of playing, but that only helps with unlocking more buildings and more objectives (it's easy to level up in this game).  What takes up the most time in this game is the timers on everything. There's timers on construction, deconstruction, food, troops healing, people becoming available to use in your economy buildings, on trees re-growing (although, it used to be worse), etc.  Most put this game in the category of being one that you pick up and play for a few minutes, then come back to a few hours later.  I didn't do that during my time going from level 1-22, so there were some stretches there that were boring.  However, you have to do a lot of battles in order to keep the flow or resources coming in, as well as working on leveling your troops, which is important so that can keep you some-what busy.The things I find the most frustrating about this game are (Con's): 1. There is no real need for the timers.  I don't understand why they exist for everything.  Some games like this require them to make the game competitive with other players, but in this game, you choose when you do any PVP business so that pretty much eliminates the need for timers.  You aren't fighting against the clock because your protection lifts in so many hours, type of thing.2. The materials you need to build or craft anything are astronomical.  It is a bit ridiculous and it is not like they are that easy to come by.  3. To level your castle to level 2 is a pain.  I found a way to do it "easily" but it is still a pain, nonetheless (I peeped on a forum where it was 'theorized' you could build three castles in the first two sections of land you acquire and I did it, but it came with a very steep price and I am not talking about any real money or game currency - I used up a lot of resources to do it, which means a huge loss of time making them back up).  It is imperative that you level your castle to level 2 in order to get anywhere in your duels, which opens the door to you obtaining your third tract of land to build on (I still have yet to do that).   I also have yet to level a castle to level 2, but was thrilled to finally open the door to it being possible now.  It's imperative to do so I can level up my military buildings, which opens the door to being able to level up my troops to two-stars.  That is necessary for dueling, which leads me to the next con on my list...4. Duels are where you finally PVP with other players.  They are just like the battles with AI, so there is no need to defend your castle(s) or village-folk in fear of being plundered, you just have to survive on the battlefield.  I don't know how their match-up system works, but my first attempt at dueling I was set up with someone that had 2 more slots open for troops than I had, which made them way more powerful than I was.  They wiped me out fast.  I do not like their match up system, whatever it is.  It does not seem balanced at all. 5. Also, along with their fail matching system for duels, there does not seem to be a lot of people who play this game.  I have sat and waited a long time before I was matched up with anyone and I attempted three times at different times of the day/night before I finally had any takers.6. Last but not least, I do not like how you are basically left to your own devices on how to figure out how the game works.  You have no clue that it is important to build certain structures next to certain other structures in your villages till you throw a few down on the tarmac where you can finally read about them in their 'menu' that you have to manually open and read.  You also don't have any idea exactly what a troops strengths/weaknesses are till you find your troops strewn about the battlefield dead before you realized it.  There are no tool tips and no up-to-date forums on such things anywhere that I could find, so I am learning by trial and error.  Some folks like that, I prefer more of a balance.  I don't want my hand held, but at the same time I don't like making costly mistakes that set me back several hours.  For the Pro's:1. Quality of graphics: It is a beautiful game for what it is.  It's free to play, but looks better than most.2. Game play:  It doesn't have bugs in it from what I've experienced thus far.3. It's a pain to advance at different points along the game, but that is what keeps me motivated to push forward. 4. There are seasons in the game, with positives and negatives that affect your overall progress in the game and I think that is awesome.  I have only experienced spring thus far, but look forward to seeing the other seasons, as well as the other areas on the map.  I just hope I last that long before I give up, lol.  5.There's no need to pay to play, or to win.  You get plenty of gold bars just playing the game and meeting certain milestones, or finding them in a tomb/cave.  6. The game is not easy.  I like that.  7. This game is expanding my patience thresh-hold. :D  It is not fun waiting for things to finish up, nor is it a lot of fun to grind out levels on my troops, but it is satisfying when it's done and you see/experience the results.  Overall, I am recommending this game despite it's pitfalls.  It's worth trying out, it doesn't cost you a dime....only a few new gray hairs or a sore forehead as you learn by trial and error what is going on.  :P  Enjoy and best of luck to ya.  Hope to see you on the Battlefield.

Posted: May 14, 2015
												This shouldn't even be a game with a 'Total War' title, or even a game at all. Give it a try, but you'll be disappointed.All-in-all, this isn't a brand-spanking new installment in the Total War franchise. Oh no no. It's just a ridiculously 'farmy' mobile title that claims to be something fresh. The graphics are actually quite nice and crisp, but it's useless having a visually decent game when there is little to nothing of interest to actually do.If you're a person that enjoys waiting 10 minutes to harvest some wheat, or a minute to build a house, you'll love this game. Alternatively you can pay-up some real money to instantly complete these 'jobs'. Once you've waited for minutes on end to complete some useless stuff, now you can go fight......on a three-laned 'Plants vs Zombies'-styled battle, where your only input is pressing a button at the right time.Seriously, just don't spend your precious time on this 'game'.1/10 (1 point for good art style and graphics)

												Well I do not do reviews often because I do not wish to come off wrong nor be trolled. But this game has made me wish to try.First this to me isn't even worth being on PC. It is pretty much an app game or facebook game. I have played for a bit and grew bored of the similarities to app games harvest times and crap. Also fighting battles on normal and having lord units destroy me over and over and the tiny amounts of exp battles give is useless, granted if you wish to spend real money you can instantly get better units just like in an app/FB game... I wish this game was more like other total war games or even like shogun total war but with knights and your hero could fight in the battle...but alas your leader is a useless image and that's it.  I am not impressed with pay to win games. If i spend money on a game i expect to get cool dlc, new units (that do not break the game or whatever), or cool looking appearances for characters not the ability to instantly buy high tier troops, buildings, cancel out timers or whatever. I would not... No Can not recommend this game to people. If this is your thing fine but its a waste of time when there are so many great free to play games out there. Sorry if you like this game that's fine, this is just how I myself feel.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Spending a bit more than eight hours on this might have been a serious mistake. At first, when I enlisted on participating in the beta, I was hoping that this might be a nice game (knowing the praise that the franchise gets from all it's fans) although I had played very little from other Total War games. After starting up the game and playing around with the options, I entered the tutorial. As previous reviewers have mentioned, there you are taught how to spend as much money as possible, to be only able to skip the ridiculous and tedious amounts of time you have to wait for the construction and completion of simple tasks. So, after I thought about it, I figured out why they decided to implement this peculiar feature: the game was designed for a mobile phone. The weird and unrealistic battle mechanics, the seemingly endless building time and the interface itself just shouted it out. But then came the simple question: Why did they release this for the PC? At least if they had it just for mobile devices, maybe they would have had the understanding of the community. Although this game is an abomination, I think that the developers will redeem themselves and put this setback aside, continuing to release good and ambitious titles, worthy of our money and respect.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Fan of the Total War Series, have most all the titles.Fan of Paradox, have most of their titles (no they didn't make this, yes it ties in read on):This is not a "grand strategy game", it should not be approached as a "Total War" game.It is, however, a good game. In fact, the map is simply beautiful - it feels like a sand box.It is a Total War BATTLES game, for those familiar with the other title.And, to be fair, it is massively improved over the first Battles game. Yes, it is a mobile game, but to be fair it is one of the most well balanced micro-transaction games (if not the most)...that I have ever seen.And I'm the guy who ALWAYS quits micro-transcation games (and LOVES the South Park Episode about them). But tough this one out, and if you do spend cash I know you all remember when we had to shell out $5 a month for Runescape - I don't play WoW but it is not free. Look at it that way, again - if you do spend.ALSO IT DOES NOT TAKE 8 HOURS TO GET RESOURCES! THE ONE OPTION THAT DOES IS A WASTE OF TIME, DO NOT CLICK IT.It takes about 20 minutes, usually. Which is actually short for a micro-trans game.

												If like me you don't have the time or patience to sit for hours and play a game, and if like me you like games like Age of Empires, this is a pretty good game. content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Loaded up game. Graphics are okay, not fantastic but not bad either. Followed my way through the tutorial - game crashed twice here (tutorial window would lock and not proceed, had to keep restarting the game). Tutorial walks through buildings and terraforming the land, which is kind of neat. Did my first tutorial battle. Stared dumbfounded at my screen as I did literally nothing and the battle was won. Was rewarded gold for winning the battle where I stared down my enemies?Decided to try this battle thing one more time. Ordered one group of archers to attack an enemy. Clicked on the other group of archers to issue the same command, only to discover "attack" is on cooldown. Watched while one group of archers engaged an enemy with deadly arrows, while the other group just sorta sat there and took it like a lil ♥♥♥♥♥. Battle doesn't pause, it's like being forced to watch the train wreak of your troops as they throw themselves forward for slaughter. I won the battle again somehow, must be rigged.This game is a lot of clicking and a lot of waiting. The battles are boring and oversimplified. Everything in the game boils down to spending gold to buy something - boosts, heals, equipment, etc. You know, that Pay2Win model that's so popular on the mobile games market.I'm almost disappointed Creative Assembly went this route. I'm not about to start logging into TW:K every 4 - 8 hours just to harvest wheat. This is not really a Total War game, but I guess a lot of us already know that. /uninstall

												Quite enjoying it though I wish it would let me restart cause there are quite a lot of lessons I have learned from playing the game, that I would like to restart and redo all over again. For example I built my second city on high ground then discovered I could not get a road to it, so I had to demolish it and rebuild. Building soldiers no point in upgrading them at early stage rather just buy better soldiers, better soldiers are ultimately cheaper and will win e.g. upgrade soldiers gives 1 point in defence, as you unlock better units, that unit could end up offering an extra 25 points, each point you earn from experience is more expensive, so to earn 25 point equivalent is not going to happen, can also upgrade soldiers, armour, weapons etc.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												1.7 hours played, and 1.7 hours is all I need to make a decision.Sadly, it seems that Creative Assembly has been in bed with SEGA too long to the point where everything becomes a micro transaction or a DLC cut from what should've been in the original game. This is a review for Kingdoms, so I digress.Total War Battles: KINGDOM does not appear to be anything more than Creative Assembly's attempt at Game of War, or Clash of Clans (although this could viewed as an insult to these games). While their attempt is noble, these types of games are exclusive to mobile devices for a reason; I could play a much more fleshed out strategy game on my PC. If I want to play a game with busy work, it will be on my phone when I am waiting in between classes.Creative Assembly revolutionized real time/turn based strategy gaming with the Total War franchise. My advice would be to stick to your niche and let the iOS devs stay in theirs.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												This may be the first positive review...!In short, it's engaging, dynamic, fairly effortless and solidly immersive. A game to snack into from time to time.It's Civilization meets Travian meets Total War - and done fairly well.To be clear, the idea of this game is to be a cross-platform thing you can dip in and out of: Battles are tres petit and your actions generally take several minutes to several hours to complete on the campaign map. With that in mind, it's not a typical Total War game to sit at for 18 hours solid conquering. If you come in  with that expectation, you're going to cry.Instead it's like so many similar time-based multiplayer online games (Travian, Tribal Wars, Clash of Clans - there may be haters, but they're good fun with work colleagues when you don't have a lot of time on hand). Only difference is that this is so far more immersive and much more fun. Battles are suitably tactical and challenging and deliver a quick buzz (handy for coursework breaks).So far, the campaign map's relatively well paced and there are plenty of new glossy things getting unlocked to keep me interested. It's a massive hex map that you unlock new theatres by defeating the army there - in each one it's a mix of terra-forming and town-building (lots and lots of little houses), trying to twist streams where you want them to make life more fertile and sustainably milk the land. It was an emphasis I wasn't expecting, but a lot of fun.I haven't felt at a disadvantage by not buying any things yet either.Negatives... Haven't found any significant ones yet, other than it's eating too much of my productivity.Give it a go - just don't expect MTW3.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												OK WE GET IT all you poor little -takes a second- people... you wanted something that was already around right? THIS GAME IS NEW, it is not a copy of any other game, it is an industry leader, and I am in <3 as of my current hours in-game I have not paid a penny into it, and the price for the "Gold" is really good- i have decided i will only do the 1 time purchase and the 50 bucks after cause it gives you almost double buying the five dollar when you add up 10 $5 buys- I will save up and stop playing hard if need be lolThank you Total War for creating a game where you don't HAVE to kill everything else on the map- nice change!!!100% Casual game, once you know a few very important thingsblacked out lines are walkthrough of basics I discovered!1) Seasons matteryou start in spring, things grow fast and stone is slow- look at the strange season wheel2) let time be timedon't pay to skip seasons so your little kingdom gets productive again- losing winter's special gift is just as bad as paying for trebuchets "because you can"    i) I have made it a policy to only use gold when i get it and the price is under 4(usually I wait for 1)    ii) Don't use gold to buy resources- it is completely unworth it3) YOU CAN MAKE GOLD WITHOUT PAYINGI really didn't see this in the other positive reviews-    i) it is not a lot but a castle will give you 1-2 every day or 2     ii) also you can make gold with with taverns (have yet to get that- its like a 3% chance or something -shrugs-)    iii) exploring tombs gives you gold, and leveling up gives you 10 gold     iv) there are a few other ways I'm sure4) Please, know the surface and remember gravity!!! TOTALLY MODIFIABLE TERRAIN LEVEL and other things can be manipulated as well (grass/tree type)    i) I was warned, and I laughed when it actually happened- lowering terrain next to a river is stupid if you didn't want the river to flow somewhere new ;-)     ii) lowering 1 plot at the top of a hill with a river can literally flood 30 tiles as it goes down- don't flip out, just build up about 300 coin and wood and stone so you can rebuild if you screw it up- and do this B4 you modify it you must also have at least 1 market (it will kill you to do but it is still a better deal then using up the construction gold) I have 7 markets and only now is it dealable to trade (I will expain markets better shortly)    iii) just because a prospecting zone wants you to lower terrain does not mean you have to- demolish the damned thing if it will require you to kill off trees you don't want to harvest or get rid of other production buildings or roads- they have (so far) not been worth it at all to do so    iv) walls will protect from floods- build them on the sides of your land that border a river if you want to change it's flow- if there is one terrain level not protected it may flood- and it happens FAST    v) beware of fall- but do not avoid it!!!4) Markets, Taverns, Castles, Cattle Farms and the connected land effect    i) connecting land is not simple- you have to think of how much land your taking away from other things (don't build too many roads within 2 plots of water unless you don't mind the cost in future output of food- i didn't risk that in one area and did in another)    ii) Markets, Taverns, and Castles all need to be connected to gain bonuses and upgrades    iii) cattle need to be connected to a market to buy cattle5) you have to have the people to use some of your buildings     i) 10 peasants = 1 crafts man the transfer is not worth it early- just save the craftsmen and use the peasents as often as you can until you are full then trade them in and start raking in the stuff!6) multiplayer is a side-note    i) I chose to do the 3 rank 18 battles and it was not an easy road toward the end, but much more worth it than as 1500 or every resource!!!    ii) it is much more fun knowing someone real is playing against you7) modify troops b4 going into campaign, to match the needs of your victory8) keep learning- I still haven't gotten into differing tree types (it matters) or masters (pains in the asses) or the fact that at first you think that all of the back slots for troops have to be filled by siege so you end up having 3 balistas and doing great for the first 6 days then you hit a all and go WTFM???? then your like "oh" and you feel so unlearned you want to punch 5 holds in the brick wall your desk is in front of9) only pay-to-win-multiplayer and I have not reached the last unlockable place yet so i do not know how that would be to pay forwill update but you have all you need for the early game

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												           This is a pay to win game, Honsetly a pay to play. You will be flooded endlessly and will run out of trees vary fast, so you will need to buy Gold to use to trade for wood. You might be able to get by for 2-3 days like this. After that you will be straped again for wood. Wood lets you build dams, and change the ground elevation.  You can only plant with in 2 hexes of a fresh water source.  So a lot of your teritory will be useless to you. Because you can only build off from your castle when it comes to your town, with the exception of mines, woodcuters, and farms. The combat is poor at best, you cant manuver your troops, flank or do any kind of stratigy.  instead the armies march strait at each other. Vary dumbed down. In order to gain a decent reward for the random battles, you will have to face higher difficult enemies. But in order to win once again you have to use Gold to buy advatages in battle. Such as artillery, flaming arrows and so on.    Conclussion: If you like to rebuild your town daily, because of the floods, and have no problem wasting real money on a game, this may be a game for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Spending a bit more than eight hours on this might have been a serious mistake. At first, when I enlisted on participating in the beta, I was hoping that this might be a nice game (knowing the praise that the franchise gets from all it's fans) although I had played very little from other Total War games. After starting up the game and playing around with the options, I entered the tutorial. As previous reviewers have mentioned, there you are taught how to spend as much money as possible, to be only able to skip the ridiculous and tedious amounts of time you have to wait for the construction and completion of simple tasks. So, after I thought about it, I figured out why they decided to implement this peculiar feature: the game was designed for a mobile phone. The weird and unrealistic battle mechanics, the seemingly endless building time and the interface itself just shouted it out. But then came the simple question: Why did they release this for the PC? At least if they had it just for mobile devices, maybe they would have had the understanding of the community. Although this game is an abomination, I think that the developers will redeem themselves and put this setback aside, continuing to release good and ambitious titles, worthy of our money and respect.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I think this game has a lot of potential. The game has a great opening and a good tutorial. I also like how the troops control during combat. It has a very smooth feeling and appears to be a rather good game considering it is 2 days old. There are a few issues however. First is the teraforming issue. I like how you can change the altitude of the ground to help prevent floods or to create rivers. It is also cool that only certain buildings can be built in certain elevations. (Like how roads can only be built on medium height. it doesn't make sense for a road to go right over a mountain and then right back down) Now the issue I have is that when you want to raise something to be one higher than the area around the tile you can do that. BUT if you want to raise it 2 times you must raise all the other tiles around it. and if one of those tiles can't be raised you either have to raise all the tiles around it OR deal with the lower land and the inability to build something. So if I am at the top of the map and need to raise a piece of ground to medium for a road I have to first raise the tile I want to low, then the 3 below it to low then the nine below those to low. If you want to alter one tile you may have to raise 20 or 30 tiles. It is crazy. What should happen is that if I raise a tile from low to medium and the ground around it is very low it costs double and it just makes the ground look like a little hill on that tile.The other issue is camera control. Just let me use WASD for camera movement. I don't to have to click and drag. It is alright for a mouse but what about anyone using a touch pad. It can take 30 seconds to a minute just to go from one side of the map to another just on the small starting one. Also, who likes a stagnate map? You are building a kingdom. Have people training in the barracks. Have a blacksmith hammering. people walking on the roads. If no one walks on them, what is the point?The game itself is fun. Good combat aspects as well as animation and building design. I think for a new game it is doing alright but there is a lot of progress to be made.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												I will actually give a review that isn't childish hate for hardwork. Or a fluff of fanboyism.This game is free to play. So in reality they need to make some sort of profit off of it to make it worth their time and money, Keep this in mind when you begin playing it.This is a game built to cater to total war fans AND tablet F2P fans. Keep this in mind when you begin playing it.It is designed to let you play for a half hour to an hour. And then set it aside and do something else. When you come back the next day you are rewarded with the things you did the previous day.Hate this model or love it.But this is a well built F2P game.Looks beautiful, has a strategy battle system that is fun. But can become a little annoying because it is very rock, paper, scissors.If you are willing to pay for your enjoyment, then you will be getting the accelerated experience. But it is no different then someone who doesnt. Just comes to you faster. The F2P idea is interesting. But I am not usually a fan. I love creative assembly and appreciate their hardwork on every game they have ever made. Because they do things no one else is willing to try.These games are more rewarding if you are willing to be patient. But I will probably spend between 10 - 20 dollars on the game if it continues to pique my interest.Don't turn away from the game based on the haters. Give it a try, and actually give it some time. If its not your thing then remember that ITS FREEEEEEEE.Thanks for reading, and hope you found this useful. Have a good day!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												So much hate on this game - I feel its misplaced.OK - this is not a standard Total War PC game.  It is a mobile FTP kingdom building game with appointment mechanics.  Yes there are 8 hr cooldowns, but you're not supposed to sit and watch the cooldown.  You can use gold or you can come back later.  Its designed for short 5-10 min play sessions.  Obv this doesn't sit well on PC as its not what we're used to.  You can spend money to skip grind, but you don't gain utility value from spending so its not pay-to-win.  However if you spend as much as you'd be prepared to on a standard PC game, you will probably be able to compete with higher ranks, but only if you spend strategically.  I've played 9 hrs (FOR FREE) - it's got some interesting base building strategy, like balancing expansion with managing water levels.  You do have to wait to re-heal troops between fights which can mean you only have 1 fight per session, but if you overwhelm opposition you can get away with zero casualties and thus fight again straightaway.   Battles are more like a puzzle game than a traditional Total War fight, but still retains elements of setting up your formation to outwit opponent and making strategic moves mid game to counter act opponent's moves.Biggest failing is that the game doesn't pit you against real opponents soon enough.  After 9 hrs I still haven't fought a real person - I assume this is coming!?!?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												1.7 hours played, and 1.7 hours is all I need to make a decision.Sadly, it seems that Creative Assembly has been in bed with SEGA too long to the point where everything becomes a micro transaction or a DLC cut from what should've been in the original game. This is a review for Kingdoms, so I digress.Total War Battles: KINGDOM does not appear to be anything more than Creative Assembly's attempt at Game of War, or Clash of Clans (although this could viewed as an insult to these games). While their attempt is noble, these types of games are exclusive to mobile devices for a reason; I could play a much more fleshed out strategy game on my PC. If I want to play a game with busy work, it will be on my phone when I am waiting in between classes.Creative Assembly revolutionized real time/turn based strategy gaming with the Total War franchise. My advice would be to stick to your niche and let the iOS devs stay in theirs.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												A lot of fun. Really wish there was a detailed tutoiral somewhere. I messed up my initial position because I did not quite get the synergy effects from nearby buildings.  Also caused a lot of accidental floods, etc. but it's still a whole lot of fun.  Played for 12 hours without buying any gold from market. Obviously that's the way to get the best out of your troops via gear. but made it to level 20 lord with no problems other than building and terrain mistakes.   And some tactics errors in battles. but it is a very fun medieval sim.I like that the classic problems of resource management are factors.  flooding, lack of funds, deforestation, really enjpying the challenges, and watching and managing the little towns that are built.I think it is the right mix between tactics and a little bit of strategy, plus kingdom management.  And the battles have the right level of command from the rear feel. A few simple commands, give your tropps the right formations, and trust to equipment and luck.Even if the troops lose battles, they learn and get better.  And armies can fight on without getting wiped out completely,  lessons learned, go at it again, with better tactics.Learning the battles and warfare as I go is a nice progression, building skills, makes it a semi RP game at a very low level.   And the graphics are really good and have a lot of flavor.  But not too intensive.  Playing from dialup on an old laptop, it's not a problem, unlike many other games on steam.Great job, developers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												This game is horrible.  The pace is slow, resources are limited (unless you pay), there is limited tactical flexibility, and the battles results are quite unrealistic.  It is just not fun to play compared to the stand-alone games in the Total War series.The Good: - Graphics and music are not bad.- It does actually work on iPad and Windows laptop.The Bad: - The server is often unavailable and you cannot complete combat missions.- Server repeatedly disconnected me during duels resulting in an immediate loss.- The battle mechanics are simple and unbalanced.  There is no tactical flexibility.- Battles are boring after the first few.- Terrain and weather have no impact on battles.- Even if the enemy is down to a handful of troops and you have overwhelming numbers, you will still lose if the server disconnects.- There is a limited technology tree.  Unit advancement is very slow.- The water flooding issue in spring was just plain annoying.The Ugly:- The game basically requires you to stay logged in all the time.  If you only log in once per day, your resources cap after about 1 hour and there is not much to do after about 10 minutes of game play.  After several weeks, I have made limited progress – two castles and a few units.- The game also strongly encourages (really requires) you to duel; and every time, I have been pitted against a total mismatch – someone whose level is far above mine.- Unit match-up results make no sense when fighting the AI.  Cavalry charge crossbowmen or archers…and somehow are all killed in the melee and not with missile weapons.  That seriously makes no sense.Total War Battles: SHOGUN was essentially a series of puzzles, solved through creative use of various units.  KINGDOMS is just an attempt to get you to pay for fleeting power-ups and resources on a recurring basis.  I recommend that you stick with the previous installments of Total War: Medieval, Shogun 2, or Empire specifically.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												While it seems like an interesting concept, the game is frustrating as hell, mostly because of the policy. Seriously, are you guys so money starved that you go on and ask for premium currency for freaking flag patterns? I understand speed ups, I understand micro transactions like cool looking vanity items, but in a strategy game of one of the most well-known franchises, you go on and charge for the "amazing privilege" of making your coat of arms navy blue or stripped? Even the emblems are for sale only, save 3-4 of the most simplistic. And honestly even the artwork of the emblems seems sloppy and doesn't even have enough variety. Simply ridiculous and annoying.Also, the game could not be more pay to win. And I know that there will be the crowd saying that "no you can very well create and gather all the items that you can buy with gold". While that might be true, it is only half true though. Because the amount of grinding and waiting required to achieve something someone who feels like emptying his pockets for Sega can achieve with a click, is comical. Crafting a single item/unit takes 2.5 days in the very best case and requires a ton of resources, especially early game. And while you struggle to get your barings, you go to a duel and have a same level player pound you with artillery and flaming arrows just because he appeased the coin hungry spirits of Sega with a couple of hard earned clicks.And the final touch is the silly terraforming that is both frustrating and before getting the gang of it can just flood your entire map. Just one step closer to creating Total War: Farmville... battle the toughest vegetables and conquer your garden!The game could be fun, some ideas are good. The implementation is really bad though, and the company policy, even worse.

												This game is simply the best medieval combat/kingdom simulator on mobile ever conceived; the fact that it's cross-platform is just icing on the cake. Those looking for a complete Total War experience are largely missing the point. KINGDOM takes the legacy of previous games (large-scale unit battles, resource management) and iterates upon them to make something entirely new. The result is a casual, portable and supremely fun game that you can play in short bursts from anywhere.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Product received for free
												Although 0.0 hours are shown on the last 2 weeks of my profile listed here, I've played this game on my iPhone everyday, several times a day, for about a month.  The i5 processor on the laptop (I'm using to type this review with) does not work as well. Too much lag.  But my phone plays this game very nicely (iPhone 6plus).  However, the play time does not appear to transfer over.  This game is, as other players have already noted, is geared more towards a phone or tablet. It's terrific for down time away from home.  It is a free download. However, the money this game generates for the company is by selling "gold" which can be used to advance your position rapidly. That's ok with me.  I like to work slowly and later decide to make a purchase with these type games.  Because I loved the Total war games that were published, I wanted to give this game a try.  First thing I noticed was the lack of instructions and no user manual that I could find. So starting off was mostly trial and error.  That was a little irksome, but I continued because I was still enjoying the experience.  I did find a forum on line that gave suggestions for play based on the authors' experience.  I used them to improve my game.  So, here's my first complaint about this game (1) Why the secrecy on play.  There may be players out there that like the challenge of exploring the unknown, but I find it tedious making the same mistake over and over again, not really knowing what I'm doing. The instructions offered are pitifully brief. I would have found it more interesting having a basic manual that showed what did what.  Like the classic PC games did.  The strategy can still be left up to me, but at least I wouldn't be fumbling around. I am sure there are players who do enjoy that approach.  I don't.Now, in spite of the initial trial and error period, I still found this game very interesting and started following the advice of the online forums.  As I said, I found myself playing this game every day, several times a day.  I was enjoying the process of slowly building my Kingdom.  This leads up to my final complaint: (2)  So, as I said, I'm slowly building up my Kingdom with farms, roads, castles, houses, blacksmiths, etc, and just got to the point of having 4 towns in 4 regions.  This was a long time in the making.  Then, I log in after an update today and find 2 of those towns completely destroyed.  No explanation.  Instead, there were 2 large large patches of icons, each indicating 'ruins' where the building once stood.  This, in short,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off.  No aspect of the game gave me a hint of this coming.  OK, again, maybe there are those who take this in stride and take up the challenge, but I personally play games on my iPhone for immediate comfort and gratification. There may be others out there, like me, who are not looking for unexpected massive tragedies, and very challenging play.  I just want to expand my own Kingdom at my own pace.  It would be nice if the publishers of these games would provide options to cover varying degrees of game difficulty for different target markets.That being said, I wish there was a choice for the above recommendation beyond "YES" "NO" if I recommend this game.  I would definitely recommend this game for those serious players who enjoy the challenges this game offers.  I wouldn't  for the vanilla players like me.  It's a shame.  I was really starting to enjoy this game.  I'm curious about the statistics of the purchases made by this game's players (of "gold").  If there is any correlation to time span played vs purchases.  I can say that I've lost my interest in continuing under these circumstances. By the way, the graphics are incredible.

												I absolutely love everything but one element about this game and I'm very sad that it's the old pay to win problem. It really isn't necessary, there are many business models that allow paying but not paying to win. The game is still in beta so there is still a chance for redemption and I believe this really would stand out among the other games of the same format due to its graphics, simplicity, unique features and style. Please please please remove the pay to win element and the fans will come flocking and you'll make more money that way (I hope).Update: I may have been a little hasty in saying it is pay to win as you can craft all items bought for gold.... It just takes a hell of a long time. But that's fine, it gives patient people the same options as impatient or time poor people to play the game to and these people are needed to keep the game going.... If no one spends money there is no game for anyone. One more thing. The game is still in beta so give it a chance. I have a feeling this will be something great. Overall...... I love this awesome game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Spending a bit more than eight hours on this might have been a serious mistake. At first, when I enlisted on participating in the beta, I was hoping that this might be a nice game (knowing the praise that the franchise gets from all it's fans) although I had played very little from other Total War games. After starting up the game and playing around with the options, I entered the tutorial. As previous reviewers have mentioned, there you are taught how to spend as much money as possible, to be only able to skip the ridiculous and tedious amounts of time you have to wait for the construction and completion of simple tasks. So, after I thought about it, I figured out why they decided to implement this peculiar feature: the game was designed for a mobile phone. The weird and unrealistic battle mechanics, the seemingly endless building time and the interface itself just shouted it out. But then came the simple question: Why did they release this for the PC? At least if they had it just for mobile devices, maybe they would have had the understanding of the community. Although this game is an abomination, I think that the developers will redeem themselves and put this setback aside, continuing to release good and ambitious titles, worthy of our money and respect.
