number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												A lot of fun. Really wish there was a detailed tutoiral somewhere. I messed up my initial position because I did not quite get the synergy effects from nearby buildings.  Also caused a lot of accidental floods, etc. but it's still a whole lot of fun.  Played for 12 hours without buying any gold from market. Obviously that's the way to get the best out of your troops via gear. but made it to level 20 lord with no problems other than building and terrain mistakes.   And some tactics errors in battles. but it is a very fun medieval sim.I like that the classic problems of resource management are factors.  flooding, lack of funds, deforestation, really enjpying the challenges, and watching and managing the little towns that are built.I think it is the right mix between tactics and a little bit of strategy, plus kingdom management.  And the battles have the right level of command from the rear feel. A few simple commands, give your tropps the right formations, and trust to equipment and luck.Even if the troops lose battles, they learn and get better.  And armies can fight on without getting wiped out completely,  lessons learned, go at it again, with better tactics.Learning the battles and warfare as I go is a nice progression, building skills, makes it a semi RP game at a very low level.   And the graphics are really good and have a lot of flavor.  But not too intensive.  Playing from dialup on an old laptop, it's not a problem, unlike many other games on steam.Great job, developers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												TLDR:Long waits between actions - spend gold to avoid.Simple, but fun, combat - made un-even by buffs bought with gold before each battle.The units you buy are limited - use (lots of) gold to buy better/more advanced ones.Don't want to do that? Spend vast amounts time/resources instead. Use (some) gold to make it faster. (Oh, you might fail in crafting them, too.)AI frequently uses higher leveled, advanced, units.Competative Multiplayer has all of these problems, made worse by wonky net-code.A fun, casual, strategy-lite game. Or, it would be, were it not spoiled by a steep powercreep in the combat minigame.  If it were just a game designed to be tough, that would be one thing.  Unfortuantely, giving attacking AI with full exp, top tier units and then calling that "challenging" (the term they use for medium difficulty) in the mid-game reveals a cynical attempt to push the player to spend gold (money) to even the field.It doesn't get much better in the 'campaign' section, where you are hampered by long waits for just about every action.Don't be fooled by the intial gameplay; the initially speedy pace slows dramticaly as the tutorials end.  Incidentaly, during the tutorial they give you some gold - which you then have to (as in, the game tells you to and does not progress if you don't) spend that gold to get around the long waits, establishing that this is 'normal' gamplay.Now, this might not be a problem in and of itself - you can just dip in and out, gather your rescources, play a battle or two - log off for an hour or two and then return.  However, this is a more expertly designed freemium game than that.You soon realise that the AI is using the units you don't have access to, generaly further leveled up than your own too.If you want those units, you either have to spend significant amounts of gold up-front or spend lots of time gathering stuff for crafting.  Then, wait a long time for the crafting to happen. Then, do it 5 more times for each item. If you decide that you can wait it out, gather your resources and use them to make a better army, you are attacked by AI periodicly.  If you fail to beat them or pay them off, they take a percentage of your resources when they leave.I'd give this a miss, folks.  Save the money you'd spend on gold - spend it on a game that has been designed and balenced to be entertaining.This is designed to extract the your gold - I mean cash - from you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												While it seems like an interesting concept, the game is frustrating as hell, mostly because of the policy. Seriously, are you guys so money starved that you go on and ask for premium currency for freaking flag patterns? I understand speed ups, I understand micro transactions like cool looking vanity items, but in a strategy game of one of the most well-known franchises, you go on and charge for the "amazing privilege" of making your coat of arms navy blue or stripped? Even the emblems are for sale only, save 3-4 of the most simplistic. And honestly even the artwork of the emblems seems sloppy and doesn't even have enough variety. Simply ridiculous and annoying.Also, the game could not be more pay to win. And I know that there will be the crowd saying that "no you can very well create and gather all the items that you can buy with gold". While that might be true, it is only half true though. Because the amount of grinding and waiting required to achieve something someone who feels like emptying his pockets for Sega can achieve with a click, is comical. Crafting a single item/unit takes 2.5 days in the very best case and requires a ton of resources, especially early game. And while you struggle to get your barings, you go to a duel and have a same level player pound you with artillery and flaming arrows just because he appeased the coin hungry spirits of Sega with a couple of hard earned clicks.And the final touch is the silly terraforming that is both frustrating and before getting the gang of it can just flood your entire map. Just one step closer to creating Total War: Farmville... battle the toughest vegetables and conquer your garden!The game could be fun, some ideas are good. The implementation is really bad though, and the company policy, even worse.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												The only reason I am recommending this game is because it is in beta right now and, despite the problems, it has potential. What problems? Crashing isn't really a problem, because when it does happen you lose nothing and it is very easy to get right back into the game because it is constantly running your scenario somewhere up there in the cloud.-Gold is a problem, not a solution. I have no idea how to get it. It is far easier to spend than get, so don't spend it, but then what is the point in having it.-Resources, in general, are a problem. Everything gets gathered so slowly you can't do anything without spending gold, which, when you do, you run out quickly and then can't do anything because you can't get gold. Either increase the yeild of basic level resource gathering facilities (because it costs way too much to upgrade them) or reduce the time it takes to gather the resources themselves. When you do have renewable resources like cattle and sheep, you can skin them for hides or sell them for 'honour,' but they don't let you keep a couple of them in order to keep the herd alive. Nope, they cut them all up and then you have to buy more cattle with the swiftly dwindling resources you no longer have.-Getting good units is a problem, because whenever you have a single type of unit of quality, like longsword knights, you can't make anymore. You can make other knights, but they cost gold and you can't get gold so you shouldn't spend it. You could craft units, but that takes a ridiculous amount of silver and hides, and as previously noted, resources like silver and hides take absolutely forever to gather in.-I have found that when you harvest something the results of the harvest can change dramatically. I have harvested all my wheat fields at once, but somehow get less per field than if I had done it one at a time. Ostensibly, the reason is that you don't have enough workers to get the full yield out of the wheat fields if harvested all at once. Then why did I sow all the wheat fields at once? And if we are going for reality, why don't we harvest wheat in the autumn and increase the yield to cover the year?-I have gathered wood from deadwood piled up on shore in odd places. The store of the deadwood when you click on it says 100. When you gather the wood though, you get 50 and the deadwood disappears. -Fishing takes longer than harvesting wheat. And fishing should replenish itself if you spread out and slow down your efforts. It does not, however, replenish itself.-Battles can be quite maddening. The good news is you never completely lose a unit unless you delete its training facility  or disband it. Mission difficulty seems to increase with your rank, but your troops don't really keep up because it costs so freaking much of the resources you can't gather fast enough or gold which you don't get just to upgrade training facilities in order to upgrade the unit, which has experience points from battling you can't use unless you do upgrade the training facility. So, as you continue along, you start to lose a lot of battles because your troops just can't keep pace. I'm losing about half now.-the Total War folks do put out codes to redeem in the game for free resources, which points out they are aware of how ridiculous it is to grow/gather your own stuff, but they seem to think that giving them out as 'single-use' codes is a good idea, so that only one person can use the code and then it is no good for whoever else is next. There are millions of gamers out there and I'm not tuned in to Facebook at all hours of the day, so I have given up on getting a code. Ever.That's a lot of complaining, but I do like the game. The persistent timeline is cool, I don't have to be playing for everyone to keep on working. All this having been said they have a lot of good stuff going on in the game and I am eager to see it developed further in its gameplay and in ways to play, like tablets. This is definitely better than the Total War Battles: Shogun.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Like: Beautiful art and design (Awesome job)Dislike:        •	Use of methods to nickel and dime your account, such as;           o	Takes only 3 or 4 min to prospect a mine but 8 hours (or 5 gold) to remove the digging equipment when it conveniently pops up in a location that would cause you to spend more real money if you wanted to transform all around the dig sight…. This as opposed to starting from camp and exploring in the immediate area then moving outward: but that would not prompt you to spend as much.           o	A.I. matching for duels makes it frustrating to the point either you spend a lot of money to equip or you quit playing all together. The people you duel against are generally over powered in relation to you if you are trying to play free as advertised.                  	If you have patients and are able to place, your second castle in the lower right so you can place a third in the upper middle, in a few months you might be able to make some gains.        •	In about six months to a year, you may be able to craft something. There are many other examples but that should suffice to make a point.       In short, I want to love this game but the matchups for duels are not even close to being balanced and the time or money it takes to get things done makes you want to just pay the forty dollars to buy one of the Total War titles (Rome etc.) and save yourself what could realistically amount to hundreds of dollars in just a few months.

												If you're a hardcore Total War fan avoid! The lack of battle field control makes it a formulaic scissors, rock, paper - no room for ambushes or clever flanking moves. It seems to be designed for 10 year olds with a smartphone and dad's credit card details. Very disapointed, got bored DURING the tutorial, that's always a bad sign. content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												I know my review is probably gonna be lost among the other 998 reviews before it and I have read a couple of them. I am gonna be honest here: Yes, it is a waiting game. This is a game designed around patience and strategy. Patience for the building and collecting of resources and strategy for the battles with your army. I have seen alot of people say in the other reviews that they have uninstalled the game SIMPLY because you can pay real cash for gold which instantly finishes any action you need to wait for. Yea the game gives you gold for free but it isn't much, and you know what? I never use any of it. I like the wait of collecting my farm or felling trees. Wanna know why? Because in real life this♥♥♥♥♥♥takes time to do and I think the game devs wanted to put some of that time into the game. How I deal with the wait times is log in, set everything up that I want done [Harvest farm, harvest trees, harvest rocks, build new buildings] and then close the game. You don't need to be logged in for the wait time to be in effect! You can set♥♥♥♥♥♥up, close the game and play something else, then later come back and BAM it is ready for you. This is a fun game for when I have nothing else to do and am looking for some kingdom building.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This game offers a two mode game similar to Campaign and Battle in Total war, but remade as "mini-town building" and "mini-tactical battles". Think a slow moving yet somewhat compact version of a Total War with other feature in mind. I find myself doing more landscaping and "town planning" by hex buildings -  This aspect is quite new but interesting because it gives something to explore for new players who come sign-up (although from this point, maybe people decide whether the game is their style or really hate how it does not feel like Total War).For battles, don't expect to see huge army stacks in epic battle. But quick skirmish with smaller "army groups" but with upgradeable and persistent soldier units. If you like a bit of RPG-element of improving stats and selecting which one to focus (although, there are not too many to worry about).If you dislike the trend of "freemium" games nowadays by any type and aspect, please beware of the "time limiter" of progress of both the town building and unit management for battles (the replinishment). While gold can still be acquired in game, it is not plenty and if you are not the waiting type, you may have to choose between paying real-life money to speed things up.So, adjust your expectation, think more like a "small-town army" manager game - with "mobile-style freemium" limits to action. If you can do this, then Total War Battles: Kingdom is a quick-fix game you can have on computer and take with you if you so feel attached to your hex town and warbands of upgradable units. It can still be likeable depending on your initial expectation.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												This game is horrible.  The pace is slow, resources are limited (unless you pay), there is limited tactical flexibility, and the battles results are quite unrealistic.  It is just not fun to play compared to the stand-alone games in the Total War series.The Good: - Graphics and music are not bad.- It does actually work on iPad and Windows laptop.The Bad: - The server is often unavailable and you cannot complete combat missions.- Server repeatedly disconnected me during duels resulting in an immediate loss.- The battle mechanics are simple and unbalanced.  There is no tactical flexibility.- Battles are boring after the first few.- Terrain and weather have no impact on battles.- Even if the enemy is down to a handful of troops and you have overwhelming numbers, you will still lose if the server disconnects.- There is a limited technology tree.  Unit advancement is very slow.- The water flooding issue in spring was just plain annoying.The Ugly:- The game basically requires you to stay logged in all the time.  If you only log in once per day, your resources cap after about 1 hour and there is not much to do after about 10 minutes of game play.  After several weeks, I have made limited progress – two castles and a few units.- The game also strongly encourages (really requires) you to duel; and every time, I have been pitted against a total mismatch – someone whose level is far above mine.- Unit match-up results make no sense when fighting the AI.  Cavalry charge crossbowmen or archers…and somehow are all killed in the melee and not with missile weapons.  That seriously makes no sense.Total War Battles: SHOGUN was essentially a series of puzzles, solved through creative use of various units.  KINGDOMS is just an attempt to get you to pay for fleeting power-ups and resources on a recurring basis.  I recommend that you stick with the previous installments of Total War: Medieval, Shogun 2, or Empire specifically.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												It's a great game and the fact that it's free is even better. It's a sad fact that my IPad is outdated and cannot have this game, but that's a personal problem. Let's get to the major good points and bad ones. The graphics are great, as is the gameplay. It's different from the other Total War games from the franchise, which gives it that one little slice of fun that the other games do not have. It's basically the little better version of Medieval II: Total War. There isn't much bad to be said about this game, it's free, has great graphics and the gameplay is just fine.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												I've gotten to a point where it's just a castle builder sim.  You only get limited unique troops.  Ranged combat is manual as well as timer delay when commanding multi troops.  Computer is typical "controls / react instantly" which detours most TBS games.  Eventually you get pitted against Tier 3 mobs, which make it nearly impossible as it takes literally several days to upgrade 1 troop gear stat when crafting, and the xp is very low to increase troop levels / tiers.Controls are a bit awkward.  Having to click so many times for resources is painful.  Click building .. click harvest 1 or 2 sources .. wait 5 mins .. only speed up is a hold click on building w/ auto collect but none the less painful slow collection.  There isn't enough to do to keep you playing more than 10 mins at a time, even then its usually waiting for a 2nd resource to complete.I typically to "harvest all" which greatly reduces your output and takes 1 hour.  But is much less of a hassle.
